column2: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 William Steinberg, who in 23 years has raised the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra to rank among the world's finest, announced today that he would give up his post as the orchestra's music director at the end of next season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Senate Republicans raised the possibility today of a Supreme Court challenge if Louis C. Wyman is stripped of his narrow victory as New Hampshire's junior Senator.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan 15 "The fact I'm here means it's a nice home," said 89-year-old Catherine M. Joyce today, about the private nursing home where she lives.

Mobile homes, the supposed low-cost alternative to conventional housing for millions of Americans, are instead highcost, shoddily built dwellings with worthless warranties, according to the Center for Auto Safety, which has released the results of a two-and-a-half year investigation of the mohome industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The nation got its most encouraging report on the inflation front in more than two years today, but there was also further confirmation of the deepening recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Supreme Court ruled today that Illinois could not send 59 insurgent Democrats to jail because they participated in the party's national convention of 1972 in place of delegates loyal to Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago.
A Brooklyn man who allegedly stole a woman's purse outside the Criminal Courts Building on Centre Street and then sought refuge in the courthouse was indicted yesterday for robbery and grand larceny.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. A man who stepped up to a window in City Court one day last week to pay two fines for moving violations was stunned to be asked a few minutes later to settle 16 delinquent parking tickets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Supreme Court upheld today the right of the armed services to treat men and women differently when an officer was forced to accept a discharge after being passed over for a promotion.
The first major tournament of 1975 accessible to New York enthusiasts, the Tristate Regional championships, begins today at Grossinger, N.Y. The schedule is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Influential Senators and House members were sharply critical today of many of President Ford's proposals to conserve energy and invigorate the economy, and there appeared to be little chance that the proposals would be approved intact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Ford Administration disclosed today that it expected the budget deficit to go as high as $34-billion this fiscal year and $47-billion in the fiscal year 1976, assuming Congress enacts the entire Ford economic program.
Blanche Dworsky Ratner, a pioneer in programs for the Jewish aged here, died Tuesday in Southport, Conn., at the age of 79.

The elderly woman on the telephone was indignant. A young neighbor in her building got parking tickets in wholesale lots but simply tore them up because he had arranged to get his license plates from a distant state. Besides, she said, he lives in a filthy room with a dozen cats, and he runs around the halls naked.
Indian Head, Inc., and the Beaunit Corporation announced jointly yesterday that Indian Head's subsidiary, Joseph Bancroft Sons, Inc., owner of the Ban-Lon trademark had been sold to Beaunit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Department of Justice gave its support today to the contention that involuntary patients in mental hospitals had a constitutional right to treatment.
Martin Luther King Day, a holiday in Massachusetts, helped send sales of ski lift tickets soaring in bordering southern New Hampshire yesterday.
Joseph Trerotola, president of Joint Council 16 of the Teamsters Union, is being challenged in his bid for re-election by John Mahoney, president of Local 808 of the teamsters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Following is the text of a report by William E. Colby, director of Central Intelligence, responding to charges of illegal domestic surveillance by the agency, which he submitted to the Senate Appropriations Committee today:
LONDON, Jan. 15 Newspaper owners warned printers tonight that they would be dismissed at 9 A.M. Friday unless they ended disruptive practices in pursuit of a claim for an extra 94 cents a week.
MOUNT HOLLY, Jan. 15 The Campisi murder and racketeering trial ended today before it formally began, with the last four of the nine defendants changing their pleas to guilty.

KUWAIT, Jan. 15 Kuwait will sell as much oil as customers will buy at price levels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries, and no mandatory reduction in output has been imposed for this year, according to highly placed oil officials here.

Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, a leader of the conservative Republicans, was quoted as having said that tax cuts would not save the economy and that the nation's economic ills resulted from Federal programs.
The first half of the National Basketball Association season was marked by an excessive amount of injuries to key players and some surprising turnabouts.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 "An outraged Governor will be joined by an outraged Health Commissioner," Dr. Robert P. Whalen said today, announcing on the eve of taking command of the State Health Department that he wanted to close 62 of New York State's 599 nursing homes because of "uncorrectable" fire hazards.

Rabbi Sol Roth, re-elected yesterday as president of the New York Board of Rabbis, said that the organization of some 1,000 Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbis in the metropolitan area and beyond was "deeply distressed" over alleged abuses in the nursing-home industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell's life might be in danger if he were sent to prison and other inmates were allowed access to him, Jeb Stuart Magruder said today.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., Jan. 15 A 15-year-old private school student killed his mother and father with an ax yesterday evening, the police said, and then committed suicide by jumping from a water tower a half mile from his home here.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 15 The land of 10,000 lakes appeared like the land of 10,000 missed opportunities tonight for the Minnesota North Stars and the Rangers. What appeared like an easy victory for New York turned into a hang-on, sweat-it-out 5-3 cliff-hanger.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 15 (AP) Cambodian insurgents tightened their blockade of Neak Luong today, heavily shelling the Mekong River town, sinking a barge carrying ammunition and forcing a seven-ship convoy to return to South Vietnam, military sources reported. Casualties were not immediately known.

Colin Davis is one of the eminent Berlioz conductors of the day, but last night in Carnegie Hall, as guest with the Boston Symphony, he was content to use his favorite composer merely as a curtainraiser. The "Waverley" Overtore is an immature work, Berlioz in utero as it were, but it is nice to hear once in a while.

Lawyers for Bernard Bergman served subpoenas yesterday on two state officials and a reporter for The New York Times, demanding that they appear with all notes and records of recent investigations of Mr. Bergman and the nursinghome industry.
ATHENS, Jan. 15 (UPI) George Papadopoulos, the former Greek dictator, refused to defend himself today against charges of high treason and insurrection before an investigating magistrate.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 15 (UPI) A commuter train proved faster today than a souped-up automobile in a race from the suburbs to Union Station.

A former employe of the Housing and Development Administration, who sued the City of New York, charging that he had been dismissed from his job for having publicly questioned the wisdom of constructing a huge housing development in Yorkville, has received an out-of-court settlement of $19,000.

OMAHA, Jan. 15 (UPI) A $25-million class action suit was filed today in United States District Court alleging that the president of American Beef Packers, Inc., of Omaha "embarked on a fraudulent scheme to cheat and defraud" hog and cattle producers.

No one was younger than 62, some were in their 80's, and about 90 per cent of them were women and they were all in the Lower East Side supermarket one morning this week to hear about a shopping experiment.
BOONTON, N.J., Jan. 15 Six members of a family died here late last night as a fire swept through their two-story home. Officials called it "the worst disaster we ever had here."
BONN, Jan. 15 (Reuters) West Germany has broken a Communist-directed espionage ring aimed against the International Business Machines Corporation, the Federal Public Prosecutor said today.
ATHENS, Jan. 15 (Reuters) The Government is taking over Olympic Airways following an agreement tonight with the shipping executive, Aristotle Onassis, it was officially announced here.

CORTLAND, Ill. "In the Middle Ages," Sidney Gross told us over a glass of homemade bee-sting liqueur, "honeybees were used as agents of warfare. The combatants would catapult the hives over castle walls to rout the enemy."

Ralph S. Saul, a former president of the American Stock Exchange, who joined the INA Corporation as vice chairman last August, will become chief executive officer of the diversified financial services company this April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Besides the vast economic stakes involved, President Ford has also gambled his political future on the program he presented to Congress today in his State of the Union Message, Whether he wins or loses should be determined within a year, give or take a few months.

In the third and most severe round of budget-reducing cutbacks so far, Mayor Beame announced yesterday that 4,050 additional city employes, including policemen, firemen, sa- nitationmen and teachers, would be dismissed next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel opened a crucial series of discussions today on how to make progress in the next round of Israeli-Egyptian negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, acknowledged at a Senate hearing today that his agency had infil- trated undercover agents into antiwar and dissident political groups inside the United States as part of a counterintelligence program that led to the accumulation of files on 10,000 American citizens.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 President Ford submitted to Congress today a many-sided energy independence plan that would mean higher energy prices for all consumers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Influential Senators and House members were sharply critical today of many of President Ford's proposals to conserve energy and invigorate the economy, and there appeared to be little chance that the proposals would be approved intact.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (AP) Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn charged today that Soviet authorities had begun a neo-Stalinist strategy aimed at cutting the links of all dissidents with the outside world.

Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Systems, Inc., Washington, has received a $252.6-million increase under a Navy contract to complete financing of the last seven destroyers in a 30-ship program.
American businessmen, who had just begun to profit from hard-won business with the Soviet Union, were chagrined yesterday by the annulment of the United States-Soviet trade agreement.
LONDON, Jan. 15 Leeds Castle, an ancient fortress once belonging to a family that helped colonize Virginia, has been bequeathed to the British nation.
CAIRO The most probable option facing all parties in the Middle East is another war between the Arabs and the Israelis. But another war will be different from the previous ones.

We have a slogan. On his television teaser Monday night, President Ford spoke of his "new direction"; he repeated it twice in his State of the Union address yesterday; in his transmittal messages for the budget and economic reports in coming weeks, the "new direction" will flutter like a banner over the fine print.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 Japan's Foreign Minister and a senior member of the governing party left Tokyo today on separate trips to Moscow and Peking in pursuit of peace treaties to bring a formal end to World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 President Ford blamed Congress today for the breakdown in efforts to exchange American trade benefits for liberalized Soviet emigration practices. But key Senators and American Jewish groups blamed the Soviet Union.
Leverett F. Hooper, a retired banker, died Tuesday at his home. He was 81 years old and lived at 29 Gordon Road, Essex Fells, N.J.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 15 India and Pakistan agreed today to re-establish shipping links as part of a general resumption of trade.
PARIS, Jan. 15 Pierre DavidWeill, an art patron and a partner of Lazard Freres Co. here and in New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Fiinance Ministers representing both rich and poor countries agreed today on a $6-billion "oil facility" within the International Monetary Fund to help nations pay their oil bills in 1975. The ministers also reportedly agreed on a new feature for the facility interest rate subsidies on loans to about 30 of the very poorest nations.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. A man who stepped up to a window in City Court one day last week to pay two fines for moving violations was stunned to be asked a few minutes later to settle 16 delinquent parking tickets.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 (AP) The Palestinian guerrilla command here said Israeli naval vessels shelled a refugee camp and other targets in southern Lebanon today hours after an Israeli troop attack on a southern Lebanese village. No casualties in the naval attack were immediately reported. [Eight Israelis were wounded in the ground attack on the village, the Israeli command said.]
Dr. Joseph A. Tamerin, a plastic surgeon and medical archivist, died Tuesday at his home at 876 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.

From a barely perceptible beginning about 14 months ago, the longest recession since the end of the Great Depression is biting deeper into the nation's economy with widespread unemployment and plant closings.

In his new book "200 Open Games," the Russian grandmaster David Bronstein says, "You can have what views you like, but there is no such thing as a competitive player that's plain fiction." As is habitual with him, Bronstein neglects to provide any defense for his assertion.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (UPI) Two Soviet astronauts aboard the orbiting Salyut 4 space station carried out complex navigational experiments and set up a teletype link to earth today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 The Republican staff of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, concluding from a computer study that "the effects of inflation on state finance are stronger than the effect of recession," predicted today that the state would end its current fiscal year with a surplus of $150million or more.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 (AP) Israeli officials expressed dismay today over the collapse of the United States-Soviet trade agreement because of Moscow's objections to American legislation linking trade benefits to freer emigration for Jews.

While applauding the broad goals of President Ford's State of the Union Message, many executives and economists expressed dissatisfaction yesterday with the specifics of his program, particularly with regard to energy matters.

Golda Meir entered Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital yesterday for cataract surgery. The 76-year-old former Israeli Premier, who recently ended six weeks of fundraising abroad, had been active up to her hospital admission.
Following is a transcript of President Ford's State of the Union Message delivered to Congress yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The York Times:

ASCHAFFENBURG, West Germany, Jan. 15 (UPI) The United States Army gave a bearded, long-haired soldier a special discharge today in an effort to block a defense bid for a test to determine whether his beard interfered with the efficiency of a gas mask.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 15 (UPI) The drilling of 53 offshore oil wells in the Santa Barbara Channel and construction of a controversial oil pipeline have been halted, at least temporarily, by the new State Lands Commission.
WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Jan. 15 (AP) A crowd of 900 taxpayers overwhelmingly approved a fourth budget proposal tonight, bailing the city government out of a temporary crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, acknowledged at a Senate hearing today that his agency had infiltrated undercover agents into antiwar and dissident political groups inside the United States as part of a counterintelligence program that led to the accumulation of files on 10,000 American citizens.
PARIS, Thursday Jan. 16 The Constitutional Council ruled today that the abortion bill passed Dec. 4 by the French National Assembly is constitutional.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15 Four Yugoslavs of Albanian origin have been tried and imprisoned on charges of plotting against the state and the Communist party.
Dr. George W. Slaughter, a urologist, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home. He was 70 years old and lived at 111 East 48th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 For official Washington, the sting of yesterday's announcement that Moscow had rejected the 1972 trade accord will be felt more in the arena of American domestic politics than in that of Soviet American detente itself. The general reaction is that detente will survive, but that someone will have to be blamed anyway.

MOUNTAINSIDE, Jan. 15 A 15-year-old private school student killed his mother and father with an axe yesterday evening, the police said, and then committed suicide by jumping from a water tower a half mile from his home here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 The controversy surrounding the plans of Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian businessman, to buy a one-third interest in the First National Bank of San Jose, Calif., intensified today when Mr. Khashoggi filed suit in Federal District Court here.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. l5 (AP) The Kansas City Royals said today they had signed Harmon Killebrew. He is expected to join Kansas City after getting his unconditional release from the Minnesota Twins.

The Public Schools Athletic League honored the memory of Martin Luther King yesterday with a track meet for its member schools at the 102d Engineers Armory. It was the fifth annual indoor memorial event.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (UPI) Yvan Cournoyer scored twice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens extended their undefeated string to 21 games two short of the National Hockey League record by beating the Boston Bruins, 5-3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) The Federal Parole Board today denied parole for Otto Kerner Jr., the former Illinois Governor and Federal judge who is serving a three-year sentence on charges of bribery, mail fraud, tax evasion, perjury and conspiracy.
The big dome of the Hayden Planetarium, usually given over to kibitzing the course of galaxies, is being taken over these weekend nights by the laser beam.
NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, Jan. 14 Every 15 minutes or so a shell screams down and explodes in this besieged town and another half-dozen people are killed or wounded. It goes on day and night.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 15 (UP) A Syracuse man was sentenced today to up to four years in prison in the traffic death of a 10-year-old boy last year.

SANTA CLARA, Caif., Jan. 15 The United States electronic industry has developed circuitry so miniaturized that it is pushing to install many computer functions in such things as automobiles, gasoline pumps, traffic signals and supermarket cash registers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that he had been repeatedly urged by White House aides to President Nixon to interfere in the prosecution of the Watergate case.

The basketball shooting talent of John Gerdy of Passaic Valley High was evident to coach Carmen DiSimoni two years before the youngster became a freshman. So, it was not a total surprise to DiSimoni that in his first year at the Little Falls school, Gerdy scored 648 points for the varsity and developed a reputation as one of the better shooters in the state.

LONDON, Jan. 15 The Government announced plans today for the nationalization of the British aircraft industry and the formation of a state-owned corporation to take over the business and assets of three major aircraft producers.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel who was released from prison last week after serving a four-month sentence for his part in the Watergate coverup, began building a new life in a new home here today.

A 39-year-old West Orange, N.J., man and an 11-year-old boy described as having a "striking resemblance" to the pair being sought for the murder of a Leonia, N.J., nurse were arrested yesterday by the Fairfield borough police, who later charged the man with the possession of a concealed weapon a 13 -inch kitchen knife.
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had purchased the Star-News newspapers of Wilmington, N.C., the only newspapers published in Wilmington, which has a population of 46,000.

SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 16 (AP)--Annemarie Proell of Austria, who was fourth after the first run, zipped through the second slalom run on the Mount Kapell course today to continue her domination in the World Cup standing.

Spokesmen for builders and gasoline dealers--two groups that would be immediately affected by implementation of President Ford's energy proposals--expressed misgivings yesterday about the effects of his plans for added fees and taxes on oil and other petroleum products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Finance Ministers representing both rich and poor countries announced tonight an agreement package intended to help the international economy to cope with the vast flow of money to oil-producing coun

CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 16 --No one blinked today when the Nevada Gaming Control Board came eyeball to eyeball with Morris Shenker, the 68year-old St. Louis lawyer who has helped arrange loans of far more than $100-million from the Teamsters Union Central State Pension Funds.
From six-billion possible combinations of games, baseball's schedule for the 1975 season is almost ready to fuel the fires of the hot-stove league.
"These people don't care about money," said a jubilant Frank Scalpone, managing director of the National Boat Show, where--in addition to spirits--sales and attendance are also up.
From the Soviet Union's repudiation of the tradeemigration compromise negotiated by Secretary Kissinger with Moscow and Senate leaders, the country should learn some important lessons.
NEWARK, Jan. 16--Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that he would cut 370 employes from the city payroll in an effort to reduce a projected $35.7-million deficit in his budget for this year.

TRENTON, Jan. 16--Warning that the state faced an immediate fiscal crisis, Governor Byrne ordered today the impounding of $66-million in the current budget, in an effort to head off a mounting deficit.
Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday for the second straight session but ended higher as trading accelerated.

Faced by an expected net loss of about $175-million for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31-- probably the largest retailing deficit in recent history--the W.T. Grant Company is involved in a retrenchment that will close 126 stores during the year and, cut its employment by 12,600 by April 1.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 16--The Provisional I.R.A. called an end tonight to its 25-day cease-fire.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 16--The American Embassy here said today that there was an emergency contingency plan to use the United States Air Force to run a large supply airlift into Cambodia to keep the Phnom Penn Government from falling to the insurgents.

ALBANY, Jan. 16--A pollution-control plan that would discourage the use of private cars in midtown Manhattan was put on Governor Carey's desk today.

The Metropolitan Opera is not perhaps the appropriate place for a 28-year-old bass to test his second-ever Don Giovanni on any stage. Be that as it may, the Met was fortunate to have James Morris on hand to step into the role Wednesday night...

Mayor Beame said yesterday he planned to organize a conference of Northeast mayors as the first step in a "mobilization of the leaders of government, business and consumers to insure that this sector of the country will not bear any greater burden than the rest of the nation in terms of fuel costs or its availability."

With no protesters, present and the bitterness of a three-year neighborhood battle with city authorities a dimming memory, Mayor Beame yesterday cut a ribbon symbolizing the formal opening of the controversial 50,000-square-foot addition to the Northside, Brooklyn...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Thirty-four prominent scientists, 11 of them nuclear physicists, released today a joint statement saying there was no reasonable alternative to the increased use of nuclear power to satisfy the United States energy needs.

The chances are that even in this new Congress, new power centers are likely to develop in the House--one following Messrs. Albert and O'Neill, another reformist group focusing on Representative Phillip Burton of California and Mr. Udall, and a third conservative faction going with Joe D. ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--To the consternation of the United States Army, the Defense Department has invited West Germany to enter a multibilliondollar competition to develop a new main battle tank for the United States.
BOSTON, Jan. 16--New England political and business leaders are taking a dim view of President Ford's proposed $3-a-barrel fee on imported oil.

DETROIT, Jan. 16--The United States auto industry's stone wall against price cuts appeared to be crumbling today with the announcement by the Ford Motor Company that it was following the lead of the Chrysler Corporation in offering large rebates in an attempt to improve slumping sales.

EAST ORANGE, Jan. 16--A high-speed chase of a stolen car by policemen from Newark and East Orange ended this afternoon with a 15-year-old passenger in the car dead of a gunshot wound and the driver held on a charge of juvenile delinquency.

Janet Baker gave her only New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, and as usual the British mezzo-soprano came, sang and conquered. She is gifted, and fortunate. Her career has not run very long, but al-...

The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, yesterday issued integration orders, based on reassignment of pupils, to be implemented fully in five cities by next fall. The cities are Buffalo, Utica, Newburgh, Lackawanna and Mount Vernon.
PARIS, Jan. 16--Twenty West European Communist parties issued a joint declaration today calling on Europeans to "block the military adventure planned by the United States in the Middle East."

ALBANY--The 1975 seed catalogues were mailed earlier than usual this season in anticipation of a big year, and New York State's seed merchants report that the orders are pouring in--especially for vegetables--and at higher prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Heroin from Southeast Asia is entering the European illicit drug market in a new and growing traffic that has United States narcotics experts seriously worried.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Faced with increasing criticism, the atomic energy industry has decided to almost double the funds it devotes to influencing the views of key Government officials, newsmen and such organizations as labor unions and women's groups.
ALBANY, Jan. 16--A pollution-control plan that would discourage the use of private cars in midtown Manhattan was put on Governor Carey's desk today.

Wandering through this week's National Boat Show at the New York Coliseum, I had something of the same feeling I had as a child standing before the penny candy booth in George Gifford's general store: then and now I was overwhelmed by the variety of choices.

A Bronx printer and a city youth counselor were arrested yesterday and charged with possession of 8,000 forged high school equivalency diplomas and an equal number of bogus high school transcripts, the police reported.

A journalist who is not in love with H.L. Mencken would be like a Jesuit priest not in love with--well, Mencken wouldn't like us to mention His name, but you get the message. To Mencken a typewriter was an infernal

For many years after the first press agent sat down to lunch with a reporter for the first time, the problem of how to handle the free tickets, free trips and other gifts proffered by news sources to reporters and editors has plagued the media.

TOKYO, Jan. 16--Japan's top two political leaders asserted today that their Government would continue to restrain the Japanese economy to fight inflation despite the shift to expansionary economic policies in the United States and West Germany.
BEACON, N.Y., Jan. 16 --A few degrees in temperature has cost this Dutchess County ski area about $1million. Snowmaking machines here are ready to cover...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Ever since Woodrow Wilson wrote his masterful study of "Congressional Government" in 1913, thoughtful men and women here have been complaining about the "divine right" of the committee chairmen in the House and calling for modification of the seniority system. Now, finally, something is actually being done about it.

EPISKOPI, Cyprus, Jan. 16-- The division of Cyprus into two districts came a bit closer today as about 10,000 Turkish Cypriote refugees prepared to leave the southern part of the island for Turkey and probably eventual resettlement in areas in northern Cyprus now controlled by Turkish troops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--Finance ministers representing both rich and poor countries announced tonight agreements intended to help the international economy cope with the vast flow of money to oil-producing countries and to deal with several other monetary problems.

Federal Energy Administrator Frank G. Zarb said last night that the Government would limit the rise in the price of home heating oil that would be produced by the Administration's proposed $3-abarrel tariff on imported crude oil.

DETROIT, Jan. 16--The United States auto industry's stone wall against price cuts appeared to be crumbling today with the announcement by the Ford Motor Company that it was following the lead of the Chrysler Corporation in offering large rebates in an attempt to improve slumping sales.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 16--Enter Dale Rolfe, defenseman; exit Rick Middleton, forward. That's the kind of stage directions the New York Rangers were forced to give as they prepared for tomorrow's game against the California Golden Seals in Oakland.

EL SOCKO--These chilly nights, El Avram radiates warm earthy informality, with a boisterous flow of international melody (you're expected to chime in). This spacious cellar, with its Israeli-based entertainment, kosher food and smiling patrons (and returnees) pack-...

MOSCOW, Jan. 16--The Soviet Union said tonight that it was not to blame for the collapse of the 1972 trade agreement and that it still sought trade with the United States, but only when "mutually beneficial.

LUCKNOW, India, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Amritraj brothers, who lost to New Zealand in the opening singles matches, came back for a doubles victory today that kept India in contention for the Davis Cup. New Zealand led, 2-1, with the final two singles matches of the East Zone series scheduled for tomorrow.
For the second week in a row, corporate loans from major New York City banks declined sharply, Since New Year's Day, corporate loans here have dropped almost $1-billion.

The New York Secretary of State, Mario M. Cuomo, said yesterday in a report on the nursing-home inquiry that "there is now good evidence that there are in existence a number of powerful syndicates which own multiple homes and which operate them as a big business."
Who is this Crazy Boot Maker selling boots at $2.99 and $3.99 a pair at Manhattan Center, 34th Street and Eighth Avenue, from 8 A.M. to midnight?
Nervous corn speculators sold vigorously yesterday in advance of the Government's final 1974 production report for corn and soybeans, which came after the close.

One if by Land, Two if by Sea, a curiously named restaurant of pleasant aspect at 17 Barrow Street, has become so popular that you can hardly get a table, is so crowded that you can hardly push through to your table after you get it and is so noisy that once you get seated you can shout your most intimate secrets to your dinner, partner without fear of being heard, much less overheard.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16--The Soviet Union said tonight that it was not to blame for the collapse of the 1972 trade agreement and that it still sought trade with the United States, but only when "mutually beneficial.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 16--The Provisional I.R.A. called an end tonight to its 25-day cease-fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- The American Civil Liberties Union won a $12-million damage suit against the District of Columbia today for what a jury said was the false arrest and infringement of rights of 1,200 antiwar demonstrators on the steps of the Capitol in 1971.

The ordeal known as applying for nursery school began in the fall and is at its peak now at some schools, as 2-and 3-year-olds are readied for their first classroom experience in September. At the most desirable private schools, forms must be filled out, parents interviewed, schools toured, the tuition (often well over $1,000 for a year of half-day sessions) worried about.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress today that the C.I.A. had become involved in domestic intelligence gathering on Presidential authority because of "the sudden and quite dramatic upsurge of extreme radicalism in this country and abroad" beginning in the late nineteen-fifties.
Utility rates in the metropolitan area would go up 5 to 20 per cent in the short run under President Ford's energy proposals, according to preliminary calculations by the area's utility companies.

Johnson (Masters) at ease, for a change--stripped of their laboratory coats and no longer mumbling in the technical language of their first two books, "Human Sexual Response" and...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The Democrats in the House of Representatives voted today to unseat the chairmen of two important House committees, Armed Services and Agri culture, throwing Congressional tradition into turmoil for the second successive day.

WILLIMATIC, Conn., Jan. 16--The Great Taxpayer Revolt ended in victory for the rebels here last night, when they forced a 9 per cent tax cut on the city. But no one in this economically hard-hit industrial community in the poor northeastern corner of the state is still quite sure why it happened at all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--One of the earliest confrontations between President Ford and the new Congress is likely to come over his decision yesterday to resubmit the name of former Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut to be a Federal appelate judge.

The Rockwell International Corporation reported yesterday a 23.2 cent drop in earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31. The decline was the second successive quarterly drop in profits.

The city's Labor Relations Director, John T. Burnell, said yesterday that the contract demands of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, if granted, would cost $274-million during the proposed two-year contract period.
Daniel J. Sullivan, secretarytreasurer of the 300,000-member Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks, died Saturday at his home in Deerfield, Ill. He was 59 years old.
The First National City Bank has taken the small print and confusing legalese out of its consumer-loan agreements, the bank announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Department of Justice charged today that the students and faculties of Mississippi's 25 state college and universities were racially segregated illegally.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 20 (UPI) There is a 3.5 million barrel a day oversupply situation among the 12 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Valentin Hernandez, Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons of Venezuela said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 Rod Laver, the most feared man in the tournament, followed Alex Metreveli to the sidelines in reversals marking the opening of the $115,000 United States pro indoor tennis championship today at the Spectrum.
In the 1950's Walter Winchell, the late Broadway columnist, began touting stocks on his broadcasts. His tips invariably proved to be winners no doubt because he had a considerable following.
TEHERAN, Iran The apartment views include gleaming domes of mosques. But the children aren't allowed to ride their bikes and new arrivals are plagued by an ailment known as "T.T."
Government security markets were under pressure yesterday, but Wall Street closed down before it got word of the big good news a lowering of reserve requirements by the Fed eral Reserve, a ...
A five-alarm fire, whipped by 20-mile-an-hour gusts, destroyed two adjacent five-story tenements and damaged two others in Harlem las night, leaving at least 100 persons homeless.

Paine Webber, Inc., parent of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's most prominent brokerage houses; reported to stockholders at its annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that firstquarter profits were down slightly. It was the first major brokerage firm to report so far this year.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday quashed subpoenas that had been served on Bernard Bergman and others in the nursing-home industry by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs, headed by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein. The justice, Hyman Korn, said the commission had exceeded its authority to investigate economic matters and had moved into criminal matters.

Steel production for the week ended Jan. 18 slipped by 1.3 per cent and remained well behind the total for the first 18 days of 1974, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Aluminum Company of America released yesterday a preliminary annual report that showed fourth-quarter sales and operating revenues were up 17.8 per cent, with net income 17.9 per cent higher than in the final quarter of 1973. Sales and revenues for the full year rose by 26.4 per cent and net income soared 66.1 per cent above 1973.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a legal dispute that could result in lower rent or carrying charges for hundreds of thousands of owners of cooperative apartments and condominiums throughout the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 Federal District Judge William T. Sweigert sentenced Jack P. Burke today to 30 months in jail for making false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the promotion of his Geotek oil exploration ventures.

Dr. Leonard S. Friedman, founder and president of the Abbe Institute School of Adult Education at 100 Fifth Avenue, died Friday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 151 West 86th Street.

The Contemporary Dance System has been brilliantly succeful in mounting works from the established repertory, but maedly less successful in creating it own new works. The final program of its current appeance was given on Sunday at Pace University's Schimmel Center.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 20 Thousands of youthful demonstrators attacked the American cultural center here today. Major damage was averted only when Archbishop Makarios calmed the crowd.
LONDON, Jan. 20 The British Government abandoned plans today to build a tunnel under the English Channel linking Britain and France.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Jan. 19 In a huge, high-ceilinged, windowless building here, engineers are assembling and testing some of the satellites that, when positioned 22,000 miles above the Equator, will significantly expand within two years the use of satellites for domestic communications.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 20 Mayor Beame, exercising the leadership role conferred on him by the National Conference of Democratic Mayors, called today for an end to Federal-city budgetary friction and for the beginnings of "domestic detente."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The A.H. Robins Company said today it was taking off the market all Dalkon Shield intrauterine contraceptive devices of the type involved in 14 deaths and at least 219 cases of infected abortions.
Should people in the audience of "Let My People Come" be allowed to drink liquor while watching nude performers simulate sex acts on the stage of the Village Gate?

NBC-TV appears determined to tap California's High Sierras for entertainment and profit. The TV network tried, and failed, with "Sierra," a weekly series about forest rangers thrust into thoroughly unbelievable situations. It tries and fails again, with "Death Stalk," a 90-minute made-for-TV movie that will be foisted on the mass public at 8:30 tonight.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday quashed subpoenas that had been served on Bernard Bergman and others in the nursing-home industry by the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs, headed by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein. The justice, Hyman Korn, said the commission had exceeded its authority to investigate economic matters and had moved into criminal matters.

Millions of acres of spruce and balsam fir are being destroyed by the spruce budworm in the forests of northern Maine, but DDT, the pesticide that lingers for years in the environment with deleterious effects on many forms of life should not be used, says Nathaniel P. Reed, assistant secretary for fish, wildlife and parks in the Interior Department.

The Federal Energy Administration is contducting an intensive study of the coal industry's price structure to determine whether the industry is enjoying excess profits, Frank G. Zarb, Federal Energy Administrator, said yesterday.

The National Maritime Union, representing 25,000 deep-sea sailors aboard 300 United States merchant ships, yesterday told shin owners that it wanted a new three-year contract that would protect members against inflation.
GRESHAM, Wis., Jan. 20 (AP) A spokesman for a 26-group Indian council said today that the organization was withdrawing support of Indian militants occupying a religious estate.

The General Foods Corporation, a major producer of packaged food and a leading factor in coffee production, reported yesterday a 3.9 per cent profit decline for the third fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 28. There was a profit gain of 1.9 per cent in the nine-month period. Sales set records in both the quarter and nine months.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) The United States is seeking "occasional use of airfield facilities" at a British-run air base on Masira Island, which commands the entrance to the Persian, Gulf, and Britain is considering the request, the Foreign Office said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Senate Democratic Caucus voted 45 to 7 today to set up a bipartisan select committee, similar to the one established after the Watergate break-in, to investigate all aspects of foreign and domestic operations of the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government intelligence units.

Those countries which for so long chose to overlook crimes against world aviation may at last be recognizing the toll of their malign neglect. For the second time in a week, clumsy but well-armed Arab terrorists opened fire at Paris's Orly Airport, missing their Israeli targets completely but spreading injury, damage and grief among innocent and unsuspecting air travelers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Federal Reserve Board today took its second major action in less than three weeks to combat the recession by making money for bank loans more easily available.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Department of Transportation said today that it had asked a Federal court to order the General Motors Corporation to notify the owners of an estimated 816,000 older model cars that the cars contain what the department alleges are safetyrelated defects.

His clients don't consider him a real bookie, and neither do most law-enforcement agents. He's simply the "guy with the cards," as customers put it, the do-it-yourself hustler who offers casual sports bettors a chance to make a lot for a little by wagering a dollar or two on the outcome of many games on a single day or weekend.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 King Faisal of Saudi Arabia flew home today after a week-long tour of Syria, Jordan and Egypt, during which he gave large amounts of financial aid to all three countries as well as to the Palestinian movement. King Faisal also supported Egypt's policy of accepting the American stepby-step approach to peace moves for a while longer.

TRENTON, Jan, 20 Senate Democrats voted to exclude Senator Alene S. Ammond of Camden County from their majority party caucus today following her renewed charges that some Senators were guilty of conflicts of interest and that the Senate was trying to kill a State Commission of Investigation inquiry into alleged political corruption in South Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The shape of the campaign for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination is being quietly but perhaps drastically altered.
Mayor Beame is expected to decide soon on a proposal by midtown planners to turn a three-block section of Broadway at the northern end of Times Square into a permanent mall.

Anthony Newman, a lavishly gifted young organist and harpsichordist, stands at an important crossroads right now, and it should soon become evident whether he hopes to become a significant artist or will be content to be a semipopular entertainer with a cultist following. Both tendencies could be discerned at Mr. Newman's concert Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall.

The Board of Education, told by Mayor Beame last week to lay off 700 employes to ease the city's fiscal crisis, will be permitted instead to avoid the dismissals by effecting $3.2million on other economies to cover the employes' salaries.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 20 Surrounded by symbols of political change and offering lessons in smooth race relations, George Corley Wallace was sworn in today for a third term as Governor of Alabama.

MAHWAH, Jan. 20 As more than 7,000 assembly-line workers returned to work at Ford Motor Company plants here and in Metuchen today, officials of the United Auto Workers Union petitioned officials in New York-State and New Jersey to suspend the state sales taxes on autos and major appliances.
The advent of Medicaid in 1967 produced an enormous inusion of public money into nursing homes that drew legitimate businessmen into the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Labor Department, warning that exposure to inorganic arsenic may cause cancer in thousands of American workers, proposed strict new work rules today on the use of the industrial chemical.

MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Jan. 20 A well-organized emergency care system involving firemen, policemen, laymen and even high school students in the city of Seattle is saving the lives of one in four persons whose hearts stop during a heart attack, a physician reported here today.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 20 Rear Adm. Charles F. Martin, commander of the battleship Pennsylvania in World War II and later of Manus Island Naval Base in the Pacific during World War II, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Ford was confronted today with the first specific challenge from Congress over a key part of his economic and energy proposals that would increase fuel prices by imposing higher fees on imported crude oil.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 Women activists, irate because Governor Byrne had appointed his commissioner of Community Affairs, Patricia O. Sheehan, to serve aso as "acting" director of the New Division on Women, converged at noon today on the Governor's office. They demanded that he appoint a fulltime permanent director instead.

CALVERTON, L.I., Jan. 20 Arthur Gilmore, a tall, professorial-looking man, waved toward the freshly fallen snow and told his class: "That's one thing Iran has in common with this country. But very little else. It's a different world you're going to."

GRAPEVINE, Tex. Charles C. Smith, a Chicago sales executive, rushed up to a Delta Air Lines boarding gate at the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport here the other day, four minutes before his plane was scheduled to take off for Los Angeles.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 The General Motors Corporation, the giant of the automobile industry, yesterday became the last of the Big Three auto makers to announce hefty rebates to customers in an attempt to spur sales of new cars and lift the industry out of one of its worst slumps since World War II.

Thomas Hart Benton died with his boots on, and he would not have minded the use of that cliche. He was always vehemently devoted to supporting the legitimacy of anything familiar and directly understandable, especially if it had any connection with folklore or folk expression.

WASHINGTON "In the many years that I have been a member of Congress, the House has revealed itself to me as ineffective in its role as a coordinate branch of the Federal Government, negative in its approach to national tasks, generally unresponsive to any but parochial economic interests. Its procedures, time-consuming and unwieldy, mask anonymous centers of irresponsible powers. Its legislation is often a travesty of what the national welfare requires."

The RCA Corporation reported yesterday that its fourthquarter net income fell 68.9 per cent from the year-ago level, while net income for the full year trailed 1973 by 38.3 per cent. Sales and other revenues were at highs for both periods.
Two former Democratic United States Senators Eugene McCarthy and Fred Harris have chosen lesstraveled roads in their respective quests for the Presidency.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 Governor Carey asked the Legislature today for $88-million to finance the completion of the Albany Mall, a legacy of his Republican predecessors that he disparaged as recently as three weeks ago in his inaugural address.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20, Both houses of Congress were preparing today for inquiries into the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the files it maintained over the years on public figures and politicians.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld the murder verdict against William R. Phillips. He did so, he said, even though the prosecution had erred by failing to report that during the trial a juror had applied for a job with the District Attorney's office.

Edward Albee's new play, "Seascape," which begins previews tonight and opens on Sunday at the Shubert Theater, is about a middleaged married couple (Deborah Kerr and Barry Nelson) who encounter two lizardcreatures (Frank Langella and Maureen Anderman) on a beach. This is Mr. Albee's first play since "All Over" in 1971, and the first premiere that he has directed. It is also the first time that his cast has not been entirely human.

The New York Civil Liberties Union has condemned the efforts at City College to oust Dr. Stanley W. Page and has called upon the institution's president to ask the faculty senate "to restrain itself" Dr. Page, a controversial history professor who has criticized some of his colleagues, is threatened with a violation of his freedom of speech under the First Amendment, according to the civil liberties organization, which says it stands ready to defend him.
When Coach Butch van Breda Kolff and his New Orleans Jazz were last in New York on Dec. 28, the Knicks sent them away with a seven-game losing streak.

The Virginia Supreme Court has disbarred Charles W. Colson, former White House special counsel, who has been a lawyer in Virginia since 1958. The court agreed with the state bar association, which asked for disbarment on the ground that Mr. Colson, who is 42 years old, had demonstrated "a reckless disregard" of the "integrity of the legal profession and the judicial system."
The police arrested a 16-yearold youth in South Jamaica, Queens, yesterday and charged him in connection with the kidnappings of three women during December.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Administration officials said today that enough progress had been made in the East-West conference on European security to allow the United States to begin planning for a final meeting next summer of the heads of state and Government of the 35 participating countries.

George J. Abrams and Griswold-Eshleman, after just a little more than two years together, have decided to go their separate ways. George J. Abrams Associates had been half owned by the Cleveland-based agency and was in effect its New York office.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 20 An unwed, pregnant public school teacher who had been transferred to a librarian's job was denied reinstatement to her classroom by a District Court judge today.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 The head of South Korea's major opposition party called today for further United States military and economic aid to South Korea despite what he termed the "dictatorial Government" of President Park Chung Hee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Israel has asked the United States for more than $2-billion in economic and military assistance for the next fiscal year, over three times what she currently receives from Washington in aid, American and Israeli officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The World Bank, Libya and the European Investment Bank are lending Zaire nearly $221-million to help expand its copper and cobalt output, the World Bank said today.
Price changes were announced yesterday by lending producers for two alloy materials, antimony and beryllium.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The State Public Advocate proposed an energy-saving plan today that would require utility companies to insulate 750,000 homes on a nonprofit basis.
PARIS, Jan. 20 The proArab policy of France came under sharp attack today in newspapers and broadcasts in the wake of the second Palestinian attack at Orly airport in a week.
Thomas Hart Benton, one of the country's foremost artists, who died Sunday night of heart disease in Kansas City, Mo., will be memorialized tomorrow at services near his studio there.
ATLANTA, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The Georgia Power Company is "on the brink of insolvency" Allen B. Wilson, a compony vice president, told the Georgia Public Service Commission at rate hearings today.

Volkswagen of America, the United States marketing arm of the West German automobile maker, said yesterday that a change of management and falling sales have put a temporary end to the company's idea of building a United States manufacturing plant, The Associated Press reports.

If the hearings on court reorganization that begin in Albany today send a message to the State Legislature that the public wants no further delay on reform measures, they will serve a good purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Unless Americans put a brake on their ever-increasing use of energy, the nation will never achieve self-sufficiency, the head of the new Federal agency for energy research said today.

Joseph Kallinger, the 39-year old Philadelphia shoe repairman suspected in a three-state spree of rapes, robberies and murder, is a prime suspect in the mysterious death of one of his own sons last summer, the Philadelphia police disclosed yesterday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP) More than half the workers at five Libbey-Owens-Ford Company plants, which provide glass for the automotive industry, will be laid off for twoweek periods in February and March, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Representative Jamie L. Whitten, the Mississippi Democrat whose 34 years of seniority have installed him in a powerful position in Congress, was stripped of his influence over consumer and environmental affairs by the House Appropriations Committee today.
Fourth-quarter operating earnings of the Bank America Corporation rose 16 per cent last year, the corporation, parent company of the nation's biggest bank the Bank of America reported yesterday.

Slipping black mourning bands over their shields, police officers of the Sixth Precinct last night, at 8:55 P.M., quietly began to observe thte death of their fellow officer, Joseph R. Garcia, who died at Bellevue Hospital after being fatally wounded in a gun battle with a holdup suspect.
Wes Gallagher, president and general manager of The Associated Press, yesterday announced two top-level management appointments at the news cooperative's headquarters here.
Mutual of New York is going to take an unusual step for a life insurance company that advertises on television. It's going to talk about death.

PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 21 Three Arab terrorists who held 10 people hostage in a washroom at Orly airport for 17 hours released them yesterday, flew off to the Middle East where six nations reportedly refused them sanctuary, and finally surrendered to authorities at Baghdad, Iraq, today.

The Federal Communications Commission has reprimanded radio station WMCA for violating the "personal attack" rule of the Communications Act in an incident involving Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a Queens Democrat. However, it dropped a $1,000 fine against the station.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Israel has asked the United States for more than $2-billion in economic and military assistance for the next fiscal year, over three times what she currently receives from Washington in aid, American and Israeli officials said today.
MADISON, Wis. Jan. 20 (AP) Quinn Buckner scored 26 points and led top-ranked Indiana to an 89-69 Big Ten Conference basketball victory over Wisconsin tonight.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (UPI) Ironworkers who stalled Olympics stadium construction for more than seven weeks threatened today to go on strike again tomorrow morning if they were not allowed to return to work.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 The General Motors Corporation, the giant of the automobile industry, yesterday became the last of the Big Three auto makers to announce hefty rebates to customers in an attempt to spur sales of new cars and lift the industry out of one of its worst slumps since World War II.

A concert of Renaissance madrigals, motets, carols and anthems regaled the residents of 25 Parade Place, Brooklyn, as a greeting to the New Year and also resulted in a donation of $100 to the Neediest Cases Fund of The New York Times.
City College began chopping down about 50 trees on an undeveloped plot of land yesterday to make room for an athletic installation with a track and field for football and soccer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Ford was confronted today with the first specific challenge from Congress over a key part of his economic and energy proposals that would increase fuel prices by imposing higher fees on imported crude oil.

GENEVA, Jan. 20 The Swiss Bank Corporation, one of Switzerland's "big three" commercial banks, disclosed today that it stands to suffer "substantial" losses from the collapse of the Sindona financial empire.

A 35-year-old police officer, shot in the heart yesterday afternoon during a gun battle with a robbery suspect in a Greenwich Village subway station, died last night at Bellevue Hospital after a team of surgeons labored eight and one half hours to save his life. The suspect was killed in the duel.
The I-T-E Imperial Corporation of Spring House, Pa., announced yesterday that it had filed suit against Gould, Inc., of Chicago and Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., of New York.

A group of protesting parents kep Public School 186 in West Harlem closed yesterday for the second consecutive school day with another morning picket line as well as a sitin that has gone on since last Friday. The demonstrators are protesting the ouster of Harold L. Lomax as acting principal, a post he had held since September, 1969.
Two 737 twin-engine jet passenger planes, valued at about $6.5-million each, excluding spare parts, have been purchased by Pacific Western Airlines from the Boeing Company.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, changed an earlier stand and agreed yesterday to make a financial disclosure to a New Jersey legislative committee investigating him, a committee lawyer reported.

HONG KONG, Jan. 20 Premier Chou En-lai held out a vision of inevitable world war to the National People's Congress in a keynote speech delivered last week and made public tonight. He also predicted the complete modernization of a stable, orderly China by the century's end.

Peter Preiser, the state's Commissioner of Correction since May, 1973, submitted his resignation to Governor Carey last night, saying he planned to leave the post on Feb. 18 to practice law here.

The Korvette department stores, whose New York group is one of the area's largest retailers, substantially improved its pretax income in the third quarter and nine months ended Nov. 30, 1974. Korvette's results were listed in a financial report released yesterday by the parent company, the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation.

Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, yesterday told members of the New York Bankers Association that the establishment of a public agency to lend money to credit-strained businesses should receive serious consideration.

The two biggest states in the Union have just inaugurated Democratic Governors New York for the first time since 1955, California for the first time since 1963. In both states the Democrats and the new Governors profess themselves to be more progressive than their predecessors; and when parties have been out of power that long they usually come back in on a wave of enthusiasm for change and reform.

His courtroom was noted for snappishness, not mercy. In Washington, he was among those judges whose rulings were most frequently overturned by higher courts.

Kay Summersby Morgan, who was confidential secretary, driver and confidante to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower during World War II, died yesterday of cancer of the liver in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 1111 Park Avenue.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 A group of Jewish activists agreed today that the nullification of the Soviet-American trade agreement was a tactical setback for their effort to gain the right to emigrate freely.

President Ford holds a slight edge over the two strongest Democratic contenders in the 1976 Presidential campaign, according to the results of a Harris Poll released yesterday.

The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings in both the final quarter of 1974 and the full year. However, the profit advances of 5.8 per cent in the quarter and 10.2 per cent for the year were well below the company's average gains in recent years.

The chairmen of the Appropriations subcommittees are among the most powerful persons in Congress and least known outside. DENVER Two incidents of unethical conduct in medical research laboratories one at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, one at Harvard have recently come to the attention of the public. Increasing numbers of faked data or, less flagrantly, data with "body English" put on them, make their way into the scientific journals.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 22--For the second time in three weeks, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party has been defeated in a by-election by opposition political parties backing an anticorruption move ment led by Jayaprakash Narayan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Negotiators for the nation's railroads reported today that they have reached tentative agreements with four key unions, averting a possible railroad strike on Friday. PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22-- The spree of upsets in the $115,000 United States pro indoor tennis championships engulfed fourth-seeded Tom Okker and 12th-seeded Cliff Drysdale in the third round today at the Spectrum.

A funeral service will be held this morning in Mount Vernon Place Methodist Church in Baltimore for the Rev. Dr. Harold A. Bosley. TRENTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)-- Governor Byrne said today a state police security force to guard him might not be necessary. LONDON, Ontario, Thursday, Jan. 23 (AP)--An escaped convict who took four children hostage Tuesday released the last child today and fled with $10,000 ransom and a car provided by the police, a police spokesman said.

ALBANY Jan. 22--The Democratic majority in the Assembly today issued a list of some of the spoils of victory. The list showed hefty salary increases for many of the party faithful, including a $9,000-ayear increase for Joseph F. Cranglem, former Democratic state chairman.

ROME, Jan. 22 (AP)--Journalists and printers staged a 24-hour strike today that will leave Italy without daily newspapers tomorrow, when a general strike for wages, pensions and other demands is scheduled. It will be the fourth general strike in Italy in four months.

PARIS, Jan. 22 (UPI)--The Most Rev. Roger Tort died of a heart attack in or in front of a prostitutes' hotel in the Les Halles section last Thursday, the police said today.

"The Ascent of Man" was halted Tuesday night because of a power failure. Channel 13's third installment of the 13-part series on the development of science went off the air at 8:59 --31 minutes too soon.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (Reuters) --President Idi Amin has told Queen Elizabeth he is coming to Britain in August to give advice to its liberation movements, according to Radio Uganda monitored here.
TOKYO, Jan. 22--Premier Takeo Miki evoked an image of Watergate today as he exhorted his troubled Liberal-Demo- cratic party to reform itself.
CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 22-- The New Hampshire Legislature passed a bill today that would set up a special run-off election to resolve the state's disputed election for the United States Senate.

Fifty Metroliners, which ordinarily speed under their own power in the New York-Washington corridor, had to be pulled this week by 35-to-40-year-old Penn Central electric locomotives because of snowy weather.

The D.W. Griffith retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art will open at 5:30 P.M. today with movies of 1908, "Adventures of Doll," "The Greaser's Gauntlet," "The Barbarian Ingomar," "Call of the Wild," "After Many Years" and "Money Mad." This program will be repeated at 2 P.M. tomorrow.

Schoch offered him immunity and ordered him to answer questions or face immediate jailing without bail.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 22 (AP)--The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company pleaded guilty today to five counts of making illegal corporate contributions to political campaigns in violation of Minnesota law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--"When you get too big a majority," House Speaker Sam Rayburn used to say, "you're immediately in trouble." This became known as Rayburn's Law, engraved as deeply in political lore as the more familiar "to get along, go along."

Bobby Bonds made his second trip to New York as a Yankee yesterday and this time announced the signing of his 1975 contract. The new Yankee right fielder reasserted that he would enjoy playing in New York, like batting third in the line-up and feel a rapport with the people of New York.

BUFFALO, Jan. 22--A prosecution witness testified here today that he had lied to a grand jury investigating the killing of two Attica prison inmates because he had been beaten and coerced and had feared for his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- Public school pupils cannot be suspended without notice of the charges against them, an explanation of any adverse evidence and a chance to give their side of the story, the Supreme Court ruled today.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22-- Ralph Munn, director of the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh from 1928 until his retirement in 1964, died today at West Penn Hospital. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- New claims for unemployment Compensation rose to a record total of nearly, a million in the first full week in January, but much of the rise was seasonal, the Labor Department reported today.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 22--The Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, has been authorized by his Awami League party to take "such steps as may be necessary to solve the outstanding problems" of the country.

MANILA, Jan. 22 (UPI)-- President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would return the country, to parliamentary government immediately if the Filipino people should vote "no" in the national plebiscite next month on his martial-law regime.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 (AP) --Jean Pronovost scored two goals and Ron Stackhouse helped set up three more to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 7-5 National Hockey League victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

The Raytheon Company, a diversified manufacturer of electronic equipment and components, reported yesterday a 33 per cent increase in fourth quarter net income to $14.5million, or 96 cents a share, from $10.9-million, or 73 cents a share, in the final quarter a year earlier.

PARIS, Jan. 22--The dollar plunged again today in heavy selling on European currency markets, causing Switzerland to take drastic action to check an influx of the unwanted American currency. The Swiss lifted the annual tax on new money from abroad deposited in Swiss francs to 40 per cent from 12 per cent.
Athletics have been on the upswing since Ed McDonnell returned to Oratory Prep School in Summit, his high school alma mater, as athletic director and basketball coach.

The Ford Administration's decision to seek a $10-to$11-billion increase in the defense budget, lifting spending close to $95 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1, should assure the first serious Congressional debate in years on the nation's overseas interests and its military force structure.

A 27-year-old woman whom the police described as a heroine addict who robbed to support her habit was arrested last night as the accomplice of the armed robber who fatally shot Police Officer Joseph R. Garcia last Monday.

ROME, Jan. 22--Italian authorities are investigating a network of ultrarightists who are said to be engaged in subversion here and abroad with the ultimate aim of establishing a federation of authoritarian states.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22-- President Ford took his opposition to petroleum rationing a step further today, saying through a spokesman he was prepared to veto "any mandatory rationing program" involving petroleum products, not simply one applying to gasoline.

SOUTH CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 22 (UPI)--A 30-vehicle chain collision in a fog bank laced with chlorine gas caused injuries and major damage on Interstate 64. WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--A New York-based public interest law firm filed suit today in United States District Court here seeking to block an increase in the cost of buying food stamps.
LONDON, Jan. 22--The British Government is considering gasoline rationing to save energy.

WASHINGTON, Jan 23 Three leading economists of both political parties, all former high Government officials, supported today President Ford's plan for a $12-billion rebate of 1974 income taxes to stimulate the economy, although they differed on some details.

Layoffs by companies, ranging from a diversified manufacturer of drugs and toiletries to a large railroad organization, were announced yesterday. Involved are about 1,666 employes. Another company reduced the work week for 600 employes.

The producer of the show "Let My People Come" yesterday denied charges that there are acts of simulated sex during the performance, saying that one alleged act was a "nude ballet" and another a "theatrical representation" that lasts less than 30 seconds.

Supporters of the United States team are cautiously optimistic about the prospects in the world team championship beginning tonight in Bermuda. The Italian team does not, appear to be as strong as usual, although appearances may be deceptive.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--While Governor Carey has decreed a "first 100 days" of innovation to bring on the new government, it is hard to sense any breakneck change of pace these days in the Capitol, where... countless hopes and promises have vaporized over the decades in the dank stone corridors of power.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Jock, pet cat of the late Sir Winston Churchill, has died at the age of 13. The name will be carried on by a replacement.

The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday a 9.3 per cent increase in fourth-quarter earnings and a 28.5 per cent increase for 1974.
