ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (AP) A Federal official said today that a full-scale investigation is warranted despite Roxie Ann Rice's refusal on the advice of a St. Louis police investigator to corroborate a story that she was a courier of drugs for professional football and basketball players.
The New York Times announced yesterday a plan to develop a modern satellite printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 Premier Yitzhak Rabin said today that Israel rejected any deadline for the completion of negotiations or troop withdrawals such as those proposed in recent interviews by president Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

A Harris Survey released yesterday showed Senators Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, and Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, running substantially ahead of Vice President Rockfeller in the 1976 Presidential race, United Press International reported.
Mary Foote Moore, wife of John D. J. Moore, Ambassador to Ireland, died yesterday of cancer in St. Vincent's Hospital, Dublin. She was 64 years old.

ELIZABETH, Jan. 23 An explosion in an aerosol-can paint factory here at 7:45 A.M. today injured 16 workers. Eight of the most seriously injured were admitted to two local hospitals for treatment of burns, contusions and shock.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI)--Broadcast journalists protested yesterday rules by Federal judges banning courthouse coverage, and the judges made the rules even stricter.
"I don't know any basketball players who have to fake an injury," said Bill Walton of the Portland Trail Blazers as he struck back at hints that his injury (a bone spur) is "not real."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Federal Energy Administration said today that President Ford's energy and tax-cut,proposals, if enacted by Congress, would probably add to the spendable income of some households and would shrink it for others.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose yesterday in stepped-up trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Asserting that doctors have become virtually uninsurable, one of the nation's major medical malpractice underwriters said today that it would stop selling the present coverage being provided for 48,000 doctors in 47 states.
Following are excerpts from a transcript of the televised interview of President Ford by NBC's John Chancellor and Tom Brokaw last night as recorded by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. called today for a ban on oil imported from the Arab nations that took part in the 1973-1974 embargo and for rationing at home.

Stanley Schneider, an independent film producer who was president of the Columbia Pictures division of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., from 1969 to 1973, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He would have been 46 years old Monday.
In line with the newest trend among the younger composers, Carman Moore has given his new work, "Wildfires and Field Songs,"

CASH GRANDE. Don't take the Chateau Madrid (7528080), at 48th Street and Lexington Avenue, for granted. Si, it's been around a long time, starting on Broadway over 30 years ago (as the Havana Madrid), then shifting to the East Side in 1951. At its present location (the old Hawaiian Room of the Lexington Hotel), this night-blooming Spanish lair retains its reputation as the most dependable, elaborate dinnershowcase in town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford signed today a proclamation increasing the import fee on petroleum amid accusations by Democratic members of Congress that his action constituted an abuse of Presidential power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford said tonight that if Secretary of State Kissinger failed to make progress toward a new Egyptian-Israeli accord the United States would probably be "forced to go to Geneva" for a reconvening of the conference strongly advocated by the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 Vice President Rockefeller flew here tonight to perform his first outof-town Vice-Presidential chore, giving a speech to a group of business executives gathered to honor members of a business hall of fame including Mr. Rockefeller's grandfather.
LONDON, Jan. 23 The Bank of England has purchased most of the Burmah Oil Company's interest in the British Petroleum Company as part of a revised plan to rescue Burmah from financial distress.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 23--Ruchell Magee, co-defendant of Angela Davis in the 1970 Marin County Courthouse shootout, in which four persons were killed, was sentenced here today to life imprisonment for kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 "When I came here in the 89th Congress, [Speaker John W.] McCorrriack told the freshman class: "When you pass a committee chairman in the hall, bow low from the waist I always do,'" recalled Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Westchester County Democrat who has returned to the House as a freshman.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its rebate program had lifted sales of its compact cars, although its over-all sales were still running behind year-earlier levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 23 The president-elect of the American Bar Association said today that the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was no place for former Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut to resume his legal career.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (UPI) World wheat production in 1974-75 will show a sharp drop from the previous year, the International Wheat Council said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Little was left to chance this morning as a caravan of 30 buses pulled itself together from several shopping centers across Salem and Cumberland Counties in South Jersey and headed, with all the efficiency of a wellplanned raid, for the White House and Capitol Hill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told Congress today that the Government needed an increase of $36-billion in the statutory debt ceiling, to a total of $531-billion, to continue operations through June 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 Arthur Ashe, Marty Riessen and Cliff Riohey are the only surviving members of the original list of 16 seeded players in the United States pro indoor tennis championships. Raul Ramirez and Tom Gorman were added to the fallen in today's action at the Spectrum.

FRANKFURT, West Germany The strong flow of Middle Eastern Petrodollar investment into West Germany, which began this fall, has again focused attention on the issue at the immense power of Frankfurt's financial Big Three the Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank and Commerzbank.

Nathan Lewin, a lawyer for the nursing-home owner Bernard Bergman, yesterday filed a suit in Federal District Court here charging that The New York Times and one of its reporters, Frank J. Prial, published a statement about him that was "malicious and in reckless disregard of the truth or, alternatively, negligent."

Four armed and masked robbers confronted a wealthy woman as she returned home from a charity ball early yesterday, forced her blindfolded to her apartment and fled with at least $300,000 in necklaces, rings and other jewelry, the police said.

Predictably, the admission by former high officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that, during J. Edgar Hoover's tenure, the bureau kept records on personal indiscretions of some members of Congress has turned the Capitol purple with the cries of outraged solons.
Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger says that he is confident that the United States can provide the resources to sustain Israeli fighting forces should a fifth Middle East war begin.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 Accustomed as they are to unfilled quotas of many things made on earth, Muscovites are now learning to cope with an insufficiency from the heavens. There is a snow shortage this winter.

After half a century a President of the United States has signed the 1925 treaty prohibiting poisonous gases in battle, thereby joining the major nations of the world in one small but symbolic step against the lasting cruelties of bizarre weapons. A second convention, renouncing biological warfare, has also been approved and will be formally ratified by Great Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. called today for a ban on oil imported from the Arab nations that took part in the 1973-1974 embargo and for rationing at home.

The supermarket shopper this month paid $1.25 for laundry detergent, 63 cents for dishwasher detergent and 75 cents for a box of plastic garbage bags. Six months ago, the same size, of the same brand, at the same supermarket, was 20 to 25 per cent cheaper.

PHILADELPHIA Despite the continuing dissolution of the family from extended to nuclear with even that atom frequently split into the smaller, single-parent unit most people still cling to the belief that the family is the best child-rearing institution we have. That belief pervades an unusual day care center here.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 23 The Thais will select a new National Assembly Sunday in the first general election since the end of military rule in 1973.
"They didn't even say thank you!" said Pedro Vidal, a welder, as he read his dismissal notice from the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation.
In his last electoral turn at bat, Ralph Kiner was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday, but Robin Roberts and Bob Lemon were not.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 23 The quality of care and nursing homes in Nassau County is generally good, County Executive Ralph G. Caso said in a report released today.

The Beame administration yesterday announced the abandonment or postponement of work this year on $16-million worth of work on construction projects on Staten Island as part of its effort to pare this year's capital budget.
"They didn't even say thank you!" said Pedro Vidal, a welder, as he read his dismissal notice from the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation.
How to get nonskiers involved in the sport could well have been the theme of Adelphi University's 19-day "vacation studies program," which is to be concluded

PARIS, Jan. 23--Trying to rub a little gloss off his patrician image, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing went to dinner at the Left Bank apartment of a picture framer last night and regaled his hosts with folksy conversation about the weather and the cost of living.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Governor Carey and nine other Northeastern Governors appealed in vain today to President Ford to delay the imposition of fees on imported oil a levy that Mr. Carey warned would make an increase in the mass-transit fare in New York City inevitable.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 Tommy Thomas, one of the 3,100 auto dealers who met here for five days to search for ways to get through one of the worst sales slumps since World War II, likes to illustrate his solution with a story about one of his salesmen.

The Inland Steel Company reported yesterday sizable wins in sales and earnings for both the fourth quarter and full calendar year 1974. Shipments of raw steel, sales and earnings for the year reached new highs for the second year in a row, while sales and earnings were at new highs for any fourth quarter.

The New York Football Writers Association honored yesterday two former assistant coaches at Colgate--Joe Restic, now the head football coach at Harvard, and Jim Butterfield, head coach at Ithaca College.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) yesterday announced that it had terminated its attempts to acquire the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

The Monsanto Company, a leading diversified chemical producer, reported yesterday for the final three weeks of 1974 the smallest percentage earnings gain of any quarter of last year, largely because of a deficit in textiles. Results for the period and for all of 1974 still set records, according to company spokesman.

Civil-rights groups and others involved in school-desegregation efforts were sharply critical State Board of Regents to ban the use of racial enrollment quotas in judging a school district's degree of integration.

In its 27th final season, the Little Orchestra Society is presenting a retrospective of some of the more important premieres in its history. On Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, it revived Richard Strauss's "Daphne." It had given the first United States performance of the opera in 1960, 22 years after its premiere in Dresden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Administration has informed Congress that it will sell Israel about 200 Lance missiles, a short-range missile capable of carrying nuclear warheads, Defense Department officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford signed today a proclamation increasing the import fee on petroleum amid accusations by Democratic members of Congress that his action constituted an abuse of presidential power.
Courtney Johnson, a former Assistant Secretary of the Army, died Wednesday in West Hartford, Conn. His age was 84.

Dr. Francis Joseph Weiss, a biochemist and economist concerned with developing food resources, died Tuesday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 76 years old and lived at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington.
PARIS, Jan. 23 The dollar fell again today in European centers despite strong measures taken yesterday by Switzerland to check the decline.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Ford said tonight that if Secretary of State Kissinger failed to make progress toward a new Egyptian-Israeli accord the United States would probably be "forced to go to Geneva" for a reconvening of the conference strongly advocated by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Twenty Latin American and Caribbean countries today voted condemnation of the new United States trade act as "discriminatory and coercive" in a resolution by the governing body of the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Napoleon Lechoco, accused of holding the Philippine Ambassador at gunpoint at the embassy last November, pleaded not guilty in United States District Court today.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 Governor Carey's family dog, Jet, was struck by Lieutenant Governor Mary Anne Krupsak's official car this morning when the dog darted out into the street in front of the Executive Mansion.

New statistics indicate that the nation has passed the peak of an epidemic of coronary heart disease that for decades has taken the lives of an everincreasing proportion of middle-aged American men, a leading heart expert said yesterday.
EAST PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 23 (AP) Dr. Margaret Shove Morriss, former dean of Pembroke College in Providence, died yesterday in an East Providence nursing home. She was 90 years old.

The Federal Communications Commission approved yesterday the International Business Machines Corporation's entry into the domestic satellite field but imposed limitations on a joint venture plan advanced by I.B.M. and the Comsat General Corporation, a subsidiary of the Communications Satellite Corporation.

Mayor Beame, members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council and state and city officials were among the more than 500 persons who attended yesterday a funeral service for Councilman Monroe Cohen, Democrat of Brooklyn, who died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 48.

The New York City Commission on Human Rights has found "cause to believe" that the National Broadcasting Company has discriminated against women in recruitment, in hiring, job classification, promotion opportunities and benefit programs.

DALLAS The builder Aaron Arker is in Florida these days, taking in the sun and waiting. His son Sol, 27 years old, giving the impression of energy coiled is home in Brooklyn also waiting, the business is at a standstill.
The Turks have suggested that each community maintain its own customs facilities at the airport, with a joint facility for foreigners. The Greek side does not like this idea.
BOSTON, Jan 23--(UPI)--Ed Gilbert scored a goal and an assist tonight as the expansion Kansas City Scouts shocked the Boston Bruins with a 3-2 victory in the National Hockey League.

Mayor Beame was reported yesterday ready to approve details of a new city cultural agency whose creation would clear the way for the departure of Irving Goldman, the Cultural Affairs Commissioner, who is the subject of Federal and state investigations.
BUFFALO, Jan. 23 A State Supreme Court justice ruled here today that a local television newsman must testify in court about events he witnessed during the Attica prison rebellion in September, 1971.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night the recovery of five valuable paintings stolen here more than five years ago and the arrest of a 56-year-old Mount Vernon, N.Y., man in connection with the case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and two of its board members today on a charge of income tax conspiracy involving almost $634,000 in allegedly fictitious deductions for illegal political contributions.
CONCORD, N.H. Jan.23 (AP) A class action suit was filed in United States District Court today challenging New Hampshire's policy of prohibiting the use of welfare money for abortions.

TRENTON, Jan. 23 Gerald Smith, the state's star witness in the trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden, unexpectedly testified today that he gate Mr. Errichetti $500 in 1969 as a political contribution, not as a payoff for help in getting city painting contracts.
NEWARK, Jan. 23 A single bid of S3-million for Bloomfield College's deficit-plagued Knoll Country Club was rejected as too low by a Federal judge at a public auction here today.

MATTHEWS, Ala., Jan. 23 Democrats running for President make pilgrimages to Morris Dees's house these days much as they will later call on Mayor Richard J. Daley in Chicago or visit the big-state delegations at the 1976 convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Federal Energy Administration said today that President Ford's energy and tax-cut proposals, if enacted by Congress, would prabably add to the spendable income of some households and would shrink it for others.

To the extent that President Ford's tax program to stem the recession can be distinguished from his tax program to conserve energy, the former seems to have two major deficiencies as a means of stimulating the economy. And when both programs are taken together, the energy conservation plan seems to offset some of the stimulus of the antirecession tax cut, at the time when that stimulus is most needed.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 23 After two working sessions, the talks on the political future of Cyprus appear to be off to a rocky start.
James Joseph Walsh, a retired assistant chief inspector of the New York City Police Department, died Saturday at the age of 65.
BELFAST, Jan. 23 The I.R.A. Provisionals have decided to renew their cease-fire in Northern Ireland, a Republican newspaper circulating in parts of Belfast said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration is facing a Congressional inquiry into its operations on such diverse fronts as personnel hiring practices and international intelligence tactics.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 23 (AP) Gerald Wayne Pike, a former convict accused of abducting seven persons in a 135-mile rampage across northern Oklanoma this morning, was arrested without resistance in Tulsa later today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Reuters) The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today it has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to suspend the $700-million interstate rate increase requested by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company pending a formal investigation.

At the recent New England Atlantic Salmon Restoration Conference in Boston it was acknowledged that those who will he regulating the catching of salmon--when the fish do return--face some sticky problems.
Partly reflecting a slump in air travel that engulfed the airline industry late in 1974, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines yesterday reported sharply reduced earnings for the fourth quarter.

Corporate loans in New York City continued to fade away in the week ended Wednesday, reflecting the recession, and borrowing in the commercial paper market fell off, too. Interest rates dropped sharply, and the nation's money supply showed little growth.
The Board of Estimate yesterday nullified the designation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission of a row of l9thcentury houses as the Steinway Historic District in Astoria Queens.

SANTA, BARBARA, Calif. Almost all skills, worth learning are learned by doing. The introduction of doing de-academizes a subject, motivates the student by giving him responsibility, and eliminates early those who should never have been there in the first place.
PARIS, Jan.23 It is one of the oldest and youngest quarters of Paris.

A Manhattan grand jury has found insufficient evidence to indict anyone on criminal charges in the 1973 collapse of the old Broadway Central Hotel which killed four persons, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday.
The Procter Gamble Company achieved record sales and earnings in the three and six months ended Dec. 31, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Democratic Compliance Review Commission extended the reach of a key party reform tonight after a confused and often comical all-day struggle in which five proposed formulas were rejected before a compromise was finally struck.

It's nice to know that taste and elegance haven't vanished from the fashion world. They're both still flourishing at the House of Norell, which is, of course, no surprise. Including its earlier incarnation as Traina-Norell, the house has been around for some 35 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan 23 President Ford, appearing on a television interview tonight after a busy day of jousting with Congress, said that if his plan for imposing energy taxes was rejected, he would accept arbitrary allocation of petroleum products instead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Dr. Arthur Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, surveys the Washington scene these days through a cloud of pipe tobacco smoke, but he still has two of the coolest and sharpest eyes in town. Accordingly, his musings on the developing struggle between the White House and the Congress over the economy are influential and could even be decisive.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 The State Supreme Court upheld to day, after ordering a little "judicial pruning," two municipal ordinances that require door-to. door solicitors to register with the local police.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24-The altius and fortius bunch was expected to overshadow the citius crowd at the San Francisco Examiner Games tonight. Those trying to go higher (like Dwight Stones) and show that they were stronger (like Al Feuerbach and George Woods) had a bigger share of the spot light in the Cow Palace tonight than those simply trying to run faster.

PARIS, Jan. 24 President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said in an interview published here today that he had "reason to believe" the United States would soon recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization.

President Ford is forcing a destructive confrontation by his refusal to consider the mounting objections in Congress and state houses to his plan for taxing petroleum imports. The problems of energy and economic revival urgently require cooperation with Capitol Hill, as the President himself has stressed; yet he is rubbing the wrong way even those legislators who might be inclined to meet him more than half-way.
BUDAPEST, Jan. 24 The United States Ambassador to Hungary, Richard F. Pedersen, will shortly be replaced, qualified sources reported today.
Two top business leaders criticized yesterday different sections of President Ford's new economic program.
GRANTHAM, N.H., Jan. 24 (AP) Tim Caldwell of Putney, Vt., a member of the United States Nordic skiteam, won the 30-kilometer race today at the Eastern cross-country championships.
PIGCAWAYAN, Philippines, Jan. 24 (AP) Philippine F-86 jets dropped napalm on suspected rebel supply depots on the island of Mindanao this week a field officer said today.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 Gene Littler, who has won 25 events in his 20 years on the pro tour, and Tom Watson, who has won one tournament in three years of pro competition, took the lead today in the second round of the 34th annual Bing Crosby National pro-amateur golf tournament.
Wang Chi-yuan, a painter and calligrapher who operated the School of Chinese Brushwork here since 1947, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 399 East 72d Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Ford's press secretary categorically denied today that the United States was preparing three army divisions for possible use in the Middle East.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 Trailing 3-6 in a 13-point-final-set tiebreaker and saving a total of eight match points, Jaime Fillol gamely upset Arthur Ashe 7-6, 2-6, 7-6, in a quarterfinal match of the $115,000 United States professional indoor tennis championships tonight.

From the very beginning of American involvement in Vietnam, the fundamental error has been the emphasis placed on a military solution to what was essentially, for most of the time, a political problem. The Ford Administration appears to be drifting into a repetition of that mistake.
An armed South Bronx liquor store owner was shot three times and critically wounded eary today when he tried to resist a man and woman holdup team, the police said. The robbers were later caught.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24 Canada has reconsidered her relations with the United States and decided to strengthen "the economy and other aspects of national life in order to secure our independence," Allen J. MacEachen, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) John R. Stiles, a retired builder who has managed all of President Ford's Congressional election campaigns, has been on the Federal payroll as a $125-a-day White House consultant, a Presidential spokesman has confirmed.

Mary Frank is a magnificent anomaly among contemporary sculptors. While so many others expend their energies on making sculpture a language of cerebration, securely guaratined against direct expressions of feeling, Mrs. Frank insists on making it a language of passion. The result is an oeuvre unlike any other on the current art scene an oeuvre in which an imagery of great inwardness and intimacy is combined with an earthy articulation of emotion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A Federal Court of Appeals in Denver overturned today an antitrust conviction of the International Business Machines Corporation that had ordered the giant corporation to pay $259.5-million to the Telex Corporation. At the same time, the lower court's judgment against Telex in a countersuit was affirmed.

Antiques enthusiasts crowding the opening yesterday of the Winter Antiques Show found that the 59 participating dealers looked as settled as if they had been doing business in the stadium-size Seventh Regiment Armory since this famous annual event began 21 years ago.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 The Soviet Union reported today that it had made economic progress in 1974, but figures released in the official Government report disclosed that there were numerous failures to meet goals for increased production of consumer goods.
The surprisingly strong performance of low-priced stocks so far this year has raised hopes however faint that the worst of the bear market may be over.

On a sunny afternoon in March, 1931, a sheriff's posse, halted a freight train passing through the sleepy north Alabama town of Paint Rock and rounded up nine black youths looking for work and charged them with raping two white prostitutes who were also on the train, Mobs gathered. the sheriff issued a call for the National Guard and the boys were transferred to a safer jail in the nearby county seat, Scottsboro.
Sharply higher soybean prices late in the trading session yesterday influenced higher wheat and corn prices on the Chicago Board of Trade.

By the mid-1930's drought had turned the American prairie into a dust bowl and started the great migration to California. President Ford's oil program, which seems designed to turn the Northeast into an ice bowl, contains the makings of a comparable migration.
The search for a college president a somber activity once confined to weighty deliberations by tweedy academics in oak-paneled board rooms, has been extended to the classified advertising columns.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 The Ford Motor Company said today that it was laying off 44,550 workers for next week and putting 2,000 more on indefinite layoff. The total number of Ford employes on indefinite layoff next week will be 33,125.
DE SOTO, Mo., Jan. 24 (AP) Clarence F. (Heinie) Mueller, a colorful outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday of cancer at his home here. He was 75 years old.
The stock market, spurted by a further decline in interest rates, made a broad advance yesterday as trading increased.

Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., achieved new highs in earnings after inclusion of an extraordinary item for both the fourth quarter and 1974, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday. Sales for the periods also reached new highs.
LISBON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Gen. Humberto Delgado, leader of the opposition to Portugal's former authoritarian regime, was buried with full military honors today, 10 years after he was killed in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 An advisory council of prominent private citizens reviewing the Social Security System said today that benefits would start to exceed tax rceipts next year by several billion dollars.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP) Marie-Therese Nadig, the Olympic nemesis of Annemarie Proell, struck again today by beating the Austrian ski ace in the World Cup downhill, a test race for the 1976 Winter Olympics.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 (UPI) The dollar fell to record lows today, ending the fourth week of one of its worst slumps Foreign exchange dealers said there was little expectation on an early recovery.

Rowena Benson Stevens, producer for the Pocono Playhouse, a summer theater in Mountainhome, Pa. which she founded in 1947 and operated since then, died yesterday at her home in Palm Beach, Pla. She was 68 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 24 In the Kentuckxy dressing room tonight, Hubie Brown, the Colonels' coach, held his hand up to his face and solemnly said, "How do you explain to your players losing a game on a backcourt foul with three seconds remaining. And a questionable foul at that".

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 24 (UPI) Dave Forbes of the Boston Bruins pleaded not guilty today to a charge of aggravated assault in an alleged attack on Henry Boucha of the Minnesota North Stars during a Jan. 4 game.

DENVER, Jan. 24 (AP) Interior Secretary Rogers C.B. Morton told Governors of Western states today that their states must supply much of the coal needed to make the nation self-sufficient in energy production.

The soaring profits of the international oil industry have given way to more modest increases and, in some cases, to declines in the fourth quarter of 1974, according to year-end reports released yesterday.

The CBS schedule for tomorrow contains three programs of more than usual interest. The first, on the generally outstanding "Camera Three" series at 11 A.M., is "Olympics of Dance," a collection of filmed excerpts from the 1966 Varna International Ballet competition.

Intervening for justice where citizens and politicians had failed, New Jersey's Supreme Court ruled in April, 1973, that heavy reliance on local property taxes had created wide disparities in education between rich and poor districts in violation of the State Constitution. Two months later the court ordered the Legislature to devise a more equitable system of financing public education by the end of last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Secretary of State Kissinger, alarmed by the Administration's deteriorating relations with Congress, called today for "a new national partnership" to avoid domestic confrontations over foreign policy and to achieve agreement on specific issues.
WASHINGTON Representative Frank Thompson Jr. came back to his office Thursday afternoon with a new, shorter-styled haircut.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Saturday, Jan. 25 (AP) Steve Holland, the 16 yearold Australian swimming star bettered two world records today in the New Zealand Games. He broke his own 800-meter record and regained the mark for 1,500 meters from Tim Shaw of Long Beach, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Federal savings and loan associations would have to pay interest on mortgage loan escrow accounts in certain states under a proposal made today by the Federal Home Loan Bank board.

A portion of the roof and wall of a partially demolished commercial building at Broadway and 96th Street collapsed yesterday evening, spewing bricks and mortar into 96th Street and injuring two persons.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 24 Jack Ross, a salesman at Larsen Ford in White Plains, watched a middle-aged couple slowly circle a blue Maverick, one of the Ford models being offered these days with a $200 cash rebate.
ALBANY Jan. 24 Two private hospitals in New York City have been ordered to close, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the acting State Health Commissioner, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Supplies of wheat in storage in the United States are l9 per cent higher than they were a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 P.N. Haksar, deputy chairman of India's Planning Commission, has described as "concoctions" the references to him made by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The Ford Motor Company will recall 178,000 1972 Maverick and Comet automobiles to replace faulty seat belts, the Transportation Department said today.

Hynes, the special state prosecutor investigating alleged nursing-home abuses.

A security officer at St. Luke's Hospital was shot and killed yesterday morning when he halted a robbery of a bank delivery at the hospital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Oil industry spokesmen reacted today to a Federal investigation of natural gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico by denying that they had held back production.

A Lambertville, N.J., nursing home has agreed to make firehazard corrections required by the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, thus avoiding a threatened cutoff of Medicaid funds under a new Federal policy, the agency's regional director said yesterday.

Because of a continuing low reserve of Rhesus negative blood, the New York Blood Center has announced a yearround campaign for Rh-negative donors.

Like long-lost cousins meeting again at a family reunion, denominationally separated Christians rejoiced in "finding" each other during the ecumenically minded sixties.

They out-perform their bigger relatives with profusion, and like Florida, they are more fun in the wintertime.

BERLIN Lorraine Cooper was one of Washington's most elegant hostesses. In the fading mural high over the proscenium at the Belasco Theater on West 44th Street, the lush figure of Mother Love still shelters Innocence, Devotion still dispels Grief with a kiss. The sky is serene, and there is no hint of a closing night.

The New York Rangers' rookie, Ron Greschner, looking more like Bobby Orr every day, helped his team catch the Los Angeles Kings, put it ahead and then saved the lead spectacularly last night as the Rangers won, 3-2, at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Two Democratic Senators said today they planned to introduce legislation tomorrow providing the President with a limited method of forcing wage and price rollbacks, and contended that it would eliminate any need for blanket Government controls.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he would vote against a request for $300-million in military aid to South Vietnam this year.

Senate leaders are predicting quick passage this week of a bill that would force the state's insurance companies that write personal liability policies to participate in a pool to provide medical malpractice insurance coverage.
PARIS, Jan. 26 A saddle cloth was replaced by a sulky today, but big Bellino II still had the right equipment to win a championship.
The East End Hotel, founded in 1911 as a "home away from home" for genteel young women who came to the big city for work or study, will close on March 3.

WASHINGTON President Ford has moved in a "new direction" to "turn the economy around" and has finally presented an anti-recession and energy program. Congressman Al Ullman, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has said that the tax aspect of the program will be his first priority, so let's look at it.

WASHINGTON President Ford has moved in a "new direction" to "turn the economy around" and has finally presented an anti-recession and energy program. Congressman Al Ullman, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has said that the tax aspect of the program will be his first priority, so let's look at it.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 26--At a garden party celebrating the fourth anniversary of Maj. Gen. Idi Amin's seizure of power in this East African nation, a Uganda major wearing a kilt of the Royal Stuart tartan and a cap resembling that of the Gordon Highlanders strolled across the lawn with a bottle of beer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Pills used by more than 1.5 million Americans to control diabetes are probably hazardous and capable of causing premature death from heart disease, according to a major statistical study released today by the American Medical Association.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Jan. 27 (AP) Ida Fuller, who received the first Social Security check issued in the United States, died today in a nursing home. She was 100 years old.

For some veteran New York Philharmonic concertgoers, reading the new program notes for the orchestra's concerts may seem like turning the clock back. Last weekend's concert program, for example, included Mozart's Concerto for Flute and Harp, and the note for it was written in 1931 by Lawrence Gilman, program annotator for the orchestra from 1921 to 1939.

The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday fourth-quarter net income of $152-million, or $2.49 a share, up 105.4 per cent from the year-earlier $74-million, or $1.22 a share. This was exceeded only by last year's third-quarter net of $2.54 a share.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a unitpricing bill that requires supermarkets in the state to post the price by ounce or pound for all food, beverages, personal-care items and household items.
Gardner-Denver, Inc., of Dallas, a manufacturer of equipment for the petroleum, mining and construction industries, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Dem-

The Park Avenue penthouse "truck farm" of Stewart R. Mott, the General Motors stock heir and political philanthropist, is the target of a contract-breaking action filed yesterday by his fellow shareholders in the cooperative apartment building at 74th Street.

Robert Abrams, Bronx Borough President, reported last night that a quasi-public agency in Albany had rejected an 11thhour effort to block the sale at auction today of the equipment of a south Bronx cabinetmaking factory that employed 200 workers.

International airlines said yesterday that they had voted to restore cut-rate youth fares between this country and Europe April 1, in a bid to help stimulate sagging trans-Atlantic travel and to deter American young people from going to Canada to catch cheap flights.

The future of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, seriously threatened by recent defections, may be further jeopardized by a formal basketball conference being organized by seven major Eastern universities. Penn State, which resigned from the E.C.A.C. last year, and Pittsburgh, which will resign in June, hope to join five E.C.A.C. members West Virginia, Duquesne, Rutgers, Syracuse and George Washington to form this league.

The Shell Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of California announced higher profits yesterday for the quarter and full year of 1974, while the Marathon Oil Company reported a decline for the quarter but an advance for the year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The sharply higher cost of oil imports pushed the nation's trade deficit to $3.07-billion last year, the second largest in this century, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CORFU, Greece, Jan. 27 (AP)--A United States destroyer today canceled its visit to this Greek island at the Athens Government's request after two of its officers were attacked during anti-American riots.

LISBON, Jan. 27 Foreign Minister Mario Soares, speaking as the leader of Portugal's Socialist party, warned today that the nation faced the possibility of civil war if democratic Government was abandoned as a result of Communist moves.
The stock market erupted in a sharp rally yesterday in the heaviest trading day in New York Stock Exchange history.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 Governor Byrne announced today that he would propose still another state income tax in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature next week, this one to be coupled with a reduction of the state sales tax to 3 per cent from 5 per cent.

ROME, Jan. 27 (AP) Italy's 80,000 butchers closed their shops today to protest high prices and poor sales, but one butcher running what he called a "meat boutique" faced trial for selling veal at $10.50 a pound.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) A Federal judge postponed today the bribery and conspiracy trial of former United States Senator Edward Gurney until Feb. 24 to give Mr. Gurney time to undergo surgery of an undisclosed nature.

PEKING, Jan. 27 It was to have been a simple beer-andnoodles lunch, the way the Chinese man in the street would have it. The four of us, three Americans and a Canadian, sat at a table near the potbellied stove and asked the waitress for the standard fare. She smiled, and scurried away to bring us what we hoped would be the 35-cent meal.
Tenneco, Inc., reported yesterday a 5.4 per cent decline in fourth-quarter net income but a 40 per cent increase for all of last year.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) Wiretap evidence forms the basis of the state's case in the trial of Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarity and 19 other men and women on gambling charges, the prosecution said today.

The 24th annual Capezio Dance Award was presented yesterday to Robert Irving, music director and principal conductor of the New York City Ballet. Martha Graham, the choreographer and dancer for whose dance company Mr. Irving has also conducted, made the presentation in the Plaza Hotel's Terrace Room. The audience included many dance figures and members of the City Ballet and the Graham company.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 The South, following the lead of New England, is producing growing opposition to President Ford's proposals to conserve energy by forcing up prices.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 27 (AP) Charles L. Banino, former chef and president of the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Boston, died here Saturday at Notre Dame Hospital. He was 73 years old.

CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP) Journeymen and apprentice jockeys filled out Keystone race track's nine-race card today as many regular riders refused to mount because they said the track was too wet and unsafe.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 27 The middle-of-the-road Democrats, long Thailand's major opposition party, won the largest number of seats in the election yesterday for the new national assembly, but they fell far short of the majority needed to choose a Premier.

Marian Thompson presented a solid program of familiar French and German songs on Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall, and she sang them in a solid, capable fashion. Miss Thompson possesses a pliable soprano with an attractively vulnerable quality that she used to make sensible expressive points and shapely phrases with a sure sense of musical purpose.

BONN, Jan. 27 An unconfirmed television report that West Germany's highest court is planning to declare unconstitutional a recently passed abortion law caused an uproar here today.

EMERGENCE The immediately postwar face of Vienna is dim to many Americans now that World War II has receded so far into the past. The television rerun of a movie like Graham Greene's thriller "The Third Man" set amid the rubble, is one kind of reminder. Many American tourists know modern Vienna as one of the most beautiful of European capitals.

Despite a 28-day strike last fall by coal miners, the Norfolk Western Railway Company, which derives about 35 per cent of its annual revenues from hauling coal, reported yesterday a 25 per cent earnings increase for the final quarter of 1974.

The request for information about last Friday's bombing of a Fraunces Tavern annex, which killed four persons and injured 56, has produced "quite a bit of response," a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.

Train announced today that the Ford Administration was releasing in the next fiscal year $4-billion for construction of municipal waste treatment plants. Five New York radio stations WCBS, WOR, WNBC, WRFM and WNEW will be running an unusual paid radio message the rest of this week. It will be promoting Catholic School Week, which begins Sunday.

CBS's four-part-monthly series on Benjamin Franklin concludes tonight at 9:30, with "The Statesman," a 90minute drama. It is the best of a generally good lot, perhaps because the writer, Edward Diamond, can pick up where the other scripts left off. The stuffing of purely biographical information is not quite so lumpy. The character of Franklin has already been developed to the point where drama considerations can come first.

BATH, Me. The Shelter Institute, located one flight up in a turn-of-the-century building at 72 Front Street here, offers a basic course in home building. William F. Brooks, who was director of news and special events at the National Broadcasting Company from 1942 to 1946 and then a vice president until 1952, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 230 East 48th Street.
A decision designed to end racial segregation at Mark Twain Junior High School in Brooklyn was affirmed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

ELATH, Israel, Jan. 27--Premier Yitzhak Rabin urged the Soviet Union today to stop ignoring Israel diplomatically and to renew contacts if it wants "to play a meaningful role in the Middle East."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)--The Supreme Court today rejected G. Gordon Liddy's contention that United States District Judge John J. Sirica had failed to give him a fair trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Representative John C. Kluczynski, Democrat of Illinois, died today of a heart attack at his home in Chicago. He was 78 years old.

ALLENWOOD, Pa., Jan. 27 (AP) Jeb Stuart Magruder, who was jailed for his part in the Watergate conspiracy, went back to the Federal prison farm here last weekend to collect his belongings. They had been stolen.

International Business Machines Corporation stock, responding dramatically to a favorable Federal Appeals Court ruling in Denver last week, surged $20 a share in heavy trading on the Midwest Stock Exchange yesterday but failed to trade on the New York Stock Exchange, its principal marketplace, because of what the Big Board called "a tremendous influx of orders."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress could compel states and cities to provide the same wages and working hours for their civil servants, including policemen and firemen, as Federal employes receive.

The announcement just before the close of trading that China had canceled orders for about 600,000 tons of wheat depressed the price on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday to $3.90 a bushel for the March delivery. This compares with a price of $4.04 on Friday.

Mayor Beame directed yesterday that 13,000 city employes working south of Canal Street begin working staggered hours. The employes would join 220,000 in private industry in midtown and downtown who are already in the four-year-old program.
The stock market erupted in a sharp rally yesterday in the heaviest trading day in New York Stock Exchange history.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 27 (AP) The Zambian Government has canceled all import licenses issued during the last 13 months in a bid to save foreign exchange following the slump in copper prices.
Frank William Reed, who was president of the New York Financial Writers Association in 1956-57, died yesterday at his home, 29 Mary Street, Valley Stream, L.I. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Ford Administration plans to announce this week a $500million increase in the food aid program, to $1.4-billion, as it continues to negotiate with legislators over how much of the total should be allocated for political rather than humanitarian purposes, according to Administration officials and Congressional aides.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 27 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington will announce his candidacy for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination in a five-minute network commercial before the 11 P.M. news on Feb. 6, he is telling supporters here.

HAUPPAUGUE, L.I., Jan. 27 Perry J. Duryea Jr. dissented today with Governor Carey's call to do away with the New York State Sports Authority. The Assembly's Republican minority leader urged that the agency, which was created to finance the building of municipal facilities through bonds, be given a chance "to prove itself."
Professional and amateur photographers will pay 4 per cent more, on average, for still and movie film ordered from the Eastman Kodak Company after Feb. 28, the big photo-

New-car purchasers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who get a manufacturers' rebate will receive no refund of the 4 to 8 per cent sales tax they pay in New York on the original purchase price, the 6 per cent in Connecticut or the 5 per cent in New Jersey.
TREVISO, Italy, Jan. 27 (UPI) --Toti Dal Monte, one of the great sopranos of the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died yesterday at the age of 81.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 27 Robert Dwyer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, said today that recent bombings in Puerto Rico attributed to left-wing groups seeking independence for the island had used Iremite, an explosive that he called more powerful than dynamite.

Le Corbusier's housing project for workers at Pessac, France, of 1925, was once composed of pure, clean forms, rationally arranged for light and air. The housing seemed to embody many of modern architecture's formal and social goals. But to many of the occupants, the buildings were just white boxes, not houses; they cared far more that they had been denied decorations than that they were given great amounts of light and open space.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Argentina, citing the new United States Trade Act, notified Washington and 22 other hemisphere governments today that as host country she had decided to postpone indefinitey a conference of foreign ministers set for Buenos Aires in March.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Six bombs were exploded in Britain today and at least 23 persons were injured, 19 of them in a single incident.

The Ford Foundation, which has announced a four-year program to reduce its annual grants by more than 50 per cent, has reorganized its mechanism for disbursing funds to the arts in anticipation of the budget cutback.

Steel production for the week ended Jan. 25 rebounded with a gain of 2.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association placed the latest week's output at 2.62 million tons and a production index of 107.2, the highest level since the final week of November, 1974. This compared with the 2.56 million tons poured in the week ended Jan. 18 when the index stood at 104.8.
Edmund A. Duffy, a veteran reporter and wire editor of The Long Island Press, died Sunday at his home in North Baldwin, L.I. He was 70 years old.
Dr. Hyman L. Rachlin, a psychoanalyst and psychiatrist, died Sunday at his home, 35 Park Avenue. His age was 78.

Yesterday's strong rally and heavy turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was but the most visible manifestation of a market upsurge that has been developing over the last six weeks or so. During this period interest rates have plummeted to 7 per cent from as high as 12 per cent for major-bank certificates of deposit and to as low as 4 per cent from 9 7/8 per cent

When the organizers of the Lublin international tournament invited Mikhail Tal to join 15 other participants, it was like opening the hen house for the fox. Not since the days of the great Akiba Rubinstein and Savielly Tartakower has Poland had a grandmaster and the only two grandmasters who entered besides Tal were Mato Damjanovic of Yugoslavia and Levente Lengyel of Hungary, both well past their prime.
There was one architect on the staff of the City Planning Commission in 1967. Now there are 48, with 30 more in affiliated agencies.

Dismissed for lack of jurisdiction an appeal from a decision declaring unconstitutional a Minnesota law of 1974 that attempted to restrict abortions during the last half of pregnancy (No. 74-254, Spannaus v. Hodgson). Not participating: Blackmun.
Joseph Rosenberg, a staff reporter on The Wall Street Journal since 1972, died Friday of kidney failure in Duke University Hospital, Durham, N.C. He was 49 years old and lived in Millburn, N.J.

A state advisory committee found yesterday that Vice President Rockefeller's gifts to state aides while he was Governor did not violate the state Code of Ethics but that the gifts were "not in the public interest" because they created a "great deal of suspicion."

ALBANY, Jan. 27 Victor H. Gotbaum, head of the biggest municipal union in New York City said today that a pension agreement negotiated with the city in 1970, but not approved by the Legislature, would be reintroduced within two weeks."
Cantor Jacob Stein of the Merrick (L.I.) Jewish Center died Sunday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 62 years old and lived in Hollis Hills, Queens.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Five people were killed and nine wounded today as dynamite bombs planted by leftwing guerrillas went off in the Mexican capital and provincial cities, the police said. [Some reports said the number hurt was approaching 30.]

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 A coalition of civil rights supporters gathered here today to talk about a civil rights program in the new session of Congress, but they spent most of the day discussing the need for economic relief for the nation's minorities and poor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI)--The Supreme Court cleared the way today for lawyers for James Earl Ray to gain access to evidence gathered by the State of Tennessee in investigating the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Jan. 27 (AP) American Basketball Association trustees approved the sale of the Indiana Pacers today to a six-member group of Indianapolis investors.

When the organizers of the Lublin international tournament invited Mikhail Tal to join 15 other participants, it was like opening the hen house for the fox. Not since the days of the great Akiba Rubinstein and Savielly Tartakower has Poland had a grandmaster and the only two grandmasters who entered besides Tal were Mato Damjanovic of Yugoslavia and Levente Lengyel of Hungary, both well past their prime.
There was one architect on the staff of the City Planning Commission in 1967. Now there are 48, with 30 more in affiliated agencies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that China's cancellation of large wheat contracts from the United States will have no appreciable effect on this nation's consumers.

PARIS France's present policy in the Middle East was not in fact designed by General de Gaulle, who changed France's pro-Israel line drastically in 1967, by President Georges Pompidou or President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. Nor was it conceived by any of the able foreign ministers who have so far served the Fifth Republic Maurice Couve de. Murville, Maurice Schumann, Michel Jobert or the incumbent, a widely experienced professional diplomat, Jean Sauvagnargues.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 28 The student government board at Michigan State University voted 7 to 3 tonight to withdraw financial support for a planned Feb. 25 speech by Ronald L. Ziegler, who had been press secretary to former President Richard M. Nixon.
The Passaic County Prosecutor has asked a New Jersey judge to block Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from selecting two out-of-state lawyers in their appeal of a triple-murder conviction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Repreentative Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today that a special committee of top-ranking members of Congress would try to work out a compromise plan for reducing oil imports that would avoid a confrontation between the White House and Congress.

As the oil-consuming countries have begun to bite the bullet of pride and move toward a common energy policy, the oil-producing nations have begun to bite the apple of wisdom. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has now offered to open a dialogue with the industrial countries and, meanwhile, to freeze oil prices for the remainder of 1975.

Despite a substantial decline in shipments of steel products in the final three months of 1974, the United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported profits of $171.4-million, in the period, an increase of 64 per cent over the fourth quarter of 1973.

RICHMOND, Jan. 28 (UPI) Third-seeded Arthur Ashe breezed to a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Corrado Barrazzutti of Italy tonight in the first round of the 10th annual Richmond world championship tennis tournament. Ashe eliminated the 21-year-old Italian in less than an hour.

PARIS, Jan. 28 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who has been trying to thaw the icicles of aloofness from his high office in recent months, has taken another step in the direction of democratization by ordering the dropping of titles of nobility from invitations to the Elysee Palace.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 28 Dorothy Hamill of Riverside, Conn., last year's senior women's champion, is expected to win again as the United States figure-skating championships begin tomorrow despite an ankle injury suffered last month.

The news that the International Business Machines Corporation had won a reversal of a $259.9-million antitrust judgment reached the stock market at a time when the technical position of the market was already favorable.

Declaring that continuing on the bench "would work a financial deprivation on his family," Owen McGivern said yesterday that he was resigning from one of the state's top judicial posts to join a large midtown law firm.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 (UPI) Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that he thought Israel should forsake United States peace moves and return to the Geneva conference because Middle Eastern peace could not be achieved without Soviet cooperation.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 The state today made public the first entries in this year's list of registered lobbyists a million-dollar adjunct to the Legislature that deals in earnest advice, quiet meals and one-to-one personal relationships unknown to most lawmakers' constituents.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Turkey announced today that she would withdraw 1,000 troops from Cyprus in what appeared a token concession to United States Congressional pressure for a Cyprus settlement.

BOSTON, Jan. 28-Editors at The Boston Globe said today that the newspaper was apparently the victim of a hoax in its recent report that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was believed to be here for cancer treatment.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark Jan. 28 (Reuters) Denmark's minority Liberal party Government resigned tonight only three weeks after the country's last general elections.

In further attempts to strengthen their offense, the New York Giants selected Allen (Big Al) Simpson, a 260pound tackle from Colorado State, and Danny Buggs, a wide receiver from West Virginia with sprint speed, as their top two choices in the college draft yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The State Supreme Court today reinstated the manslaughter County woman in the death of one of her twin daughters.

Edith Reid Holman, widow of Eugene Holman who was chairman of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), now the Exxon Corporation, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 2 East 67th Street.

Harold E. Wiswall, vice president in charge of the insurance department of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Monday apparently of a heart attack, in the Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, New Hyde Park. He was 62 years old and lived at 187-08 Wexford Terrace, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

Last Saturday night, 800 to 900 people jammed the Directors Guild Theater in Hollywood for "a tribute to Dorothy Arzner," which was produced by the Committee of Women Members of the Guild. Miss Arzner was Hollywood's only woman director in the nineteen-thirties.

If New York State fails to appropriate funds for Urban Development Corporation bonds, the state's credit rating will be affected, Brenton W. Harries, president of the Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday in a speech delivered in New Orleans.

MANILA, Jan. 28 The Phillipine Supreme Court, besieged for more than two years with arguments against the martial-law Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, decided today to hear 14 citizens seeking to prevent what they contend is an unfree and illegal referendum on Feb. 27.
Fathers who evade or ignore child-support obligations will be in for a considerably tougher time as a result of Federal legislation signed earlier this month by President Ford.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) The dollar staged what dealers described today as a technical recovery from its recent steep slide:
DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 28 The change-over to a presidential form of government and the establishment of a new administration have stirred un easiness and distrust among some Bengalis and diplomats.

Almost 37,000 more New York City residents lost their jobs in December, pushing the unemployment rate here up 1.1 percentage points from 7.4 to 8.5 per cent and the total of jobless to 269,700, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 More unemployed American workers are turning to the food stamp program, so that 17.1 million people 8 per cent of the American population are purchasing their groceries with these coupons, Department of Agriculture figures are reported to show.
Prices of wheat futures staged a vigorous recovery late yesterday after a decline that began Monday in response to the cancellation by the Chinese of contracts for 601,000 tons of wheat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Eleven weeks after the Nov. 5 Congressional election, the Senate took the first step today toward deciding whom the voters of New Hampshire elected as their junior Senator.
The Iranian Government has begun plans for a major development in Teheran that, if built in its entirety, will be one of the most extensive new-town projects of the twentieth century.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 (AP) A state appeals court ruled today that a policeman had no legal obligation to sound the siren on his car while chasing a suspect.

The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, James J. Needham, ever on the lookout for ways to spark the equity markets, is talking up an idea that American corporations should be allowed to deduct common dividends as a business expense.
It was billed as the National Football League's annual selection meeting, but for the Jets there was a lot more to the hectic day than the routine selection of college players.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he believed a formula could be found in the Middle East to reconcile Israel's desire for progress toward peace with Egypt's insistence on the return of additional occupied territory in Sinai.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Counterintelligence Program of the Federal Bureau of Investigation attempted to encourage the dismissal of an Arizona State University professor in 1970 by filing an anonymous, derogatory letter about him with a college committee that was reviewing his teaching contract, according to documents from F.B.I. files.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 Governor Carey said today that he was considering the removal of criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana and replacing them "with a system of fines or mandatory attendance at health clinics" for treatment.

Brokers huddled six-deep around Post No. 10 on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. "E.F. Hutton ... 232!" a broker shouted. "One, five hundred," he yelled again. "I sold you 500," someone replied.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 24 The political uncertainty that envelops this Mediterranean island is severely hampering efforts to reconstruct the Cypriote economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 A loophole in the Emergency Jobs and Employment Assistance Act, which was enacted to provide benefits to jobless people, may legally extend millions of dollars in assistance to thousands of schoolteachers when they take their vacations this summer, officials of the Department of Labor said today.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 A second state witness testified today that Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden had exercised no improper influence in the awarding of city painting contracts.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter last year fell 75.5 per cent below those of the final quarter of 1973. For all of 1974, the nation's largest chemical producer said profit was down 31.1 per cent from 1973, despite record sales for the quarter and the year.

For the fifth consecutive year, donations to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded $1-million. The 159 latest contributions aggregating $15,742.63, raised the total receipts to $1,004,024.50 in the fund's 63d annual appeal.

The Justice Department disclosed yesterday in Washington that a Federal grand jury in New York has been investigating alleged price-fixing by major sugar refiners during 1974, when sugar prices soared 400 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 Four men who produced $8.3million in counterfeit currency with paper, press, plates and ink supplied by the Secret Service will begin jail terms Monday.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 Governor Carey said today that he was considering the removal of criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana and replacing them "with a system of fines or mandatory attendance at health clinics" for treatment.

The Pittston Company, the nation's largest independent coal producer, reported yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1974 increased 398.8 per cent from a year earlier. Similar increases were reported for the year, despite a nearly 2-million-ton decrease in the amount of coal the company sold.

New York nee Nieuw Amsterdam, is an ancient city, unlike most of its fellow American settlements. Herb Washington, a sprinter-turned base-stealer, said yesterday he had been offered an undisclosed salary increase by the Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley. Washington is the only major leaguer used exclusively as a pinch-runner. Although last season, his first, was a controversial one, including a pickoff in the World Series, Washington said his confidence had been bolstered since he was given a raise "in tune with the times."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today that a moratorium was continuing on the use of a contraceptive device called the Dalkon Shield.
The stock market rally, while powered by the heaviest trading in history, nevertheless slipped into lower gear yesterday and only managed to finish with a moderate gain.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 28 (UPI) George Johnson and Mel Utley tallied 18 points apiece to lead St. John's to a 72-63 victory over Villanova tonight.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 28 They were billed as the "new" Minnesota North Stars, but they played the same way as they had when shut out by the Islanders back in October, Tonight only the score and the crowd count were different; New York 6, Minnesota 2, before an audience of 14,169 at Nassau Coliseum. The victory was the Islanders' 19th in the National Hockey League, equaling their total of last year.

The Justice Department disclosed yesterday in Washington that a Federal grand jury in New York has been investigating alleged price-fixing by major sugar refiners during 1974, when sugar prices soared 400 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that Latin America's year-long "new dialogue" with the United States was in jeopardy as a result of the postponement of a hemisphere foreign ministers' meeting in Buenos Aires.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 To the Penn players, there was no place like home tonight as they gained sweet revenge by beating Princeton, 75 57, before 6,297 basketball fans at the Palestra.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28? Despite new warnings of strong Congressional opposition, President Ford asked Congress today?as his aides had said he would?to appropriate $300-million in additional military aid for South Vietnam and $222-million more for Cambodia.

ROTONDA, Fla., Jan. 28 In his first seven swings in the baseball-hitting competition of the ABC-TV Superstars program today, Anthony Davis managed one foul ball that the catcher had no chance on. The New York Jets may have a good chance of signing their first choice in today's National Football League draft.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 28 The leader of the moderate Democratic party, which won the most seats in Sunday's inconclusive election for a National Assembly, met today with leaders of other parties in an effort to put together a coalition.

The city and its labor unions yesterday recessed until today considerations of what First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh called "additional suggestions" in efforts to forestall the layoffs Friday of more than 1,000 Civil Service workers.
The sexual revolution is cooling down as some of the avantgarde find that sexual variety without affection leads to "frustration, tension and jealousy," a panel of researchers said yesterday.
Fordham University's basketball team had to struggle to beat a scrappy Columbia team last night, but finally prevailed, 67-58, and posted its fifth straight victory.

With those words the supreme being of professional football opened the National Football League's annual auction of human flesh, the draft of college boys, which Judge William P. Schweikert of the United States District Court has ruled patently unreasonable and illegal.

KESHENA, Wis., Jan. 28 Negotiations to settle the 28day occupation of a vacant Roman Catholic novitiate by armed Menominee Indians were abruptly broken off late tonight by the militant Indians over what they said was the wounding of one of their band by "a vigilante or a National Guard."
A gala benefit concert, with some of the best-known women performers in pop music, is being planned for the United Nations General Assembly on the evening of March 8.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Senator Barry Goldwater said today that former President Richard M. Nixon had told him that he would like to get back into politics to help the Republican party.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan 22 When the army took control of this country in September it propagated a now-ubiquitous slogan "Ethiopia first" but it did not say what was meant.

MANILA, Jan. 28 President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the Moslem insurgents on Mindanao Island controlled three major towns and were staging frequent ambushes of military detachments. A battalion commander and 41 of his men were killed, he said.
Mayor Beame announced yesterday steps to curb the use and possession of guns here.
The stock market rally slipped into lower gear yesterday. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange opened with substantial gains and then gradually slipped back.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 28 An investigator for the Hudson County Prosecutor's office testified today that he had found $630 in cash in a dresser drawer while searching the apartment of Ann Kelly, one of 20 defendants charged with numbers-game violations here.

The Board of Education will soon offer to extend Irving Anker's contract as School Chancellor, probably for another two years, and the 63-year-old educator is regarded as almost certain to agree to continue in the school system's top administrative post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he believed a formula could be found in the Middle East to reconcile Israel's desire for progress toward peace with Egypt's insistence on the return of additional occupied territory in Sinai.

The Senate has sensibly voted to entrust its Rules Committee with the task of unsnarling the New Hampshire Senatorial dispute in which one candidate was certified the winner by ten votes and then his rival was certified the winner by two votes. Since neither man has a clear claim, it was only logical to seat neither pending the outcome of the Rules Committee's examination of the results.
A bill to offer home care as an alternative to sending the elderly to nursing homes was introduced in Congress yesterday by Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan.

The Southern Railway, one of the most profitable rail carriers in the nation, reported yesterday a 12.5 per cent increase in its net income for the final quarter of 1974 compared with the same period in 1973.

After the trauma of a car accident, the last thing anybody needs is a hassle with an insurance company over getting the car put back together. But such hassles have been common enough to move the New York State Insurance Department to enact a new regulation, effective April 1, that gives consumers broad new rights in dealing with their insurance companies.
The Passaic County Prosecutor has asked a New Jersey judge to block Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from selecting two out-of-state lawyers in their appeal of triple-murder conviction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Several doctors told Congres sional investigators today that they favored severe restrictions on two widely prescribed antibiotics that have been linked to at least 14 deaths.

Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn and two upper-Broadway neighbors, Verdi Square and the Central Savings Bank, were granted protected status yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which thus guarded the cites against unregulated change of destruction.

Judge John J. Galgay was named here yesterday bankruptcy judge in the case of the Investors Funding Corporaof the Bankruptcy Act, according to James Bloor, trustee.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 28 (AP) Julia Sanderson, a star of Broadway musical comedies in the nineteen-twenties, died last evening at her home here. She was 87 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) Hanoi said today that the United States must halt reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam, provide it with reconstruction aid and end "military involvement and intervention" in South Vietnam to obtain a peaceful settlement.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 The first significant bill to come to a vote in the 1975 Legislature a stop-gap measure to avert a threatened cutoff of medical malpractice insurance was passed by the Senate today and promptly encountered a frosty greeting from the Assembly.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) The New York Rangers rallied from a 3-0 deficit tonight but the Los Angles Kings withstood the surge and defeated the New Yorkers, 5-2. On Sunday, the Rangers had overcome a 2-0 deficit and had beaten the Kings, 3-2.
While a top racing official was criticizing "gimmick" wagering yesterday, the Offtrack Betting Corporation was looking forward hopefully to bigger and better double-exacta payoffs.
Charlotte Brown, a 24-yearold black woman, was hired last January by Twentieth Century-Fox to be trained in publicity and advertising.
PARIS, Jan. 28 The Presidents of Egypt and France met today for the second day and the Egyptian leader inspected advanced military radar equipment and missiles that he might purchase.

Prices on the Amex rose again yesterday for the second straight day but not as much as in the previous session. Trading, however, was slightly lighter than on Monday. Prices in the over-the-counter market also rose in stepped-up trading.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (UPI) Bill Walsh, a writer and producer for the Disney studio, whose achievements included the "Mickey Mouse Club" and "Davy Crockett" televion series and films including "Mary Poppins," died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 61 years old.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 Editors at The Boston Globe said today that the newspaper was apparently the victim of a hoax in its recent report that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was believed to be here for cancer treatment.

Antonin Novotny, the Communist party leader who wielded virtual one-man rule in Czechslovakia from 1953 until 1968, when he was forced out by the "Prague Spring" democratic reforms of Alexander Dubcek, died yesterday at the age of 70.

SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Jan. 28 The defending champion Italian team suffered its first defeat in the World Bridge Federation's Berumda Bowl tournament today, losing to the Indonesians by 48 international match points.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 28 (AP) Freddie Lewis of the Spirits of St. Louis scored 26 points tonight as the East Squad trounced the West, 151-124, in the American Basketball Association's All-Star game.
