MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Armco Steel Corporation said today it would lay off 617 employes at its Middletown steel works, effective Feb. 2.

Bergdorf Goodman, which only three months ago opened the first suburban store in its (history in White Plains, has plans for four to six more stores and is augmenting its management team for this purpose.

PARIS, Jan. 28 President Val ry Giscard d'Estaing, who has been trying to thaw the icicles of aloofness from his high office in recent months, has taken another step in the direction of democratization by ordering the dropping of titles of nobility from invitations to the Elys e Palace.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 28 One morning last month, a mysterious phone call was made to the advertising department of the newspaper Dong-A Ilbo. "There will be hard days ahead of you," the anonymous caller said, identifying himself only as one of the paper's "bigger sponsors." The next day, ads began dropping off sharply.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 28 A Westchester County grand jury has indicted a former Peekskill City Court judge, Hugo Scuccimarra, for perjury in denying before a judicial inquiry that he had made sexual advances toward the mother of a defendant appearing before him.

Former Patrolman William R. Phillips was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 25 years to life in prison for the murders of a pimp and a prostitute in an East Side brothel on Christmas Eve, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Senate Judiciary Committee completed its questioning today of Attorney General-designate Edward H. Levi and, although several witnesses remain to be heard, the committee's speedy recommendation of his confirmation is expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission barred today any future purchases by newspaper owners of radio or television stations that serve the same market. It also ordered 16 such existing combinations to be broken up.

NEWARK, Jan. 28 A Superior Court judge today issued an order blocking the distribution of any funds collected at a Republican State Committee dinner scheduled to be held tomorrow night until a clear understanding is reached on the recipients of the funds.
Maisie Ward, the publisher, biographer and Catholic activist, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital at the age of 86. She lived at 7 Tonnele Avenue, Jersey City.

Coach Red Holzman's idea of giving Mel Davis his first National Basketball Association starting assignment worked out well enough last night, but a superb allround game by Walt Frazier was the ingredient that lifted the Knicks to a 115-111 victory over the Atlanta Hawks before a crowd of 17,754 at Madison Square Garden.

Almost 37,000 more New York City residents lost their jobs in December, pushing the unemployment rate here up 1.1 percentage points from 7.4 to 8.5 per cent and the total of jobless to 269,700, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Representative Leonor K. Sullivan of Missouri was deposed today as chairman of the Consumer Affairs Subcommittee as leadership changes continued in the House of Reprecentatives.

An auctioneer's chant echoed through the cavernous Acrite Industries plant, in the Bronx yesterday even as Borough President Robert Abrams accelerated his efforts to save the bankrupt cabinetmaking operation and the jobs of 200 workers formerly employed by the company.

Dr. Leonard Cohen, a mathematics professor at City College since 1951, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, while on vacation in Aruba, Netherlands Antilles. He was 46 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

Merrill Lynch Co., Inc., the diversified financial services holding company that owns the giant brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., reported yesterday a 9.9 per cent decline in earnings for the final quarter of last year but a 2.2 per cent gain for all 1974.

When Ansel Adams, the renowned scenic photographer, visited the White House the other day to discuss the National Park System, President Ford told him: "If anyone has the basic feeling for parks, I have."

PARIS, Jan. 28 The French Government decided today on a 10-year program to reduce the country's dependence on imported fuel from the present level of 75 per cent of energy used to 55 or 60 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Army has successfully tested a laser-guided artillery shell that defense officials believe will revolutionize the role of artillery on the battlefield.

BUDAPEST, Jan. 28 Two noted Hungarian sociologists, whose positions have been precarious since they underwent five days of police interrogation last November on suspicion of subversive agitation, say they have reached an agreement with the Government by which they hope to be able to continue their work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 In times of recession, when industrial corporations must scramble to bring costs in line with reduced sales and shrinking profits, the easy, standard tactic has been to lay off employes.

PARIS, Jan. 28 The French Government decided today on a 10-year program to reduce the country's dependence on imported fuel from the present level of 75 per cent of energy used to 55 or 60 per cent.

John Portman, the Atlantabased architect and developer, said yesterday that plans for the 54-story, 2,000-room hotel proposed for Times Square would be abandoned unless long-term financing could be found within five to six months.

It is 7 o'clock. A family in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, enters the communications room of their home and switches on television. A projector as low to the floor as a cocktail table casts the nearly life-size images onto a concave 4-by-8 screen. The picture is in color and is accompanied by stereophonic sound.
Dr. Samuel H. Bell, a dentist on the Lower East Side and in the Bronx for 42 years, died yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 79 years old.

Nice place, nice show.

A deranged prisoner disarmed and shot his police guard and fatally wounded a visitor last night before his effort to escape from St. Vincent's Hospital turned its corridors into the scene of a grim chase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Ford indicated today that he would be willing to compromise with Congress on tax cut legislation, but appeared to rule out any concessions on his program to reduce oil imports.

SHAWANO, Wis., Jan. 29 The Alexian Brothers, a Roman Catholic order, agreed tonight to extend until noon Friday a proposed agreement to settle peacefully the 29-day-old occupation by armed Menominee Indians of a vacant novitiate that the Alexians own in nearby Gresham.

The New York Mets signed Bud Harrelson yesterday, three weeks before the opening of spring training. Harrelson agreed to his 10th contract for about $70,000. The Met shortstop was home in California with his parents and two children, and also i with a case of flu.
The metropolitan area faces the "most serious" social and environmental consequences because of a continued scattering of population, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (AP) Leonid I. Brezhnev, who has been absent from public functions for nearly five weeks, was seen by Westerners on his way to work yesterday and today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 While public debate has centered on President Ford's controversial economic and energy proposals, he has been formulating an over-all policy position...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Some well-known musical talents began performing verbally here today in a program without an audience a Music Policy Conference staged by the National Endowment for the Arts. The purpose is to help the endowment, whose music program is the largest area of its arts funding, define issues and problems in the field.

PARIS, Jan. 29 The United States has begun a new round of difficult bargaining with Western industrial nations to intensify the consumer cooperation it feels is necessary before any meeting with oil-producing states.

The city's Muncipal Broadcasting System said yesterday that austerity measures might force it to curtail broadcasts on WNYC-FM radio between midnight and 6 A.M. and to cut back service on the other city-owned stations, WNYCTV/Channel 31, and WNYCAM radio.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that "troubles may break out in a number of areas" as a result of the decline of United States military power.

The Andy Warhol Factory of International Art Artifacts has at long last turned its atention to the theater. It was a musical, appropriately enough about bombs, called "Man on the Moon." It is the kind of show that can leave a strong man a little numb and a litle dumb.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Bomb threats against Federal buildings caused the evacuation of nearly 6,000 Government employes in Washington today, after an early morning explosion in the State Department.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 29 (UPI) Two Protestant gunmen surprised three men at a lunch-hour chess game today and killed one, a Roman Catholic.

Boughton Cobb Jr., a technical adviser and writer on marine construction, died yesterday of cancer at his home on Shore Road, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. He was 50 years old.

MILLBURN, Jan. 29 In his first partisan political foray since being sworn into office last December, Vice President Rockefeller visited New Jersey tonight in an effort to revitalize a state Republican party that has been debilitated by Watergate, the disastrous gubernatorial campaign of Charles W. Sandman Jr. and the economic ravages of the nation's continuing recession.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Two frequently prescribed antibioties have been associated with at least 32 deaths, Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said today.

Mayor Beame, in what he called a "milestone in labor negotiations," announced early this morning that in return for union concessions, 391 civil service workers scheduled to be dismissed from the city payroll tomorrow would be retained.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 Lebanon has called for an urgent meeting of the Arab League Defense Council next Tuesday to consider Israeli raids into southern Lebanon, but Lebanese political forces are divided over what form of help should be sought.

Harper Row has turned over to Columbia University a collection of first-edition books, letters and contracts with authors that covers American publishing history for most of the 19th century and sheds new light on the careers of such writers as Mark Twain, Herman Melville and Henry James.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gen. Alexander Haig Jr. has repaid the Army $91 in shipment charges for liquor shipped here in a crate marked "glassware," an aide said today.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said yesterday that Federal export curbs on wheat and soybeans, imposed last October because of fears of domestic shortages and soaring food prices, would be relaxed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Reports that President Ford may appoint John Bell Williams, former Mississippi Governor, to the new Federal Elections Commission drew an angry protest today from the Congressional Black Caucus.

The Braniff International Corporation, the holding company for Braniff Airways, said yesterday that its airline subsidiary earned $6.7-million, or 34 cents a share, during the fourth quarter of 1974. The earnings were 51 per cent higher than the $4.4-million, or 22 cents a share, reported during the same period in 1973.

LONDON, Jan. 29 A strike by bus crews over a fatal assault on a black bus conductor left this city without buses today. Although it rained all day, Londoners coped well and there was little disruption.

An examination of Federal Energy Administration regulations indicates that consumers will not feel the effect of price increases on petroleum products until March if President Ford goes ahead with his plan to impose a fee of $1 a barrel on imported oil on Feb. 1.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a fourth-quarter net loss of $76.2-million compared with net income of $23.6 million, or 26 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1973.
Wheat futures prices closed with little change yesterday after fluctuations following news that the Soviet Union had canceled an order for 3.7 million bushels of American wheat.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 The "Big Six" Mayors made their ritual pilgrimage to Albany for state aid today and said afterward that Governor Carey had seemed sympathetic to the idea of alterations in the budget he will make public on Friday.
BUFFALO, Jan. 29 The New York Rangers meet the Buffalo Sabres here tomorrow night in a National Hockey League game, the first of seven within an 11day span for the Rangers.
Nassau Downs OTB staged its first race yesterday, a nonbetting affair through the streets of Westbury, Uniondale and Hempstead, L.I.

Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced yesterday the appointment of Pierre N. Leval, 38 years old, Mr. Morgenthau's former campaign manager, had served as chief of the appeals bureau in the United States Attorney's office when Mr. Morgenthau was head of that office.

The Paper Bag Players are back in New York with their latest imaginative offering, "Everybody, Everybody." It consists of revue-like sketches that blend art, music, dance and drama and has a tempo that carries one happily from relaxing mood to suspenseful melodrama.

DETROIT Nowhere in America can the nation's disregard for its cities and the failure of the nation's economic policies be seen so clearly as in Detroit. Nowhere are the nation's other grave problems so obvious: racism, unemployment, crime, the lack of landuse laws, the dreadful failure of forty years of housing programs, a costly transportation system that depends so heavily on the automobile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) United States trade with China climbed to a record total of $922.1-million in 1974 but is expected to decline by about 40 per cent this year because of reduced Chinese agricultural purchases, the National Council for United States-China Trade has reported.

A detective commander who previously headed an investigation of the Black Liberation Army was put in charge yesterday of a major police search for Puerto Rican nationalists believed responsible for recent bombings in the city.
LAS VEGAS, Jan, 29 Jimmy Connors checked in at Caesars Palace today for Sunday's $100,000 tennis match against Rod Laver, and insisted that the money wasn't the important thing.
The National Football League's draft of the supposedly best 442 college senniors ended last night at 7:58 when the Pittsburgh Steelers, the league champions, made the last selection.

NEWARK, Jan. 29 The Newark Housing Authority and the Columbus Homes Tenants Association today signed an agreement ending a four-and-ahalf-year rent strike at the 6,000 resident low income project in the city's North Ward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Ford indicated today that he would be willing to compromise with Congress on tax cut legislation, but appeared to rule out any concessions on his program to reduce oil imports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Senate approved today $275-million in emergency grants and loan guarantees to keep the Penn Central Railroad from shutting down next month.

HONG KONG, Jan. 29 Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping, who has returned to leading government and party positions in Peking in the last year, has now also been named army chief of staff, a Foreign Ministry spokesman disclosed today.

While the Giants drafted a linebacker the Jets selected last year, a placekicker who kicks barefoot and a cousin of Joe Morgan, the baseball star, the Jets intensified their involvement with the World Football League yesterday. They drafted one of that league's top pass receivers.
Ashland Gains 12.2% The Phillips Petroleum Com pany reported yesterday a 2.5 per cent decline in profits for the fourth quarter of 1974 but a 74.5 per cent advance for the full year.

Federal and city law enforcement officials yesterday announced the indictment of 19 alleged heroin traffickers and the seizure of more than half a million dollars in cash at the home of a couple in Teaneck, N.J.
OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (UPI) Canada will increase the cost of oil exported to the United States through a 40-cent-a-barrel increase in its export tax, Energy Minister Donald MacDonald said yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The prosecution rested today, using its final witness to emphasize the central theme of its case: that the fetus aborted by Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin could have lived if given the chance.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 29 The Palestine Libenation Organization announced today that it had decided to treat the hijacking of airplanes, ships or trains as crimes and would impose death penalties on hijackers if their actions led to the loss of life.

ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 29 (AP) Lise-Marie Morerod of Switzerland, who had won only once previously, beat the world skiing elite today as she captured the slalom race at the Arlberg Kandahar ski meeting, a World Cup event.

Six years ago, a Federal commission urged the development of 110 new communities to accommodate 20 million of the nation's expected additional inhabitants in the following three decades. Only 16 such "new towns," with an eventual capacity of less than one million people, have come into being and they are having financial difficulties.

MIAMI, Jan. 29 A former New York City policeman, who won the departmental Medal of Honor and a dozen other citations for bravery before service wounds forced his retirement, has pleaded guilty here to armed robbery, it was disclosed today.

The board of the Exxon Corporation cut the company's dividend to $1.25 a share for the first quarter of 1975 from $1.55 a share in the fourth quarter of 1974. In the first quarter of 1974, Exxon the world's largest oil company paid shareholders $1.10 a share, the same as that for the final quarter of 1973.

DENVER, Jan. 29 (UPI) A Federal Appeals Court, in explaining why it overturned a lower court decision, says the International Business Machines Corporation's alleged antitrust practices were part of the competitive scene in a highly competitive business.
ALBANY The front door at the Ambassador bar banged open. Doug the bartender looked up and saw an Assemblyman lurch in, slump against the wall, then walk unsteadily toward the bar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) An Associated Press dispatch earlier this month, reporting that a former Washington lobbyist, Fred B. Black Jr., was convicted in 1964 of income tax evasion, failed to report that the conviction was overturned and that Mr. Black was acquitted in a second trial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A Democratic study group unanimously recommended today that the House create a bipartisan select committee to investigate the activities of all Government intelligence agencies.

A major narcotics defendant, his 26-year-old son and an alleged associate went on trial in Federal District Court here yesterday on charges of conspiracy to sell large amounts of heroin, but another defendant failed to appear and forfeited bail of more than $200,000.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29 The Jersey City Medical Center and the police here today announced a new program designed to give priority to medical and pyschological treatment of sexual assault victims.

Everybody has a special area of identification, and Pierre Boulez's is the immediate postwar period through about 1970 the great age of postserialism. It was the first of two programs of new music, using Juilliard student musicians, given under the auspices of the Lila Acheson Wallace Visiting Artists Series.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 Government planners are being advised that paying too much attention to consumer goods could make Soviet citizens greedy, egotistical, dependent and doctrinally weak on Communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 During World War II, Donald M. Nelson headed the War Production Board; the former Sears, Roebuck executive typified the businessman who came to Washington to put his managerial skills to work to win the war.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) Prize money at Wimbledon this year will surpass $250,000 for the first time, a spokeman for the All-England Tennis Club said today.

Gerald Ford is beginning to look more like a President, which is not necessarily a good thing. In dealing, with the energy crisis, he has acted unilaterally, challenged rather than consulted Congress, and proclaimed one true religion.

PARIS, Jan. 30 French sources said today that Egypt had ordered a total of 44 Mirage fighters from France. Half of them are to be the new F-1 plane, which went into service with the French Air Force last year.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Phyllis Fraser Cerf, widow of the publisher, Bennett Cerf, were married yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in a candlelight service attended by 200 people, including Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, celebrities and friends.

MARCUS HOOK, Pa. Friday, ripped through a tanker early today as its cargo of crude oil was being unloaded at the British Petroleum plant dock on the Delaware River. The police said there were "quite a few injuries."

Alonzo S. (Jake) Gaither, the former head football coach and athletic director at Florida A. and M., was named yesterday to the National Football Foundation Hall of Fame. People should stop thinking of environmental protection "as sort of dessert on the social menu" and realize it is "the meat and potatoes of man's existence," Russell W. Peterson, chairman of the Federal Council on Environmental Quality, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Saying that inflation was still a major problem, the Federal Reserve chairman, Arthur F. Burns, recommended today against any permanent tax cut and indicated that his agency would not quickly ease credit to bolster the economy.

When a consumer gets an advertising message, what makes him remember it and remember it right? A number of researchers addressed themselves to that question yesterday at a conference sponsored at the Biltmore Hotel by the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association.

The Civil Aeronautics Board gave Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines approval yesterday for a massive exchange of overseas routes that would save the financially ailing carriers up to $25-million each per year.

GREENWICH, Conn. Sculpture of a full-bodied obstreperous sort thrives on tragic involvement. Agitation and anxiety are one, in other words, and agitation is basic to abstract expressionism, whether in painting or in sculpture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, citing a detailed new Treasury analysis, told Congress today that the build-up of petrodollars in the oil-exporting countries would be much less in the years ahead than was estimated last year after the sharp increase in the price of oil.

ROANOKE, Va. Jan. 30 (UPI) Fifth-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, who won $7,000 last week with a secondplace showing in the United States professional indoor championships in Philadelphia, beat Gene Mayer of Mendham, N.J., 6-2, 6-3, today to enter the quarterfinals of the Roanoke international tennis tournament.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 30(UPI) Kanawha County's controversial textbooks do not violate the First Amendment guarantees of the United States Constitution, a Federal judge ruled today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 30 (UPI) A fleet of 87 vessels is expected to answer the starter's gun tomorrow when the Southern Ocean Racing Conference kicks off its 1975 series with the 103mile St. Petersburgh to Anclote Key race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Administration opened an uphill battle in Congress today for additional military aid for the Saigon Government with a claim that North Vietnam was moving one and perhaps two other combat divisions into South Vietnam.

In what would represent a rare shrinkage of the state bureaucracy, Governor Carey recommended yesterday in his proposed budget the elimination or consolidation of 20 state boards, commissions and councils, many of which have been havens for "seldom show" political appointees.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 30 Chinese have come to India to play table tennis, and the Indian Government, which has been seeking to normalize relations with Peking, is treating the games as more than a sporting event.

The Union Pacific Corporation, operator of the Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's most profitable line in 1973, reported yesterday a 45 per cent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1974, resulting primarily from the company's decision to switch accounting methods and put $31.2-million into a special reserve fund to cover anticipated losses on an oil project.

TRENTON, Jan. 30 At least one of every 10 persons in the labor force in New Jersey was unemployed last month, according to state figures released today. State labor officials said the figure signified an economic and social crisis of major proportions in the state.

The Gulf Oil Corporation, the last major United States-based international oil company to report 1974 results, announced yesterday a drop of 19.6 per cent in net income in the fourth quarter but an advance of 33 per cent for the full year.

Boris Blacher, one of the leading German composers in the period after World War II, has died at the age of 72, it was announced yesterday in Berlin, where he had been living since 1922. The son of German and Estonian parents, he was born in Newchwang, China.

The 19-year-old former convict accused of wounding a police officer and killing a man who came to his aid during a shootout at St. Vincent's Hospital Wednesday had been sentenced to a 10month prison term on Aug. 29, but for some reason that could not be learned yesterday had been released from jail less than five months later.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 One immediate line of speculation about Governor Carey's budget proposal centered on which parts of it might be negotiating items to be surrendered in compromise with the two parties that control the Legislature.

MUCAMBO PLANTATION Brazil The air on this rambling cocoa plantation in the northeastern state of Bahia is sweet with the fragrance of fermented cocoa beans and the freshness of last night's tropical rain. Barefoot workers sing cheerful folksongs as they stamp the impurities from the dried beans. Others slash away at the forest with machetes to clear the ground for a new crop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Saying that inflation was still a major problem, the Federal Reserve chairman, Arthur F. Burns, recommended today against any permanent tax cut and indicated that his agency would not quickly ease credit to bolster the economy.

Wheat, corn and soybeans traded in a narrow price range yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting uncertainty about the effect of the Soviet cancellation of orders for 100,000 tons of American wheat.

Contracts for new construction, expanded by plans to build a huge new nuclear power plant, rose to $7.3-billion in December, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, reported yesterday.

CHAMONIX, France, Jan. 30 (AP) Gustavo Thoeni, Italy's 23-year-old world and Olympic champion, showed his masterly form again today and won the World Cup slalom race of the Arlberg Kandahar ski tournament.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that the $300million in additional aid requested for his Government by the Ford Administration was "the minimum" that his forces needed to defend themselves from stepped-up North Vietnamese and Vietcong attacks.
Samuel Markewich, a practicing lawyer here for more than 70 years, died yesterday on a visit to Los Angeles. He was 93 years old and lived at 23 West 73d Street.

Surviving the loss of Glenn Mosley, who has been declared ineligible by the school, Seton Hall opened the Madison Square Garden Classic last night with an 8987 victory over Fairfield University.
Two Brooklyn men were arraigned on murder yesterday in the fatal shooting of a woman bookkeeper and the wounding of two co-workers in a Queens holdup on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Ford today extended until March 1 the deadline for Vietnam-era draft evaders and military deserters to apply for clemency.
The Continental Can Company, the world's largest packaging manufacturer, reported yesterday an 8 per cent drop in fourth-quarter profits, the first decline since 1971.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 27 The chief executive of Ghana's Cocoa Marketing Board has termed a world slump in the consumption of chocolate "an unfortunate but temporary condition" and he declared that Ghanaians "woudl continue to produce as much cocoa as we can."

The dismissal of 260 city policemen, the first Civil Service workers to be laid off since the Depression years, was ordered by Mayor Beame yesterday after the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Ken McFeeley, rejected a city proposal for labor-contract concessions that would have forestalled the discharges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 iUpl Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, today called on Congress to enact an alternative to President Ford's oil program that would include provision for emergency rationing and a cut-back on oil imports.

Revised terms for the merger of the Empire National Bank into the National Bank of North America were announced yesterday.

Filbert Bayi found some home cooking less than a 440-yard dash from Madison Square Garden yesterday, which was all he needed to take his mind off Marty Liquori and his first indoor race in tonight's 50th Wanamaker Mile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Karen DeCrow a feminist leader, predicted today that the Equal Rights Amendment would be ratified by April. However, Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, foresaw "a full hard year's work ahead" because it becomes part of the Constitution.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) Attorney General William B. Saxbe urged Congress today to create "a permanent, watchdog committee" to guard against Justice Department wrongdoing.

A group of eight electric utilities announced yesterday plans for a joint feasibility study for a $250-million plant that would reprocess spent fuel from their nuclear power plants. An anonymous gift of $15,000 yesterday highlighted the continuing stream of contributions to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

The nation's retail sales faltered in January as many consumers became more cautious in buying clothing, home furnishings and other departmentstore merchandise, according to reports yesterday from a number of the country's biggest retailers.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 30 A committee appointed by the British Government to review antiterrorist laws in Northern Ireland recommended in its report today that detention without trial should be retained, but not indefinitely.

President Ford's proposed tax of $3 a barrel on crude oil and 37 cents a thousand cubic feet on natural gas would cost the nation's natural gas consumers $8-billion a year, Louis R. TRENTON, Jan. 30 Governor Byrne announced today that New Jersey's statutory ceiling for interest rates on conventional mortgage loans would be reduced from 9 per cent to 9 per cent, effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 After almost nine years of controversy, the Drug Enforcement Administration once again is ready to propose formal controls over the tranquilizers Valium and Librium, two of the most widely prescribed drugs.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters, made up of artists, composers and writers eminent in their fields, has elected Harrison E. Salisbury, the newspaperman and author, as its president for a three-year term. He succeeds Jacques Barzun, a university professor at Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Associate Justice William O. Douglas, who was partially paralyzed by a stroke New Year's Eve, is on the mend, but he will probably not be able to rejoin his colleagues on the United States Supreme Court before mid-March, at the earliest.

In a somber session yesterday, the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee heard tenants and public and private housing-project representatives debate proposed legislation to bar landlords from excluding tenants with dogs.
The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday reduced its prime rate to 9 per cent, the lowest rate charged by a major bank since March, 1974, as corporations continued to cut back their borrowings.

Dr. William T. Daily, an attending physician at Long Island College Hospital, serving its obstetrics and gynecology department for 45 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 99 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.

Those who depend on Groundhog or Candlemas Day (Feb. 2) for a prophecy on the end of winter had better trust an almanac instead.

This is Candlemas Day by the Christian calendar, the time of the purification of the Virgin and the blessing of the candles. It also is Groundhog Day, which is believed far to predate Candlemas. The superstition is that sunshine on Groundhog Day means six more weeks of winter.

The language of finance is full of instances of the pathetic fallacy--the endowment of inanimate objects with human traits. Thus, one day the dollar is said to be weak, the next strong, and on the third to be suffering a sinking spell. This does not mean, however, that the dollar is undergoing some sort of crisis. All it means is that on particular days market forces have pushed the dollar up or down a bit.

The gloomy forecasts in President Ford's budget report if well grounded are strong evidence of the inadequacy of his own program to pull the nation out of recession. Confronted with the reality of slowdown but still threatened by a recrudescence of inflation, the President and his advisers seem to be managing somehow to lose on both fronts at the same time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The cover of the new budget is a modernistic design in red, white and blue. It is the first time in history that red the symbol of losses and deficits has been used on a budget cover.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Vice President Rockefeller said today that his commission's investigation of alleged domestic spying by the Central Intelligence Agency might require more than the three-month period set by President Ford.
The Amerada Hess Corporation announced yesterday a 48.6 per cent decline in profits for the fourth quarter and the Atlantic Richfield Corporation a 5.7 per cent advance.

A labor lobbyist said yesterday that New York State's present unemployment insurance, benefit level now being studied for an increase "can only act as a work disincentive" for some people.
The stock market, after early weakness resulting from profit taking, made a broad advance yesterday in heavy trading.

After turning down a request from the Republican National Committe for the purchase of three half-hours of prime time, CBS-TV has agreed to sell five minutes on Thursday night to Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Ford's budget included today a new plan of the Forest Service to accumulate a stockpile of timber from Federal lands to be ready "for future sale as a reserve against expected increases in demand."

Representatives of the New Jersey Attorney General will go before a grand jury in Trenton today, seeking authority to subpoena financial records of five nursing homes in the state, four of which have, been associated with the interests of Bernard Bergman over a period of years.

Calling the Park Plaza Hotel at 50 West 77th Street a "chamber of horrors," Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office had slatted court action to dissolve the corporation operating the single-room-occupancy hotel and to gain the appointment of a receiver to evict tenants engaged in unlawful activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would receive $67.7-million in Federal funds for rivers, harbors, beaches and lakes under the 15-month budget submitted today by President Ford.

The administrative restructuring of the city into 40 or 50 "service districts," each with its own police, sanitation, parks, health and other service units, was recommended yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission.

Moshe Starkman, a Yiddish and Hebrew writer, who directed Yiddish publicity of the United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Miami Beach. He was 68 years old and lived at 4700 Broadway.

It will be mostly sunny today over the Northeast, Florida peninsula and desert Southwest. DETROIT, Feb. 3 The General Motors Corporation reported today that its profit for the final quarter of 1974 fell 1.7 per cent from the same period a year earlier, and that its earnings for 1974 were down 60 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Ford Administration plans to propose long-range legislation that would permit part of the tax revenues now earmarked for highway construction to be spent for other purposes.

Federal environmental officials reported yesterday what they called the first real progress since 1973 in their attempts to get city and state officials to carry out a transportation control plan that would make New York City's air healthful.
Two New York radio stations, WOR and the all-news station WINS, said yesterday that they planned to carry President Ford's news conference in Atlanta at 2:30 P.M. today.

Logue, president of the Urban Development Corporation, warned two State Assembly committees today that it would be futile for the Legislature to carry the foundering corporation through March with a $178-million emergency appropriation without advance assurance that major banks would buy the agency's bonds again in April.

LONDON, Fb. 3 The Royal Shakespeare Company sees its new season of repertory in New York as part of a growing artistic friendship with the Brooklyn Academy of Music, something more valuable than the expected modest profit.

Will Georg Jensen lose its Scandinavian accent for an Argentine one? Julio Tanjeloff, the store's new owner, says no, in English strongly flavored with the Spanish of his native Buenos Aires. Mr. Tanjeloff has just acquired the Madison Avenue specialty store and its five branches, from the Kenton Corporation, whose holdings are now down to Cartier and Mark Cross in New York. (Mr. Tanjeloff has also bought the Cartier wholesale division.)

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters) The Justice Department petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to begin a broad investigation with major emphasis on the route structures of international air carries.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 More than 120 nations began here today the second session of a conference convened by Switzerland to expand the four 1949 international conventions for insuring the humanitarian treatment of war victims.

It's a privilege and a pleasure to be in Atlanta. I've enjoyed this day and looking forward to this press conference. Mr. Cutts of the Atlanta Papers.

In a dramatic exchange with Representative Edward I. Koch, at a United States Senate hearing here yesterday, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut backed away from his earlier insistence that he had never warned Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein not to investigate nursing homes owned by Bernard Bergman. Instead, Mr. Steingut said he could not recollect such conversations.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. Feb. 4 Gov. TRENTON, Feb. 4 The State Public Advocate sued the prison system on behalf of 58 inmates today, charging that they were systematically beaten by guards in a special unit for hard-core prisoners.
MANILA, Feb. 4 The Philippine military, responding to charges of torture made by religious groups, took action yesterday against seven enlisted men and five officers.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 Governor Carey is expected to turn down a request by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for a $110-million loan to help the deficit-ridden agency get through the first three months of the year, an aide to the Governor said today.

The French team that finished third in the world team championship in Bermuda last week has every reason to be satisfied with its performance. The annals of medicine list few experiments as daring and revolutionary as those that Dr. Werner Forssmann performed on his heart beginning in 1929. As a 25-year-old interne who disobeyed orders from his superiors at a small hospital near Berlin, he pushed a catheter, or thin tube, into a vein in his elbow crease and then threaded it up past his armpit through a series of veins connecting with the right side of his heart.

For the first time in a 16year-old underground war for independence, Basque guerrillas in Spain say they are willing to stop shooting and negotiate with the Government. But a Basque spokesman said that Madrid would probably balk at the terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Secretary of State Kissinger has decided that if his coming efforts to bring about an Egyptian-Israeli agreement fail, he will give up his step-by-step mediation approach, State Department officials said today.
TRENTON, Feb. 6 A jury of four men and eight women deliberated more than four hours today without reaching a verdict in the conspiracy trial of Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden and two others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan submitted his resignation today and said he planned to return to New York to reassume the eadership of the Building and Construction Trades Council.
Senator Henry Jackson, Washington Democrat, who has now formally entered the contest for his party's Presidential nomination, is a strong candidate yet a vulnerable one.

Two elderly sisters, 73 and 66 years old, were arrested yesterday and accused by fire marshals of having participated in a conspiracy to hire professional "torches" to set hundreds of fires in Queens and Nassau Counties over the last 12 years for millions of dollars in insurance.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP) Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, said today that he had offered to resign from the Presidential commission investigating the Central Intelligence Agency, because he has been too busy to go to its meetings.
LISBON, Feb. 6 A scheduled visit here by the Soviet. Minister for Fisheries, Aleksandr A Ishkov, has been called off according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

More than a dozen of the top singers from the Metropolitan Opera's roster performed at Carnegie Hall last night in a concert that, had originally been scheduled to be sung by Richard Tucker and Robert Merrill and that was turned instead into a moving tribute to Mr. Tucker, who died last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, betting that his traditional liberalism would prove popular in hard times.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Agriculture Department formally confirmed today reports that the Soviet Union has canceled orders for American wheat, but said large sales have been made to other buyers.

World sugar futures jumped the daily 2-cents-a-pound limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, possibly because of a report that Iran was in the market for a substantial amount of sugar.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. There is a sad misunderstanding in American higher education about the teaching and study of folklore. Were folklore called by a highfalutin name or even by folkloristics, a term now making headway-it would encounter less suspicion and derision from university administrators and faculties.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which operates more supermarkets than any other national food chain, plans to close "many more" stores this year than in any previous year, Jonathan L. Scott, A.'s new chairman, said here yesterday. The largest number of stores closed in one year was 404, in 1972.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 Leonid I Brezhnev, the Soviet leader has been extended a fresh in vitation to visit Italy this year Western European diplomats reported today.
Nearly 900 businessmen got up early yesterday to help the Boy Scouts open a $2.1-million fund-raising campaign at the annual dawn-patrol breakfast at the Walderf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 President Ford struck back at Congress today, accusing it, through his press secretary, of inaction on his energy and economic programs and of doing "basically nothing" in a month of operations.
Offtrack betting enterprises in Schenectady and Western New York were ordered yesterday to stop taking wagers on thoroughbred races at Garden State Park in New Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (Reuters) President Ford's tax and energy package will lead to no more than a 2 per cent over-all increase in the inflation rate, according to a report issued today by the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates.

The main banking trends of the new year remained intact this week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday in its weekly statistics. Business loans declined, interest rates dropped, moneysupply growth remained stalled and banks were less cramped for reserves.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and the City Council have taken opposing positions on a proposal by Inamu Amiri Baraka, the black socialist, to build a 258-unit housing project in the predominantly black president, Earl Harris.

Two Arab investment groups have managed to keep several major Jewish-controlled European banking houses out of two Eurodollar syndications, according to Business Week magazine. It describes the move as "the first overt attempt to discriminate against Jewish-controlled institutions since the big wave of petrodollar spending began."

The National Collegiate Athletic Association has tried for nearly a quarter of a century to establish academic credibility for all its eligible student members, but tampering with high school grades and transcripts of outstanding athletes is taking place more than ever.

We have many comedies about love but rather few about passion. We have many comedies about life but rather few about life-style. We have many comedies about language but rather few about its accentuation. Which is why, one supposes, Noel Coward's "Private Lives" is not only so very durable but also so very remarkable. The fact that it is also screamingly funny has also probably never hindered it.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 Faced with continued opposition, the John F. Kennedy Library Corporation dropped today its plans for a museum near Harvard Square honoring the late President.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Two Democrats warming up to run for President pictured Secretary of State Kissinger's role as a central political issue todaybut from opposite vantage points.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 6 One of the rockets that the Cambodian insurgents have been firing daily into Phnom Penh struck the classroom of a crowded primary school today and 14 children, all under 12 years old, were killed. At least 25 others were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Dr. Arthur F. Burns, c hairman of the Federal Reserve Board, opposed today a Democratic bill aimed at reducing interest rates and allocating bank loans to "priority" borrowers rather than speculators.
An 18-year-old youth was stabbed while playing basketball at the University Settlement House last night and died an hour later at Bellevue Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Governor Carey and Mayor Beame came here today to seek Federal funds from Vice President Rockefeller in a ritual reminiscent of other supplications involving the three men.

Avon Products, Inc., which had an outstanding growth record until the start of 1974 in its door-to-door selling of cosmetics and toiletries, reported yesterday its fourth successive decline in quarterly profits. As a result, annual earnings retreated for the first time in more than 10 years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The House Ways and Means Committee gave all-but-final approval today to an antirecession tax-cut bill that would give almost everyone a cash rebate of $100 to $200 this spring.

The New York Stock Exchange bowed last night to the Securities and Exchange Commission and said it would not sue to block the order to end fixed brokerage commission rates by May 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Laurence H. Silberman, the No. 2 man at the Justice Department for the last year, is expected to be named President Ford's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, Administration officials disclosed today.

Comedians have long since moved from the borscht belt to rock concert halls. Linear descendants of the stand-up comedians of a previous generation have updated their routines with hip argot and casual reference to rock music and drugs, and transferred their acts onto the rock concert circuit.

More than 4,000 New Jersey commuters who daily ride Lincoln Transit Company buses between Atlantic City and New York and intermediate points were forced by a strike to find other means of transportation yesterday.

Without an "R", Ranger spells, "anger," and 18 angry New Yorkers played the Flyers into submission, winning 3-1, at the Spectrum, where they hadn't won since the 1972-73 season.

The issue is heightened by Iran's position as a leading member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries whose enormous increase in wealth results from their monopolistic action in quadrupling the price of oil.

HONG KONG, Feb. 6 The epicenter of a major earthquake that hit Manchuria this week was in one of China's most important industrial districts and only 35 miles from the country's leading iron and steel center, according to a dispatch today from Hsinhua, the official press agency.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 6 Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister for Petroleum, said today that his nation remained strongly opposed to a further increase in oil prices.
HARTFORD, Feb. 6 An oil painting by Thomas Gainesborough was cut from its frame and stolen from the Wadsworth Atheneum here this afternoon.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon A commodity cartel on the lines of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is being formed here the yet unnamed inter-African organization for cooperation in timber trade and forestry conservation.
LONDON, Feb. 6 Buckingham Palace announced today that Queen Elizabeth had abandoned a $600,000 project to modernize Sandringham House, the mansion on her privately owned estate in Norfolk.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose yesterday in increased trading.

The trouble with Senator Scoop Jackson, who has just entered the Presidential race, is that his name is misleading. In newspaper terms, "scoop" means being ahead of events, but Mr. Jackson somehow always seems to be more than a little behind.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Denouncing the impact of the Civil Aeronautics Board as "inequitable, inefficient and uneconomical," the Ford Administration said today that it would introduce legislation aimed at substantially reducing the power of the board to regulate the airline industry.

Egypt has received four shiploads of ammunition and spare parts from the Soviet Union in the last month but, according to highlY qualified Israeli sources, any decision to supply heavier military equipment has been made conditional on a return of Soviet military advisers and instructors to Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today the Administration was unduly pessimistic in predicting two years of high unemployment and inflation.

REHOVOT, Israel, Feb. 6 The hardline views of the Israeli right the "hawks" are being articulated these days from a fourth-floor penthouse in this quiet, tree-lined Tel Aviv suburb.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) One out of three Senate and House candidates who received campaign donations from dairy cooperatives last year lost the election, the latest campaign finance reports show.
Ruth Matteson, an actress whose roles ranged from musical comedy to serious drama, died Wednesday. She was 65 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP) An Atlanta-based company, the North American Acceptance Corporation, and two other companies were charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with fraud in a petition filed in Federal court here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, tried to persuade McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, to withdraw funding from a public-interest law firm that had sued to block Occidental's drilling on the California coast in 'West Los Angeles, documents before the California Supreme Court show.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Astronomers have discovered evidence of water in the atmosphere of giant Jupiter, a major advancement in learning whether the solar system's largest planet can support some form of life.

PARIS, Jan 28 The French Government has judged "acceptable" a plan put forward by a French-Belgian group to operate the key company in the French nuclear power program apparently ending a bitter proxy figit.

HACKENSACK, Feb. 7 Appellate Judge Theodore I. Botter delayed today for a maximum period of three weeks implementation of a lowercourt order closing the Overpeck Creek sanitary landfill used by 26 Bergen County communities.
LISBON, Feb. 7 Several thousand workers went into the streets tonight to protest rising unemployment, defying a Government ban on demonstrations.
John C. Sawhill, President Ford's former chief energy adviser, joined other critics of the President's enemy program yesterday and supported a 90-day suspension of oil import fees.
The Senate Subcommittee on Long-Term Care issued a subpoena yesterday calling on Bernard Bergman to appear at a hearing in Washington on Feb. 19.
A total of 1,724 city employes have been dismissed outright from among the 11,985 Mayor Beame has ordered off the payroll since November.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 Shortly after Pennsylvania trounced Columbia, 113-69, at the Palestra tonight, Chuck Daly, the Quakers' coach, said, "They just didn't have any size inside against us. So in our place it made it a relatively easy game."

BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Billy Cunningham led a Philadelphia outburst early in the second half and the 76ers held on for a 98-95 victory over Boston tonight, snapping the Celtics' 11-game winning streak in the National Basketball Association.

NEW YORK, Feb. 7 (AP) Two Soviet astronauts who will join American astronauts in the first United States-Soviet Union space venture July 15 arrived at Kennedy Airport from Paris today with little fanfare.

In an unusual move yesterday, CBS-TV replaced the scheduled premiere episode of "Khan!," a TV series about a San Francisco detective, with a substitute episode. The original episode had drawn poor response from several critics.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had renegotiated its licensing agreement for the Wankel rotary engine, giving it an option to pay for the rights over a longer period of time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 R. Buckminister Fuller, the scientist who is best known for his investion of the geodesic dome, is also a boating enthusiast. This week he was granted a patent for a folatable breakwater. Patent 3,863,455 describes the breakwater as a flex- ible tubular envelope through whose open ends the water flows. A number of circular rubber tubes inside support the envelope and can move with relation to one another.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News, two of the city's three daily newspapers, suspended publication indefinitely today after truck drivers refused to deliver the papers yesterday and again today despite an injunction ordering them back to work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 In an effort to shape energy and fiscal alternatives to the Administration's proposals, a committee of senior Democratic Senators is studying a staff outline of a plan that would assign first priority to a reduction of unemployment.
David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had an optimistic report yesterday on the chances of saving transit and commuter fares "through this year."

The Italian state-owned oil company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, has signed three contracts with the Soviet Union to construct fertilizer plants worth more than $160million, E.N.I. announced in Rome yesterday. Two of the plants will be at Togliattigrad on the Upper Volga River and the third will be near Moscow.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7 A Hungarian sociologist who was arrested by the security police in Budapest last November and then "invited" to go into exile abroad has protested to Hungarian authorities that they have not kept their word to allow him to leave.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Ford, described as "concerned" about the sharp increase in unemployment last month, "will keep close watch on the economic situation and will not hesitate to take further action" if the economy worsens more than expected, his spokesman said today.

In the second in its series of reports, the State Charter Revision Commission has moved cautiously toward the controversial nub of the problem posed by its mandate to make New York City's government more responsive to the needs of its citizens. The question is how if at all to redistribute power between a now dominant City Hall and the dissatisfied boroughs and local communities.

Justice Joseph A. Martinis of the State Supreme Court sentenced a 40-year-old former convict yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a young woman, but indicated he would have sentenced him to death if the law permitted.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 (AP) The Government of Turkey has warned the Mobil Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., that it will revoke their refining licenses within three months unless the companies resume importing crude oil into Turkey, company officials said today.

Now comes a reminder of the turbulent late nineteen-sixties: Carefullytimed explosions are detonated in Manhattan, linked this time to groups favoring independence for Puerto Rico. Four persons are killed in a restaurant blast in the financial district.
JEFFERSONVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) Former State Supreme Court Justice William Deckelman died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 81 years old and lived here.

PARIS, Feb. 7 The 18 countries of the International Energy Agency agreed here today that measures must be taken to protect the search for new sources of fuel, to cut back dependence on Arab oil and eventually force down the price.
Jai-alai fans in this area don't have much longer to wait before they can start betting close to home.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 The chairmen of the Legislature's two health committees are sponsoring a bill that would establish a uniform schedule of Medicaid payments for nursing homes.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 The Drug Enforcement Administration absolved today National Football League players of charges they were supplied narcotics by a drug ring.
Felicia Sanders, the nightclub singer, died of cancer yesterday at her home, 845 West End Avenue. She was 53 years old.
Reported homicides in the city declined by 7.5 per cent last year compared with 1973, but all other categories of reported serious crime continued to increase, the Police Department said yesterday.
George Best, the temperamental soccer star with the lifestyle of a movie idol, advised the New York Cosmos through his attorney yesterday that he wouldn't be in New York this weekend as planned.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 American farmers who have been fattening cattle, hogs and poultry with corn and soybeans are now cutting back on their feeding operations more sharply than in any Period since the nineteen-fifties.
TRENTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The state's second highest court ruled today that developers could construct five high-rise apartment houses in Ocean City, Cape May County.

In a move to cut costs and improve customer service, Edwards Hanly, the brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had completed arrangements to have retail customer orders processed through back-office facilities of Shields Model Roland, Inc., effective about April 1.

FARMINGVILLE, L.I., Feb. 7 Mary Ann Asimake checked to make sure her boots and bindings were fastened properly, took a deep breath of the sharp night air and moved down the novice slope on her skis, twisting and turning, sending clouds of powder snow spraying behind her.

The Fire Department has stated its opposition to plans to ship liquified natural gas by barge through New York Harbor, declaring that high risks to human safety were involved, spokesman for the city administration said last night.

TORONTO, Feb. 7 (UPI) The heads of two major oil companies, bolstered by $600-million in Government money to save the Syncrude oil sands project, admitted today they could not guarantee they would not need an extra $1-billion in the future to keep the program alive.

LOS ANGELES With Golda Meir retired and Israel's leadership transferred from "founders" to "sons," with the "sons" now responsible for coming to terms with the Arabs, and with Henry A. Kissinger abain involved in another round of Middle East diplomacy, this would seem the moment to remind Americans of the little-known conditions for that peace laid down before he died by the greatest founder of them all David Ben-Gurion.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 7 Calm returned to this city after two days of rioting and looting that left about 100 people dead, according to the Peruvian military Government's estimates.

The defense in the obscenity trial of the movie "The Life and Times of a Happy Hooker" entered a poll into evidence yesterday that purported to show the attitudes of New Yorkers toward sexually explicit films.

"The house is big today," said Thomas P.F. Hoving, appreciatively auditing the distant roar of the crowd the other day from his director's office at the Metropolitan Museum, "I can tell by the decibel count."

"The Ramayana," the epic of India, has finally opened in New York at the BarbizonPlaza Theater, after a halfdozen years of working out in New Delhi, the Fiji Islands, Britain and college campuses across America.
Reuben Jay Cole, a jazz pianist and younger brother of the drummer Cozy Cole, died Tuesday at United Hospital in Newark. He was about 60 years old.
George Balanchine's threeact ballet version of "Don Quixote" for the New York City Ballet has never had the popular success of the company's other full-evening productions.

Based on the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" on Thursday night, it could be said that the company's new production of the work is so sumptuous it is becoming to anyone involved in it.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 Saigon's leading political cartoonist, who pilloried Government figures and the Communists with equal vigor, has been arrested, well-placed sources reported today.

While many people deplore the heavy-handed Teamster raids on California vineyards once under the jurisdiction of Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers, an argument is now being made by some that Teamster control may prove best for the farm workers because the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is big, powerful, and above all, "efficient."

When the fates offer a choice between two lines of play, one of which is routine while the other is elegant, few can resist the elegant play when the percentages seem close. The temptation is especially strong when the player is also a writes, motivated, perhaps subconsciously, by the need to have a hand to write about.

The Lykes-Youngstown Corporation, engaged in steel production, shipping, oil and natural gas drilling equipment and supplies, reported yesterday a 226.4 per cent increase in fourth-quarter earnings and 232.4 per cent for all of last year. Sales and revenues showed modest gains by contrast.

LONDON, Feb. 7 A number of major European banking houses connected with prominent Jewish families have reportedly been excluded from a series of routine international financings in recent months because of pressure from Arab governments.
A $50,000 reward was offered yesterday for information leading to the capture and conviction of any of the persons responsible for the fatal bombing of the Fraunces Tavern annex on Jan. 24.

Federal investigators will urge major changes in the safety features of more than 1,050 railroad cars that serve Long Island, Westchester County and Connecticut commuters, Government transportation officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Over strenuous objections from within the military, the Defense Department has decided to eliminate the Government subsidies that have permitted military families to buy food in commissaries at a substantial discount.

The 35-cent transit fare may soon go the way of the Second Avenue subway unless Mayor Beame and Governor Carey act quickly to find new sources of operational support for the floundering Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday a reduction in its base lending rate to 9 per cent from 9 per cent, effective Monday. This action by the nation's second largest bank, followed by a similar move on the part of Marine Midland Bank, means that all major banks in the city now charge 9 per cent or lower on their prime rate the interest cost to their most creditworthy corporate customers.

Speculative buying helped spur silver futures prices on the Commodity Exchange again yesterday, with March delivery silver closing at $4.33 an ounce, up 9 cents. A week ago the same contract closed at $4.10 .
Reported homicides in the city declined by 7.5 per cent last year compared with 1973, but all other categories of reported serious crime continued to increase, the Police Department said yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 7 An Onondaga County grand jury this afternoon cleared a lawyer, Frank H. Armani, of criminal wrongdoing in failing to disclose that his client in a murder case had told him where he had hidden two bodies.

A.M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The New York Times, announced yesterday the appointment of Henry R. Lieberman as an assistant to the managing editor. Mr. Lieberman's successor as director of science news will be John Noble Wilford, an assistant national editor.
Dr. Vivian J. Horn, assistant professor of English at Suffolk County Community College in Selden, L.I., died Wednesday in Setauket, L.I. Her age was 66.

In earlier times, symphonic programs held more or less to a pattern that is rarely found today. There would be a symphony, a concerto, a relatively new piece and then something colorful to provide a bang-up finale. This is what the New York Philharmonic offered in its generous concert Thursday night under the direction of Bernard Haitink.

Landlords of many of the 600,000 rent-stablized apartments in New York City were told yesterday that they could raise rents one-half of one percentage point more than previously allowed, when leases are renewed or when new tenants move in.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Ford, described as "concerned" about the sharp increase in unemployment last month, "will keep close watch on the economic situation and will not hesitate to take further action" if the economy worsens more than expected, his spokesman said today.

AI Young sends his heroine on an odyssey that spells out the gypsy's prediction, and juxtaposes some contrasts of possibility.

Heublein, Inc., famous for its Smirnoff vodka, registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission last Wednesday a $125-million offering that is expected to reach the public market later this month.

The major Swedish and French warplane makers are offering four Governments in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization financial inducements in an effort to head off the purchase by these countries of United States fighter aircraft.

Theodore Hughes of Fairfield, Iowa, became the bride of Philip Roger Carroll, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Carroll of Bridgeport and Milford, Conn.

College costs, especially on private campuses, will rise more sharply than ever next fall, with most colleges reporting tuition increases of more than 10 per cent, the highest singleyear increase so far.

One tenth of the native plant species in the continental United States and Alaska may not survive. In a list of about 2,000 species, subspecies and varieties, 100 kinds have become extinct, 761 are endangered and 1,238 are threatened. Of Hawaii's 2,200 higher plants, almost 50 per cent are in danger or already extinct.

The engagement of Claudia Neale to Jeffrey Brodlieb has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Neale of Mount Kisco, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Brodlieb of Hewlett Neck, L.I.

PARIS, Feb. 8 Raymond Cartier, co-director general of the magazine Paris-Match, died here today at the age of 70.

SOUTH ORANGE "Candy is dandy," the late Ogden Nash once quipped. And as Valentine's Day draws near, one candy man, Herman Gruning, is getting set for this week's buying onslaught at all of his stores. The main one is here, at the front end of his large candy and ice cream plant at 59 South Orange Avenue.

WASHINGTON The inflation of the last two years has achieved what the Pentagon's Congressional critics never could do: It has reduced the nation's defense program. But the budget proposed by President Ford last week does far more than merely make up for the erosion caused by inflation. It calls on Congress to approve the first step toward a gradually increasing investment in the defense establishment over the next five years.

TRENTON More than 70 per cent of all traffic lights and about 40 per cent of all traffic signs in New Jersey fail to meet Federal standards and are therefore,"illegal," according to Robert J. Nolan, head of the state's Bureau of Traffic Engineering.

HIALEAH, Fla., Feb. 8 Four years ago Gene St. Leon won the Eclipse award as America's best apprentice rider. Since then he has had only modest success, and with Hialeah reaching its midpoint today, he had not won a race at the meeting.

A panel of management specialists said yesterday that the city's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council had not been fulfilling its role and recommended that Mayor Beame appoint a fourth Deputy Mayor to deal with criminal justice matters.

Following "tremendous pressure" from the construction industry, the Beame administration announced yesterday that it would release from its citywide capital budget freeze $18-million worth of construction work this year on projects in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 Dr. Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles, announced today that he had arranged a six-month exchange of art works that will include 30 classic paintings from the Hermitage Museum in Leninggrad.

AMERICAN HEROINE: The Life and Legend of Jane Addams, by Allen F. Davis. (Oxford, $3.95.) She wasn't just a respectable reformer of the pre-World War I era; this scholarly study reveals Hull House's founder as a dissenter and quite real woman.

Some female fireflies are able to mimic the illuminated mating signals of other species of fireflies, luring would-be suitors into what quickly becomes a deadly embrace, a Florida biologist has found.
JERSEY CITY Plans by the Colgate-Palmolive Company to fence in its industrial plant in the Paulus Hook area have stirred a controversy that is pitting homeowners against the company.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Manes of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Elizabeth Manes, to William Elton Larzelere Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Larzelere of Seneca Falls, N.Y.

BOWIE Md., Feb. 8 Gala Double came along on the outside in the stretch to win the $33,050 Vertex Handicap today. Guided by Leroy Moyers, Gala Double carried the silks of Gertrude Leviton to a 1 -length triumph in the 1 1/16-mile event for Maryland breds. The Food and Drug Administration, after discounting for almost two years the contention of a California pediatrician that hyperactivity and learning disability in children can be triggered by artificial food flavors and colors, is now helping to test the validity of his research.

Chocolate lovers are running into double-barreled price increases as they shop for Valentine's Day this year some 20 per cent at one New York candy store. A one-pound box of assorted chocolates costs $3.95, up from $3.25 a year ago; a pound of pure Swiss milk chocolate sells for $3.50, up from $2.95.

Admittedly, a good part of the stage action centers on revivals, but all in all this is surely the most fruitful season for actresses in a long time.

THE scent of musk and ambergris fills the air. Dark blue Turkish tiles cover the walls of the long room. The women of the harem in their silk and velvet costumes lounge on couches, the blindfolded musicians on the balcony stroke the strings of their dulcimers and beneath the baldequin, diamonds glinting in his turban, golden chalice raised to his lips, the sultan sits upon his throne.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Brig. Gen. Francis Rusher Kerr, assistant administrator of the veterans Administration during the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations, died today at the Naval Hospital in Newport, R.I. His age was 85 and he lived at Derrydown in Middleton, R.I.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Pacific 21, a bicentennial exhibition and conference center in Los Angeles, will open June 19, 1976, as a major West Coast focal point for the nation's 200th birthday celebration, sponsors have announced.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 8 A man was shot dead and his wife wounded at their front door today in Belfast and seven persons were injured in a bomb attack in a book store.

The circumstance: Our house had burned down, leaving us shiver ing in a bleak Catskill dawn, divested of all worldly possessions save ourselves and child, a middle-aged hound and two used typewriters. We needed to go somewhere fast, somewhere that was warm, cheap, English-speaking, accessible to an ancient Saab and amenable to dogs.
