The accomplishments of the Pioneer unmanned space ex plorations, which made scientific history and opened new vistas in man's knowledge of his universe, are acclaimed by the United States in a new commemorative to be issued at the end of this month.

The engagement of Robin Fields Kirk to Richard King Lintern, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Lintern of Kirtland Hills, Ohio, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Kirk of Orford, N.H. A spring wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON To many Americans, one of the most disturbing aspects of the impeachment proceedings against President Nixon was the disclosure of Mr. Nixon's misuse of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for his personal aims and political ambitions. The evidence is of a program of wiretaps and other abuses carried out with the far from reluctant cooperation of the bureau's late director, J. Edgar Hoover.

A State Supreme Court justice in Brocklyn has ruled that two sections of the election law dealing with the nomination of statewide candidates are unconstitutional and has directed the State Legiislature to amend the law.

PARAMUS, Feb. 9 Andrew Maguire, the freshman Representative from New Jersey's seventh Congressional District, met here today with more than 700 of his constituents in an open exchange of questions, answers and ideas dealing with the current economic and power crises.
TRENTON The number of new homes authorized for construction in New Jersey last year plunged to half of the 1973 total, a 25-year low.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 "The liberals can't find a horse," said Anne Wexler Duffey, a prominent Democratic organizer, "and when they can't find a horse they feel insecure."

ROME, Feb. 9 A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization has stated that the leader of guerrillas who attacked a United States airliner at Rome's airport in December, 1973, has been "executed," the Italian Communist newspaper, L'Unita reported today.
The deepening recession is taking a heavy toll of the nation's black-owned businesses.
Frank Richard Perls, an internationally known art dealer, died Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif., where he had his art gallery. He was 64 years old and underwent open heart surgery last Dec. 19.

In the field of energy, there is no equivalent on Capitol Hill to the traditional tax-writing committees or the newly formed budget committees. The defeat in the House last year of the committee reorganization plan urged by Representative Richard Bolling, Missouri Democrat, deprives the House of a unified committee on energy. Responsibility in the Senate likewise remains fragmented among a half-dozen rival committees.
"I love to be at a performance where I don't have to play the piano," said Arthur Rubinstein to an admiring crowd.

BOSTON, Feb. 9?His Bruin teammates have been calling him Jailbird in a blundering attempt to help him make light of his troubles. But Dave Forbes says it will take a little longer than he expected to get back in shape, physically and especially psychologically, after a 10-game suspension.

A handful of landlords in Brooklyn are responsible for a disproportionate number of complaints from tenants, housing inspectors and community leaders about poorlyrun apartment houses, city records show.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 9?Rabbi Baruch Korff said today that former President Richard M. Nixon, in view of his poor "physical and emotional health," had no intention at present of seeking either Republican party chores or foreign policy assignments.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9 The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., Yale University's chaplain for 17 years, announced today that he was resigning next year to seek a change and new challenges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The Administration intervened last week in a labor-management situation for the first time since wage-price controls lapsed nine months ago.

A 65-year-old dentist from Newburgh, N.Y., was shot and killed by two holdup men here yesterday afternoon as he walked to a neighborhood drug store to pick up medicine for his invalid mother-in-law in the Williamsburg section of Brook lyn.

President Ford is embarked on an aggressive, high-risk strategy when he goes around accusing the new Congress of doing "basically nothing" about the nation's urgent problems. His criticism is unwarranted by the facts up to now, but an element of justification might appear if certain institutional shortcomings are not resolved more fully in the weeks ahead.
Dr. Rena L. Foy, professor of education at Bowling Green State University in Ohio, died Friday in the Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus. She was 45 years old.

Dorothy Laphan Ferris, an artist and the widow of Hugh Ferriss, architect and painter, died last Friday in Amherst, Mass., while visiting her daughter. She was in her 80's and resided until two years ago at 35 East 9th Street.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 9 Republican state leaders cheered former Gov. Ronald Reagan, scoffed at third-party talk and laid plans for a comeback at their biennial state convention, which ended today.

A fine new work for unaccompanied violin was given its first New York performance on Saturday night by Zvi Zeitlin in his recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall. It was George Rochbergs's "Caprice Variations," and it consisted of 22 variations separated into two groups of 11 each by a "quasi cadenza."

Some 800 delegates contributed more than $1.5-million yesterday to the National Committee for Labor Israel that will he used by Histradrut, Israel's labor federation, to carry out its program of health, educational and social-welfare services among workers and new immigrants.
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 9 The battle for control of the Mekong River is becoming the battle for the survival of Phnom Penh.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate committee in testimony released today that there was "no doubt" in 1970 that the Nixon Administration wanted to have President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile overthrown.

Just as we're beginning to get used to the big, voluminous look in fashion, European designers are getting ready for the next step. Enrica Sanlorenzo shows what that's going to be with her knitwear collection for next fall and winter.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 9 Turkey will probably order the closing of some United States military installations here if Congress does not restore military aid to Ankara soon, according to diplomatic and Government sources here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Secretary of State Kissinger left for the Middle East tonight on an exploratory mission that he hoped would lead to a further interim agreement between Israel and Egypt next month.

The distribution of ash layers in sea floor Sediment extracted from deep holes at 84 sites scattered across the world's oceans has shown that of the periods of global eruptions in the last 20 million years the greatest period coincided with the ice ages of the last two million years.
China has enhanced her growing role as a petroleum exporter by completing her first large-diameter pipeline from Manchurian oilfields to a tanker terminal on the Yellow Sea.
Walter Rydd, an industrial nurse in the medical department of The New York Times, died yesterday afternoon at his home. He was 63 years old and lived at 218 Broad Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (Reuters) Governors of the Western worlds's main central banks will review recent support operations to store up the dollar when they open a twoday meeting tomorrow at the Bank for International settlements.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 9 Thomas F. Olmsted, director of the United States economic aid program in Cambodia, died last night in Thailand in a Bangkok hospital, where he was rushed a week ago after a sudden attack of pancreatitis. He was 45 years old.
BOSTON, Feb. 9 Steamrollered the last time they visited the Bruins' yellow ice, the Islanders were flattened again tonight, 5-1, before a crowd of 14,519.

OSLO, Feb. 9 (AP) Harm Kuipers returned the world speed skating title to the Netherlands today for the first time since Ard Schenk, the Olympic champion, turned professional in 1972. Schenk had taken three straight world titles.

One of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's better ideas was its rediscovery after a lapse of many years of the Limited Stop Bus. For many New Yorkers tired of traveling to and from work at the normal stopand-start snail's pace, this particular reinvention of wheels that move was a welcome indication that somebody at the M.T.A. thinks and cares.
It looks as if New York may well turn out to be a battleground for the country's two major cigarette companies seeking dominance in the new super-length field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Two Senators called today for a Congressional investigation of a Defense Department contract with a private firm to train Saudi Arabian troops to guard oil wells in the Persian Gulf.

Inventory reductions continue to intensify the recession, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in its January report on business conditions. Fully 45 per cent of purchasing executives surveyed by the association are cutting their stocks of materials in contrast with only 9 per cent who were reducing their stocks last summer.

STAMFORD, N. Y., Feb. 9 The Temporary State Commission to Study the Catskills asked today for two more years to complete a detailed program to meet the main needs of the Catskill Mountains region a control of land use to protect the scenic beauty of the area and economic development to provide more jobs for local residents.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9 The Yale Corporation approved today a teaching appointment for H. Bruce Franklin, who was dismissed from a tenured position at Stanford University in 1972 for allegedly inciting violent student demonstrations.
CAMDEN, Feb. 9 (UPI) Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti returns to his office for the first time tomorrow since his acquittal of misconduct-conspiracy charges.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 9 (UPI) A ship's captain was dead, another man was hospitalized and a third was missing today following a weekend boating incident 400 yards offshore.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Origanizations, said today that the nation's unemployment rate may reach 10 per cent by July.

RIO DE JANEIRO Carnival has burst across Brazil, four days of dancing, drums and wild cries in the street before the austerity of Lent. Those who have never come south for the celebration may have seen "Black Orpheus," with its scenes of hillside slums favelas where Carnival compensated for a year of misery and despair.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 The twoman crew of the Soyuz 17 returned to earth today after spending 30 days in space, a record for Soviet astronauts.

Dr. Samuel H. Rubin, a professor of medicine at New York Medical College since 1965 and its executive dean since 1972, has been named dean of the medical college and vice president for academic affairs.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 For the second time in 24 hours, the New York Knicks today were on the receiving end of a thrashing from the Boston Celtics, the defending National Basketball Association champions who, after some early season problems that included the loss of Dave Cowens for 17 games, seem to be rolling in championship form again.

BONN, Feb. 9 A mason who lost his job three weeks ago sat in a restaurant bedecked with balloons in Plittersdorf and said: "I'm not even going to start looking for another job until Karneval's over. Nobody ever works then, anyhow, so it doesn't feel any different for me."
With the opening of the 99th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madi son Square Garden this morning, New York becomes the dog capital of the world for two days.

The corporate bond market, riding on the crest of heavy demand and rising prices, faces a relatively light calendar this week because of the Lincoln's Birthday observance on Wednesday. Spurred initially by the FedCredit eral Reserve's push Markets to lower interest rates, the rifle in corporate bonds now bears all the signs of a classic rally. The top-grade issues responded first, with January's offerings of $3.6-billion in straight corporate debt snapped up by purchasers.

Russell K. Branscom, who retired at the end of 1969 as a director and vice president for industrial and public relations of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, died Thursday in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON Tom Downey, at 26 years old the youngest member of Congress, was dining with his parents at a Capitol Hill restaurant last week when he caught the eye of a young woman dining alone at a nearby table.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 9 An attack by Iraqi forces on Iranian frontier posts has been repelled, the Iranian press agency said today.

There were snowflakes yesterday, meaningless snowflakes that promised neither a great blizzard, nor the death of winter, although the thing about the weather in New York is that the citizens always assume that somehow it will get worse. Snowflakes on Sunday are mostly pleasant because you don't have to go out in them. Everyone expected Monday to be a mess.

Vincent C. Papa, reputedly one of the city's major drug dealers, was convicted by a Federal jury yesterday of conspiracy to distribute narcotics and possession of 160 pounds of heroin. His son was acquitted on the consphacy charge, and the jury could not reach a verdict on a third defendant, Peter Giamarino.

BERKELEY, Calif. Civilian police review boards, those watchdogs of the police produced by the urban strife of the nineteen-sixties, have faded from public attention and drifted into general ineffectiveness.
DUBLIN, Feb. 9 The I.R.A. Provisionals announced tonight an open-ended renewal of their cease-fire in Northern Ireland and Britain.

Near the beginning of "Here at The New Yorker," Brendan Gill describes very accurately what his 50th-birthday present to the magazine might well have been. "My intention," he writes, "is to follow the principle upon which the 'Talk of the Town' department of the magazine is based: I will try to cram these paragraphs full of facts and give them a weight and shape no greater than that of a cloud of blue butterflies."

An 84-year-old widow who lives alone in a Bronx apartment has sent six $1 bills from her weekly budget to the six children of Frank J. Walker, who was killed when he tried to aid a seriously wounded police officer.

In one miniature amphitheater called a pit, in the American Museum of Natural History's People Center, there is a demonstration and talk on African influences in Puerto Rico. In another pit a lecture on Haitian history ends and one on how the English language puts down blacks begins.
One of the most important sections of the Truth in Lending Act is a 1970 amendment limiting the liability of credit card holders to $50 for unauthorized use.

The Citizens Union and the City Club, two of the oldest nonpartisan civic organizations here, called yesterday for revising the state laws on campaign financing to reduce contributions and spending and harden the provisions for en forcement.

Susan Hardy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hardy of New York and Durham, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Ralph Porter Suechting of Troy, Mont., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Suechting of Neenah, Wis. The Rev. Robert K. Fell of the United Church of Durham performed the ceremony at the Hardy's Durham home.
The decline in the economy has apparently inspired an increase in sharp practices in the marketplace.

The first two reports of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City have disclosed a split in the commission that, some politicians say, could jeopar dize the proposed new City Charter when it goes before the electorate in November.
SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Feb. 9 A local tournament with an unusual international flavor ended here last night, with United States competitors taking the Swiss teams laurels.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (UPI) Quintuplets, three boys and two girls, were born today to a 27year-old woman who had been taking fertility drugs.

Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would have "no choice" but to lay off more than 500 police rookies and recruits if the rank and file of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association rejected a plan to save their jobs that bad been agreed to by union leaders.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) A Wisconsin car dealer paid $141,000 today for Adolf Hitler's sleek black parade car, but the price was $35,000 below what the seller said he paid for the car a year ago.

Bravos may abound and justifiably when the Lenin Prize winner Ludmila Zykina takes the stage, but credit must also go to the cohesiveness of the 13-piece Moscow Balalaika Orchestra, which provides the sometimes fragile, sometimes tough backgrounds to her Russian folk songs. So it was at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon with Miss Zykina, something of an institution on the Soviet folk scene, on another American tour.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 9 Despite a 22-point halftime lead that led to a 11790 triumph, the New York Nets opened the third quarter with their starting five against the Virginia Squires today. Kevin Loughery, the Nets' coach, was not particularly pleased with his team's first-half performance against the worst team in the American Basketball Association.

BUFFALO, Feb. 9 (UPI) Two goals each by Guy Lafleur of Montreal, and Richard Martin of Buffalo brought the Canadiens and Sabres to a 4-4 tie today in a nationally televised National Hockey League game.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 The twoman crew of the Soyuz 17 returned to earth today after spending 30 days in space, a record for Soviet astronauts.
LISBON, Feb. 9 Portugal is drifting in a sea of suspicion, fear and intolerance nine months after the military overthrew an essentially fascist regime and set the country on a democratic course.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) Raul Ramirez, Mexico's No. 1 player, scored his first triumph on the World Championship Tennis tour today by beating Roscoe Tanner in the final of a $60,000 tournament, 6-0. 1-6, 6-2. It was a duplication of his recent Davis Cup victory over the American.
ROME, Feb, 9--Talks between the Vatican and the Italian Government on revision of the Concordat of 1929--a treaty regulating church-state relations are expected to start this week.

It will be of more interest, perhaps, to those who write about food rather than those who like to read about it to learn the name of the first newspaper food columnist as well as the meal served to inaugurate the institution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that the nation's unemployment rate may reach 10 per cent by July.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) The Senate acted last year to turn a minor bill helping the upholstery industry into a benefit reportedly worth $800,000 to the 1972 Presidential candidates, Richard M. Nixon and George McGovern, according to a news account.

Twice in less than a year Asmara, capital of the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea, has played a key role in the suddenly greatly increased tempo of change in a country that once seemed almost changeless. It was in Asmara late last February that the military mutiny first broke out, a mutiny that led to the downfall of Emperor Haile Selassie and produced an almost clandestine provisional military government which has promised revolutionary socio-economic changes.
United States copper companies, squeezed by rising inventories and tumbling prices, are curtailing mine and smelter operations and laying off thousands of workers.

GRESHAM, Wis. The peaceful ending last week to a volatile, potentially blood occupation by armed Indians of a vacant religious facility came about in large measure, observers here believe, because of the presence of the Wisconsin National Guard under the command of a colonel who practiced tact and restraint.
It took two hours before Ch. Tirvelda Distant Drummet was selected as the best Irish setter last night at the Combined Setters Club of America show at the Statler Hilton.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9--Orson Welles, the film maker and actor who remains one of Hollywood's most enigmatic personalities, received tonight the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Feb. 7 Things have changed at the Hamburg Staatsoper. A few years ago, when Rolf Liebermann was running the house, a visitor to the opera had a good chance of encountering an avant-garde work by Penderecki, Tal or Kagel, or a 20th-century stage work by Stravinsky, Krenek, Klebe, Henze and a dozen or so others.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) Fred Carter and LeRoy Ellis scored 27 points each to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 109-97 National Basketball Association victory over the Chicago Bulls today.
John H. Secondari, a dominant figure in the field of the television documentary, died Saturday of a heart attack in Memorial Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 1148 Fifth Avenue.

ROME, Feb. 9 Pope Paul VI today officiated at the beatification of Marie Eugene Milleret, a 19th-century French educator and nun who founded the order of the Sisters of the Assumption.

The head of the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy urged the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday to cut off Federal payments to nursing homes that did not remove "substantive violations" within three months.

It's one job that has no coffee break. The men who do it really love coffee, but they never swallow a drop on duty. They can be poker-faced and demanding, but unlike El Exigente, they have never, as far as they know, inspired fiesta or revolution.
SEATTLE, Feb. 9 (UPI) Seattle SuperSonics' coach Bill Russell, the former Boston Celtics' star who was elected to the National Basketball Hall of Fame yesterday, said today he would refuse induction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Eighty-two members of Congress asked President Ford today for a dialogue on phasing out all United States aid to South Vietnam and Cambodia.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 (AP) None of the 10 Federal District Court judges in New Jersey received income in 1974 for extrajudicial services, such as speechmaking or lectures, according to financial statements they have filed.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9 The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., Yale University's chaplain for 17 years, announced today that he was resigning next year to seek a change and new challenges.

Renee Payson, a teacher in the Central Synagogue's Nursery School, was married yesterday noon to Rabbi Mark Jay Panoff, the synagogue's assistant rabbi. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, the senior rabbi, performed the ceremony in the synagogue's sanctuary. He was assisted by Rabbi David J. Seligson, rabbi emeritus, Rabbi Harvey J. Fields, and Cantor Richard Botton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 A Congressional economic survey made public today has found that higher tax payments outstripped all other price increases in the 1974 consumer budget and that this rise had a greater impact on low-income and middle-income taxpayers than on the wealthy.
Business kickbacks, bribes and embezzlements axe on the rise and the consumer is paying for them, according to Herbert Robinson, a prominent New York lawyer.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. and former Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan are among the witnesses scheduled to be called next week by a state commission trying to unravel a 15-year-old mystery: What happened to the Kaplan report?

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9 Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, has reeived a letter from Mr. and Mrs. Robert Colbert of Philadelphia saying that they had named their 2-month-old son Yasir Arafat Colbert:

THURMONT, Md., Feb. 9 (UPI) President Ford completed a weekend of relaxation and paperwork at Camp David today in preparation for another round of traveling, public meetings and private appearances on behalf of his economic recovery proposals.

When George Balanchine's spectacular "Don Quixote" was new, nearly 10 years ago now, much could be forgiven it. For one thing it represented New York City Ballet's emergence as a great national ballet in its own splendid, and then new, theater, the New York State Theater. "Don Quixote" was almost a symbol of necessary grandeur.

DALLAS, Feb. 6 If you are fond of tender, juicy, grain-fed beef, you'll find that it will still be available in the coming months, despite the recession and a financially painful year for cattle feeders.
An American agreement to sell six desroyers to Iran for an amount estimated at $700million or more brought a move yesterday to block the transaction.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 9 Rhett Colby, an 11year-old Lake Placid athlete, won the junior Division 4 championships in the New York State cross-country and ski jumping tournaments today. He covered the four kilometers cross-country course in 14 minutes 35 seconds and came back to win the jumping championship with two jumps of 63 feet fog 119.1 points.

BERKELEY, Calif. Civilian police review boards, those watchdogs of the police produced by the urban strife of the nineteen-sixties, have faded from public attention and drifted into general ineffectiveness.

WASHINGTON Tom Downey, at 26 years old the youngest member of Congress, was dining with his parents at a Capitol Hill restaurant last week when he caught the eye of a young woman dining alone at a nearby table.
Agnes Moe Culver, president of Culver Pictures Inc., here, died yesterday in White Plains (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 1 Lynwood Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.
NICOSIA, Cyprus The Turkish Arms rules northern Cyprus with a strong hand, raising doubts even among Turkish Cypriotes about its willingness to yield territory or control.

NAPLES. Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) Sandra Haynie sank a 14foot par putt on the final hole today and her two closest competitors missed birdies to give Miss Haynie a $5,700 victory in the Naples Lely tournament of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 9 The battle for control of the Mekong River is becoming the battle for the survival of Phnom Penh.

NEW HAVEN The Government is suing to break up the long-distance telephone network of the United States, and to divorce the Bell System's manufacturing unit, and perhaps even Bell Laboratories, from its operating companies.

The long-awaited meeting of the two top-winning wire fox terriers in America took place yesterday at the 102d Engineers Army, with Ch. Sunnybrook Spot On defeating his son, Ch. Aryee Dominator.
Following are excerpts from a report on nursing homes submitted to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner by his Investigation Commissioner, Louis I. Kaplan, on April 6, 1960.
For the 11th successive year, Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times has been honored by the Dog Writers' Association of America.
LONDON, Feb. 9 Sir Robert Robinson, who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1947 died yesterday at his home in Great Missenden, 30 miles northwest of here. He was 88 years old.
EDISON TOWNSHIP, Feb. 9 About 125 residents attended wreath-laying ceremonies here today commemorating the 128th birthday Tuesday of Thomas Alva Edison.

Steadily increasing numbers of non-Hispanic whites have joined the city's welfare rolls in recent years and, by various informal estimates, now constitute 13 or 14 per cent of all welfare recipients here.

BONN, Feb. 9 The purchase of the Foster-Grant Plastics Company in December by the giant Hoechst Chemical Company marks a turning point but by no means an end to the expansion of German companies in the United States, according to officials of chemical concerns.

NBC Radio announced yesterday plans to begin a 24hour-a-day national news service, separate from the NBC radio network, that would package an all-news format for local stations around the country, using the resources of NBC News.
LONG TRACH, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 The farmers here have never heard of protecting the ecology. But they have stopped using American insecticides to kill the worms in their rice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Secretary of State Kissinger left for the Middle East tonight on an exploratory mission that he hoped would lead to a further interim agreement between Israel and Egypt next month.

TULTEPEC, Mexico, Feb. 91 (AP) An overloaded bus was struck by a freight train that it apparently tried to beat at a crossing at this town 17 miles north of Mexico City last night. Twenty-nine people aboard the bus were killed and 28 injured.

Bob Sylvester, entertainment columnist for The Daily News, where since 1951 he had written "Dream Street," died early yesterday of a heart ailment at his home. Mr. Sylvester, who became 68 years old last Friday, lived at Old Montauk Highway, Montauk. L.I.
WASHINGTON A Communist rocket, fired with the intent of killing civilians in the capital of Cambodia, exploded in a school and slaughtered a score of children.

ROME, Feb. 9 Judicial authorities have opened an inquiry into allegations that Michele Sindona, the Sicilianborn financier who for some time controlled the Franklin National Bank, bribed Italian politicians to obtain illegal favors, Milan court sources said today.

For 58 seconds last night the New York Rangers outplayed the Washington Capitals. Three goals in that short stretch broke a 2-2 tie and helped New York go on to post a 7-3 victory over a team that has won but four games in its brief National Hockey League history.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9 It was never in doubt, Johnny Miller, the 27-yearold superman of the pro golf tour, easily won the Bob Hope Desert Classic today by a margin of three strokes.
Robert Carter Nicholas, a lawyer here for 40 years, died Friday at the Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington, N.J. He was 66 years told and lived in Oldwick, N.J.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP) Rabbi Korff said today that he did not attend a party given by Mr. Nixon last night for his departing staff.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 A recent study by Japan's increasingly vigorous Fair Trade Commission indicates that the concentration of economic power held by the so-called zaibatsu, or huge conglomerates, here is even greater than previously known.

Aldo Ciccolini first broke into international attention in the late nineteen-forties, when he won a spate of contests, and he made his New York debut in 1950. Since an appearance with the New York Philharmonic in 1957, however, the Italian pianist had not been back here until his Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday. It can be chalked up as a brilliantly successful return, even though an often puzzling one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A Federal judge has stopped the United States Park Service from proceeding with a controversial plan to accommodate millions of automobile-borne bicentennial visitors here next year at a fringe parking lot that has shuttle bus connections to the downtown area.

Warmed by the glow of official benevolence, national song and dance companies have flowered in the various regions of Poland. ANCHORAGE, Feb. 10 (AP) An executive of the catering company that prepared meals for 144 Japan Air Lines passengers who suffered food poisoning killed himself yesterday, the Anchorage police reported.

Muhammad Ali, who is scheduled to defend his world heavyweight championship against Chuck Wepner in Cleveland on March 24, said yesterday that from now on "all my fights are free. All the profits will be given away from both the live gates and closed-circuit television, I will keep only training expenses."

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10 Or dinarily, a passenger waiting for a streetcar on the St. Charles Avenue Trolley Line could expect to board one in five to 10 minutes, but this winter the wait has stretched to almost two months.

PARIS, Feb. 10 Yehudi Menuhin and the executive committee of the International Music Council, an affiliated body of UNESCO, have come out against any boycott of the organization because of its attitude toward Israel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A bipartisan group of eight former high Government officials who have directed the Social Security System over the years said today in a "white paper" that the system was in no financial danger and continued to be a sound investment for the workers who contribute to it.
NORTH NEW HYDE PARK, L.I. Feb. 10 Three men, two of them armed, escaped with gems reported worth more than $100,000 after locking a jewelry salesman in the trunk of his car this morning.

LONDON, Feb. 10 Arab efforts to exclude Jewish banking interests from financial deals on the international loan market have touched off a controversy in the London financial community over whether to oppose such moves with a united front.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 10 Secretary of State Kissinger began talks tonight with Israeli leaders in an effort to reconcile Egyptian and Israeli views on achieving a new interim agreement in the Sinai Peninsula.

TOKYO, Feb. 10-Foreign Minister Kiichi Miyazawa indicated to Parliament today that Japan, the only nation ever to experience an atomic attack, had again backed away from ratifying the treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.

"A Wedding in Shtetl" is an old-time Second Avenue Yiddish musical comedy done in exactly the same way that they have been turned out for generations. If you haven't been to one of these standard productions for a long while and for some reason miss them, you will find this production at the Eden Theater a rewarding trip backward.

MONTREAT, Feb. 10 (UPI) Members of the Montreal organizing committee for the 1976 Olympics begin talks with the International Olympic Committee tomorrow on problems facing the upcoming summer games.

Approximately $120,000 in nickels, dimes and quarters from the city's parking meters was stolen over the weekend, from a safe by burglars who apparently escaped with their three tons of loot in trucks that would have been used to move the money to the bank, the police said yesterday.

A note sale of $260-million under the New York City Stabilization Reserve Corporation that was scheduled for Thursday will be postponed because of a lawsuit, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 Iraq was reported today to be seeking a high-level meeting of Arab countries bordering on the Persian Gulf to seek support against Iranian military aid to Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq.

Harry A. Gair, a past president of the Metropolitan Trial Lawyers Association and of the Law-Science Academy of America, and senior partner in the law firm of Gair, Gair Conason died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 65 Central Park West.
CAMDEN, Feb. 10 Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti resumed his 9-to-5 schedule at City Hall today relieved at last from the tiring and trying routine of the last five weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The other day in the House Ways and Means Committee, one of the new Republican members, Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, proposed an amendment to the oil import fee bill that would have authorized gasoline rationing in case of a national emergency.

Dr. H. Leslie Wenger, an orthopedic surgeon who devised the spine-jack operation to correct a spinal curve known as scoliatic deformity, died of cancer Feb. 3 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old and lived at 123 West 197th Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) One of the Shaf quintuplets born yesterday died tonight, hospital authorities said.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 10 The nine members of the European Common Market were understood to have reached agreement today to seek tariff cuts of 25 to 50 per cent at the international trade liberalization talks that begin tomorrow in Geneva.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 A cease fire ordered by the Irish Republican Army went into effect at 6 P.M, today, but bombings and shooting incidents throughout the day left three persons dead.

Without agreement for restraint on both sides in the deployment of MIRV (multiple warhead) missiles, future efforts at meaningful cutbacks may be frustrated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A new surgical technique for female sterilization was described here today as offering greater safety and convenience than conventional methods for the woman who undergoes it.

ROME, Feb. 10 Gianfranco Spadaccia, national secretary of the Radical party, who was imprisoned four weeks ago on charges of being an accessory to the crime of abortion, was freed on his own recognizance today.
The International Paper Corporation appeared yesterday to have won the final battle for control of the General Crude Oil Company.

Item: A four-bedroom cooperative apartment on Park Avenue was put on the market recently and one prospective buyer estimated that it needed $70,000 to $100,000 in renovations to put it in good condition. The windows were loose. The electrical wiring was inadequate. The walls had not been painted in years and there was linoleum on the bedroom floor.

CAMERIDGE, Mass. Earthquakes are among mankind's most feared scourges. In a sense they represent the small price earthlings must pay to enjoy their beneficent environment, for it is the same internal heat energy that has provided us with atmosphere, oceans and mineral wealth that is the source of the stresses that periodically fracture the crust.

A West Highland white terrier, imported from England 16 months ago, came through with a sensational victory at Madison Square Garden last night as the 99th Westminster Kennel Club opened a two-day run.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) The General Motors Corporation's Cadillac division plans to begin production March 24 on a new compact luxury car scheduled for debut on May 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb 10 James J. Angleton, the former chief of counterintelligence for the Central Intelligence Agency, was the principal witness today at the fifth weekly meeting of the Presidential commission investigating alleged illegal domestic activity by the C.I.A.

BLUE BELL, Pa., Feb. 10 (UPI) The Philco-Ford Corporation announced today that it would recall more than 10,000 black and white nine-inch portable television sets because of a possible electric shock hazard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) One of the nation's largest food chains, A., has been ordered to stop advertising goods at a stated price unless the company insures that it has the advertised products to sell, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
ATLANTA, Feb. 10 The South, once the national pace setter for economic growth, appears to have been hit harder than any other region by the current recession, according to Federal Reserve economists.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 10 (AP) Scott May and Quinn Buckne led Indiana, the nation's top-ranked college basketball team, to a 69-54 Big Ten Conference victory over Minnesota tonight. A crowd of 17,637 fans watched.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 10 Black and white Rhodesian Leaders are preparing to meet again on Wednesday to try to arrange a new constitutional conference to settle the political future of this breakaway British colony.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) Some 19,000 production workers have struck McDonnell Douglas plants in Missouri and California in a wage dispute. Company officials say that jet fighter production will be halted if the strike is a long one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) A Pentagon spokesman, commenting today on a report that Americans were being recruited to train military forces in Saudi Arabia, stressed that similar services have been provided to Saudi Arabia before.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 (AP) Joel Kline, a bankrupt financial manipulator, testified today that he knew that an Annapolis banker, who is under Federal investigation, was the man to contact about "payoffs" to get loans from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 The Democratic majority in the State Senate decided today to readmit Senator Alene S. Ammond to its closed caucus, at the order of the Federal Court and on the advice of a special majority committee.

More than $100,000 in contributions have been tallied to date in a fund for the six orphaned children of Frank J. Walker, the hospital visitor who was killed as he went to the aid of a seriously wounded police officer.

Nassau and Suffolk Counties and five towns on Long Island filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to block the Federal Government's plans to sell or lease 10-million acres of offshore lands to oil companies this year.

Rapt attention is rare at fashion shows there's often music to distract you, friends to catch up with. But you could hear a pin drop at the showing of James Galanos's spring collection yesterday afternoon at the Plaza. Not that the designer would leave one carelessly in any of his dresses so it could fall out.

VIENNA, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Th North Atlantic alliance and the Soviet bloc faced a new impasse in troop-reduction negotiations today when the West rejected a Communist proposal for an immediate military manpower freeze in central Europe.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 13 (UPI) Yugoslavia expelled two American opera singers today for distributing Anti-Yugoslav leaflets, the press agency Tanjug reported.

Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary from 1945 until he retired in 1963 and a leading ecumenist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment at the Carrier Clinic in Belle Meade, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 Armour Road, Princeton, N.J.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 Under unusual security, a county grand jury has opened an investigation into a 1974 burglary of Howard R. Hughes' operation headquarters here.

The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association has approved the agreement that its president, John J. DeLury, worked out with Mayor Beame last month to avert the layoffs of 235 sanitationmen, Mr. DeLury said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-The White House announced today that President Ford would nominate a woman, Carla Anderson Hills, to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and the nomination immediately ran into opposition.

A trial jury in a Boston homicide case now faces the unenviable and perhaps impossible task of deciding just when human life begins in order to determine whether a doctor committed the homicide of which he is accused.
Charles D. Lawrence, a senior judge of the United States Customs Court, died Wednesday at his home, 69 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 96.
President Ford appealed to the Democratic-controlled Congress in a speech here last night for a return to "nonpartisanship" in setting the nation's foreign policy.

The Pritzker family of Chicago yesterday completed its take-over of the Cerro Corporation. Under a previously announced plan for transfer of executive authority, Jay A. Pritzker, 53, who had been vice chairman, was elected chairman, while his brother Robert A. Pritzker, 48, who was chairman of the executive committee, was chosen president.

Defense lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case yesterday accused Judge Samuel A. Larner of the New Jersey Superior Court of refusing to hear all vital evidence before he rejected an appeal for a new trial.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 13 Arizona's state Senate defeated today the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constiution, apparently assuring that the amendment would not her passed by the state Legislature this session.
A Brooklyn pizza-parlor owner has been accused of taking an order for a $5,000 murder "contract" and farming it out to a gangland gunman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Civil Aeronautics Board, in what was called a "basic shift" in favor of expanding low-cost charter flights, said today that it was ready to develop a broad program for cut-rate group travel but insisted that a change in the law was necessary first.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13, (Reuters) The Sanete, criticized by President Ford for its slow pace of action, met and adjourned today in 18 second.

The day after Eli M. Black died, a suicide at the age of 53, a notice appeared in the papers. It announced that a West German chemical concern had bought a major subsidiary from the United Brands Company, the $2-billion conglomerate of Chiquita bananas and John Morrell meat products that Mr. Black had created in the late nineteensixties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Nancy Lammerding, social secretary to Betty Ford, was married here today to L. Nicholas Ruwe, who resigned last week as assistant chief of protocol at the State Department. Both the President and Mrs. Ford, who was the bride's only attendant, were present at the small, noontime ceremony in the chapel of the residence of the Apostolic Delegate here.

MAGNET Lovelace Watkins is a singer with a new show at the Waldorf-Astoria. He flashes a smile and easy warmth, belts out "Once in a Lifetime" in a piercing in a Lifetime" and instantly connects with the audience. He shakes hands around the rim of the stage, asking people to clap tempos and talks pleasantly about his career overseas and in Las Vegas, while modestly expressing hopes of catching on here, in his local debut.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 13 (UPI) the dollar lost ground again today on most European currency markets, despite intervention by the West German Federal Bank in its support.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 (UPI) Ellis Rubin, the attorney who led the fight that lifted local area television blackouts of sellout football games, accused the Miami Dolphins today of dealing him a "cheap shot" by refusing to renew his season tickets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Industrial production showed an exceptionally huge decline of 3.6 per cent last month following a drop of 3.1 per cent in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For most of this century the trend has been toward feeding infants more solid foods earlier. It was once common to feed only milk for the first year; it is now common to supplement that milk with other foods such as cereal or strained fruit in the first month or two.

Ralph Fabri, an artist, writer and teacher, died here Wednesday at the age of 80. He lived at 54 West 74th Street.
Mayor Beame yesterday accepted an invitation to be the guest of honor at the annual lampoon dinner and show of the Inner Circle to be held at the New York Hilton on the evening of March 1.

Rosenbaum, called today for a grand-jury investigation of a series of campaign contribution shifts in which $1,250 from Governor Carey's campaign eventually reached an upstate conservative party worker who had embroiled former Gov. Malcolm Wilson in a campaign controversy.

ATHENS, Feb. 13 Greece tonight denounced the proclamation of an independent Turkish zone oh Cyprus as an "arbitrary and illegal" act that "endangers the peace in this delicate region."

DETROIT, Feb. 13 American new-car sales declined 5.1 per cent in the Feb. 1-10 period from last year, but this was the best showing since the 1975 models were introduced last fall. Price-rebate programs obviously helped the industry's Performance.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The United States is lending Bangladesh $30-million to help build a fertilizer plant with an annual capacity of 500,000 metric tons, according to an agreement signed here.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 Leonid I. Brezhnev, smiling and looking fit, emerged today from seven weeks of seclusion to greet Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain when he arrived at the Kremlin on an official visit.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association filed an unfair-labor-practice charge yesterday that accused the city of attempting to impose a pattern contract settlement on the 23,000 P.B.A, members by including "me, too" provisions in agreements with other city unions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 After two years of experience without the draft, the Defense Department concluded today that for the foreseeable future it could meet its military manpower needs with volunteers.

The head of the Soviet Union's main cancer research center said yesterday that cooperative studies by Russian and American scientists on the incidence of various cancers in the two countries might help mankind find the causes and means of preventing the leading cancer killers.

New York's thoroughbred trainers hinted yesterday there would not be enough starters for Aqueduct's Feb. 24 opening unless horses were permitted to race with certain pain-killers.

Nicholas S. Gesoalde, who had had a career of 69 years in pharmacy, died Monday in Port Jefferson, L.I., where he lived. He was 90 years old.

Genesco, Inc., the large Nashville-based producer and retailer of apparel and footwear, reported yesterday a net loss of $1.4-million for the second fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, in contrast to a net profit of $6.7million in the year-earlier period. Six-month earnings declined 76 per cent to $3.6-million or 15 cents a share, from the yearearlier $14.5-million, or $1.01 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Presidential election campaign of 1976 has already started over a year before the first primary in New Hampshire, 18 months before the nominating conventions, and almost 21 months before the final voting.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 Industrialized and developing nations agreed here today to begin on March 3 the detailed bargaining phase of their trade talks. WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today reprimanded station WBAI-FM in New York for broadcasting language it found "indecent."

Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's largest food chain, reported yesterday a decline in net income for the 16-week and 52-week periods ended Dec. 28. The decline is attributable to reductions resulting from the change in the last-in, first-out (LIFO) accounting method of inventories. Without the LIFO effect on results, the earnings would have reached records, as did sales for these periods.
MADRID, Feb. 13 Three Croats serving 12-year sentences for hijacking a Swedish airliner were pardoned today by Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 13 President Park Chung Hee suggested today that he would seek reconciliation with his opponents in the political parties, the Christian churches and the universities.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market climbed sharply yesterday in stepped-up trading.

New York City's Local Law 5, the most stringent high-rise fire safety law in the nation, is in trouble. Wilder Foote, who retired in 1960 as director of the United Nations press, publications and public services division, died Friday of a heart ailment in Rockland, Me. He was 69 years old and lived in Camden, Me.

Arnold Scaasi's attempt to swim upstream is working out quite nicely. Last year, the designer of custom-made dresses whipped up some hats at the request of a millinery manufacturer in Dallas. They sold so well that for spring he's producing them himself.

Yesterday, with extraordinary speed, presumably after consulting a panel of scientists, the Army approved this ruthless and questionable procedure.
A 27-year-old Queens man killed himself early yesterday after shooting four members of one family in the Ridgewood section of Queens following a "long-standing personal feud," the police said.

LISBON, Feb. 18, (Reuters)-- The Armed Forces Movement, Portugal's dominant political power since the coup last April, announced today that it would continue to play an active role in politics after elections this year.

After months of debate as to the possible role of spray can propellants in depleting the protective ozone of the strathosphere, a Federal group has been formed to assess the problem and, a week from tomorrow, will hold its first public meeting in Washington.

ROME, Feb. 18--The five watchmen on duty at Milan's Gallery of Modern Art when 28 paintings were stolen early yesterday had disconnected the electronic burglar alarm system, "probably to be able to sleep," the museum's director said today.

BONN, Feb. 18--A Philippine bambo organ, a historic instrument built in a parish church by a Spanish missionary a century and a half ago, trumpeted its return to the musical world today after more than a year of restoration here.

The country's major movie producers and distributors plan to establish a special security organization to ferret out and help prosecute pirates who obtain prints of films and show them illegally around the world.
FORT MILL, S.C., FEb. 18 (UPI)--Springs Mills has announced that it will shut down 17 of its plants for one week beginning next Monday.

With refreshing candor, George Meany acknowledges that his forecasts of how high unemployment is likely to go are pulled "out of the air"--the same air that generates the subjective estimates of White House economic advisers and all the other seers currently giving Congress divergent prescriptions on the precise degree of Federal stimulus needed to revive the economy.
TRENTON, Feb. 18--The New Jersey Supreme Court rejected today a legal move to force the Byrne administration to spend $120-million additional in state aid to public schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A day before the Senate planned to vote to delay President Ford's increased fees on imported crude oil, Mr. Ford lobbied hard today to rally enough Republican votes to sustain his expected veto of the measure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that President Nixon did not have the right to impound $9-billion in water pollution funds approved by Congress because the legislation authorizing the program had not given him that authority.
Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Paul Warfield of the Miami Dolphins asserted yesterday that they would be playing in the World Football League next season.

The W.T. Grant Company, financially troubled retail chain, announced yesterday that it was considering the sale of its 50.2 per cent interest in Zeller's, Ltd., a Canadian variety-store chain, to build up cash and to reduce its indebtedness.

The cost of feeding a family of four dropped slightly last week, O.I per cent below the previous week's level, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. It was the first fractional drop in a month.

REMSENBURG, L.I., Feb. 18--P.G. Wodehouse was eulogized by his friends today for bringing humor and happiness into the lives of millions and yet being unaffected by the fame that his work brought him.

FT. CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 19 (AP) Flying over two pine groves, Army helicopters began tonight the destruction of an estimated five million starlings and grackles.

Atef Gamel-Eldin, secretary general and counsel of the Houston-based AmericanArab Chamber of Commerce, has disclosed that a proposal for formation of an Arab-American bank is being circulated among unspecified United States banks and various Arab countries. If formed, the bank would be a 50-50 joint undertaking by United States banks and unspecified Arab interests.

A 16.8 per cent average in- crease in rates for about 3 mil- lion Blue Cross and Blue Shield hospital insurance subscribers was approved yesterday by the State Insurance Department.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 The Sovet Union will supply Egypt with enough arms between now and June to make up for most of the losses suffered in the 1973 war with Israel, according to East European and Lebanese press sources here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Defense Department reported today, in the first full public listing of its technical assistance contracts with foreign countries, that Government and private teams were training military personnel in 34 countries under contracts worth $727-million.

Richard J. DeHaan, vice president for finance and administration at the University of Connecticut, was found dead Tuesday in the garage of his home at 16 Willowbrook Road, Storrs, Conn. He was 45 years old.

Hilda Holland, who had been associate editor and advertising manager of American Judaism, an official publication of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, died Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital, following a taxi accident Saturday. She was 74 years old and lived at 345 West 58th Street.

With 51 seconds left and each team shooting the puck back and forth, Greg Polis, New York's hottest player, slammed into the boards and had to be helped from the ice in great pain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company says a Government demand for documents in its antitrust suit could cost the Bell System $300-million and "20,000 man years of effort."
QUIET VICTOR Ian Hugo, who has been called a "dedicated artist of the cinematic eye," is an experimental movie maker whose 12 short works spanning 25 years have won him an international reputation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Supreme Court ruled today that the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, having violated a 1962 antitrust consent decree, must pay a $1,000-a-day fine for continuing violation, rather than a single $5,000 penalty for the illegal acquisition itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 In a 2-to-1 decision, the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals held today that the Government had acted illegally in letting some domestic crude oil sell at unrestricted market prices since January, 1974.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 The state has dropped from the latest version of a New York City pollution-control plan its longstanding demand for tolls on the East River bridges, Ogden R. Reid, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, told the Legislature's fiscal committees today.
TRENTON, Feb. 19 A Long Branch police officer who shot to death a 16-year-old high school student on Dec. 8, was indicted here today by a state grand jury on charges of manslaughter.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 19 With 165 bowlers in a field of 192 failing to shoot for at least a 200 average par in the pro ranks lefthanders took over the top five positions tonight at the first two six-game, qualifying rounds were rolled in the $60,000. Long Island open bowling tournament at Garden City Bowl.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) Walt McKechnie, playing his first game for the Detroit Red Wings, scored on a power play at 11 minutes 15 seconds of the third period tonight to give the Wings a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 19 Luigi Dallapiccola, one of Italy's foremost composers and musical theorists, died here today at the age of 71. He was taken to a hospital several days ago suffering from a pulmonary condition. Death was attributed to a circulatory ailment.

An unusual solution to an old problem was devised last month by a group of Westchester players. The problem is how to avoid rescheduling a head-to-head team-of-four match when one player falls ill at the last moment. The solution was to go ahead with the match, but arrange a telephone hookup from the sickbed to the playing scene.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Feb. 19 (AP) Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan, the Nazi concentration camp guard who later was a Queens housewife, was indicted today with nine other Germans on charges connected with the killing of 250,000 inmates of a Nazi camp in Poland. The trial is scheduled to start this summer.
An outspoken critic of Luis Fuentes, the suspended superintendent of Community School District 1, has been named acting superintendent of the strife ridden Lower East Side district.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The lawyer who prepared former President Richard M. Nixon's tax returns and the appraiser who valued the pre-Presidential papers claimed by Mr. Nixon as a tax deduction were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to commit fraud and other crimes in connection with Mr. Nixon's tax returns.

Roy White signed his 11th contract with the New York Yankees yesterday and got a slight raise to around $90,000, despite being so disatisfied with his status last season as a designated hitter and part-time left fielder that he had asked to be traded. The 31-year-old White had played in 388 consecutive games before pulling a leg muscle last May while sliding into third base in Boston.
Unlike Japan, where the white dog is extremely popular, so much so that the Maltese is the No. 1 breed, in Switzerland the all-white canine is in scarce supply.

WASHINGTON At a recent dinner party in the suburb of Chevy Chase, part of the old foreign policy establishment came together in a moving and courageous display of support for one of its embattled members, former Central Intelligence Agency Director Richard Helms.

That great connoisseur of living, Fernand Point, is supposed to have said that a woman under 40 wasn't worth talking to. If publications can be judged the same way, perhaps a magazine under 50 isn't worth reading. The New Yorker, which celebrates its 50th birthday this week, was always worth reading except for an occasional touch of turgid profilese. In its style and its content, it is a connoisseur both of art and life.

A 57-year-old Manhattan man described as a major distributor of pirated motion pictures was arrested yesterday at his Broadway office, where a police raiding party seized illegal master copies of more than 500 commercial movies, including. "The Godfather," "Planet of the Apes" and "Deep Throat."

The battle of the burger continues in New York, generating heat and litter. Community protest increases as the number of fast-food places grows. "Protest is a fact of life which we accept," says one McDonald's spokesman. "We must be doing something right," says another, referring to an apparently insatiable demand for Big Macs.

Frightened parents forced the closing of a Bronx public school and the mass testing of about 2,000 pupils and teachers by the Department of Health yesterday following the death from meningitis last Friday of a 6year-old first-grade pupil.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Ford expressed regret tonight at the Senate vote delaying for 90 days his increased fees on imported crude oil but said he did not regard the Senate action as final.
Fans of the two-pronged attack will be excited to learn that Allied Mills, Inc., is planning just such an attack on the $1.4-billion dog food market.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 Rich Degnan found the Nassau Coliseum track to his liking tonight and set a meet record in the 600-yard run. Rudy Reavis found fault with the high-jump runway and still posted a meet mark.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 19 A class action suit alleging kickbacks to the Republican Party by county employes was dismissed in State Supreme Court here today.
Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal Court upheld yesterday the dismissal of a black principal at Mark Hopkins Junior High School-33 at 70 Tompkins Avenue in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Bernard Bergman and an aide refused to answer questions today at a Senate hearing about their nursing-home operations, citing their Constitutional rights under the Fifth Amendment.

Three teen-agers who are accused of stabbing to death a 23 year-old graduate student on a crowded, rush-hour subway train in Upper Manhattan on Tuesday had been riding back and forth on the train, looking for someone to rob, the police said yesterday.
Prices of soybeans and corn tumbled sharply again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, continuing Tuesday's downtrend.

WALLACE, N.C., Feb. 19 The 12-year drive by the Textile Workers Union of America to organize the J.P. Stevens Company's Southern textile mills stalled again today when employes here voted not to affiliate with the union. However, union officials indicated they would probably file unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board to have the election voided.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., A Municipal Court judge here has set upon a new, old way to write wrongs. Judge Gary W. Thomas has taken to sentencing petty of fenders to write repeatedly a promise not to violate the rules again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Officials of the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission clashed here today on legislative safeguards they consider necessary to reform the securities industry.
A 16.8 per cent average increase in rates for about 3 million Blue Cross and Blue Shield hospital insurance subscribers was approved yesterday by the State Insurance Department.
George Van Santvoord, who was headmaster of the Hotchkiss School from 1926 to 1955, died yesterday in Williamstown, Mass. He was 84 years old and lived in Bennington, Vt.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 19 Although Billy Paultz missed three periods, the 6foot-11-inch Nets' center was a factor in the New Yorkers' 113-91 victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Permits for new housing starts plunged to a record low in January, although actual starts rose slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 After finding a National Basketball Association opponent whose recent form was even worse than their own, the Knicks alertly used the opportunity tonight to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 109-94, before a jeering crowd of 8,056 at Cobo Arena.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 19 Shops and offices were closed and few people were on the streets in Asmara today after a night of fierce gun battles between Government troops and secessionist guerrillas, Ethiopian and foreign residents of the city reported by telephone.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 A group of Senators and Representatives is scheduled to fly off this weekend, at the State Department's suggestion, for a ten-day visit to South Vietnam and Cambodia. They will be accompanied by high State and Defense officials, and on the scene they will get the usual official guidance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) In parallel statements to Congress, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company and the president of the United Automobile Workers Union said today the country was heading for economic disaster and efforts so far by the Government to change course have been unavailing.
The city obtained yesterday the lowest-interest-rate on its notes in eight months an average of 7.0783 per cent in a borrowing of $260-million.

DETROIT, Feb. 19(UPI) The United Automobile Workers and General Motors have reached an agreement calling for the automaker to provide health and life insurance coverage for blue collar workers even if they are laid off after the supplemental unemployment benefit fund has been depleted.

The World Trade Center, which suffered heavy fire damage to several floors a week ago, reports that anonymous telephone callers have threatened to set "more fires" unless Trade Center maintenance workers receive two weeks' back pay they won last month in a new contract settlement.
Despite the heavy Senate vote yesterday to delay President Ford's proposed energy program, Mr. Ford and Congress seem to be sparring rather than trying to knock each other out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Supreme Court said today that the Internal Revenue Service, in investigating suspected tax cheats, had the right to compel banks to make available records about large numbers of depositors.

Death by violence came to three people on the Upper West Side Wednesday night. One victim was a woman, and another was the older man she had been sheltering in her apartment for nearly 10 years. The third victim was a neighborhood fence, who had been arrested 24 times in the last 30 years. All three were shot to death.

Warren R. Jollymore, who had been director of public relations for the Chevrolet Motor division of the General Motors Corporation since June 1, 1972, died yesterday in a hospital in Detroit, following a stroke. He was 53 years old.

Some of the spontaneity and iconoclasm so evident in Second City improvisations are demonstrated in "Sweethart," a new "play with music" now running at the ETC Theater. Actually that comes as no surprise since the author, director and star of the show is J.J. Barry, a worthy graduate of Second City.

R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of cigarettes, announced yesterday that Malcolm P. McLean, a director and its largest preferred stockholder, would sell 1 million shares of Reynolds convertible preferred stock for conversion to common stock that would be resold to the public.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)--President Ford signed today a bill temporarily increasing the national debt limit from $495-billion to $531-billion through June 30.
Jimmy Connors, America's top-ranked tennis player and one of the sport's more controversial figures, has refused to sign with the Pittsburgh Triangles of World Team Tennis.

PENSACOLA, Fla. Feb. 20 (UPI)--A Tampa man was found guilty today of attempted hijacking in what was believed to have been the first conviction of its kind since Congress amended the air piracy statute to include planes on the ground.

Although concentrations of DDT have declined in the world's temperate zones over the past decade, its global spread is now as great as or greater than it ever was. Some 22 per cent of this dangerous pesticide now in use is still exported from the United States, where its domestic application is banned--but not its manufacture.
CAIRO, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Egypt warned Israel today that plans to build a $10-million aircraft plant in East Jerusalem was "aggression" that could blow up chances of peace in the Mideast.

"When Oki was tired of writing, or when a novel was going badly, he would lie down on the couch in the open corridor beside his study. In the afternoon he would often fall asleep there for an hour or two.

Two viewpoints on why today's parents seek out so much help: One is that we have become but quivering shadows of our own parents, insecure and helpless, needing instruction at every step. The other is that we are just now finding out how much there is to learn about the job of raising children.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 --The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. warned today that the nation's economic crisis was growing at a "frightening speed" and called for massive emergency measures.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 (AP) --Jim Cleamons, Dick Snyder and Dwight Davis combined for 49 points and the Cleveland Cavaliers held off a fourth-quarter Washington rally to defeat the Bullets, 106-95, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Federal Power Commission began an investigation today to determine why certain offshore natural gas is not being produced and sent to market to alleviate the acute natural gas shortage.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)--A group calling itself the Nixon Historical Association says it will try to raise money to buy two Key Biscayne homes owned by former President Richard M. Nixon and preserve them as historical sites.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland Feb. 20--The organizers of the 1976 Montreal Olympics, using the right words and pictures, have regained the confidence of the International Olympic Committee. They'll be trying to keep the faith once a month for the next year. During that time, the I.O.C. will have no choice but to believe.

ALBANY, Feb. 20--The State Board of Regents today significantly softened its earlier opposition to the use of ethnic balance as a measure of integration by implicitly returning to the Commissioner of Education the power to move against districts with racially imbalanced schools.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 20 --About 100 minority students of the University of Michigan ended today their three-day occupation of the school's Administration Building after university officials said that they could not meet the group's demands immediately.

The bill to cut personal and business taxes by $21.3billion that has now cleared the House Ways and Means Committee is the essential first step in the campaign to halt the most serious slump the United States economy has experienced since the 1937-38 recession.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (AP)--North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces carried out attacks in the Mekong Delta and near Saigon today, shelling population centers, blowing up bridges and striking at a regional headquarters of the international peace-keeping force, the Saigon command said.
PARIS, Feb. 20--The number of Soviet military advisers and equipment experts in Libya has more than doubled in the last year, a reliable source said here today.
Francis E. Waters went on trial in Federal District Court here yesterday on charges of selling heroin in 1968 shortly after he resigned as a narcotics agent in New York.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 30--A sensational one-minute-53.5-second anchor leg by Ron Stafford gave hometown Maria Regina an outstanding victory tonight in the twomile relay at the Nassau County high school track meet in the Coliseum.

Ted Irvine of the Rangers, who scores few points, and Denis Potvin of the Islanders, who scores a lot, were honored yesterday for something that had nothing to do with points. Both players won Good Guy awards from the New York Chapter of the Professional Hockey Writers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A House subcommittee ended today the first round of hearings on legislation to limit the use and availability of guns, and its chairman said he expected some form of gun control to be passed by Congress this year.

LIMA, Peru,--For centuries, Latin-American writers, artists and intellectuals have traditionally been the political gadflies of their countries, often enjoying a following and influence far greater than their colleagues in Europe and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) --Lynn Townsend, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said he told President Ford today that "the auto industry is in serious, serious, serious difficulty."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (AP)--Lee Trevino, who hadn't planned on competing and didn't expect to play well, shot a solid five-underpar 66 today and established a first-round lead of one stroke in the $150,000 Glen Campbell-Los Angeles open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Senate reformers were foiled today in their attempt to modify the Senate's filibuster rule by the superior parliamentary skill of Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama.

Edo De Waart, the young music director of the Rotterdam Philharmonic and recently appointed principal guest conductor of the San Francisco Symphony, came to Avery Fisher Hall with the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Wednesday night to conduct a program that was partly American, mostly Russian.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--Iran set a high parity today for the rial against the dollar because of the decline in the United States currency's foreien-exchange value.

Business loans at major New York City banks, after tumbling sharply from Jan. 1 through early February, rose moderately in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Oil Minister Manei Said Uteiba said in an interview published today that Abu Dhabi's foreign partner's in its two largest oil consortium's face retaliation unless they increase oil production by 40 per cent.

W.H. Krome George, 56, was named chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday at a board meeting in Pittsburgh. Mr. George, who will continue as Alcoa's president, will take over his new post on March 1.

The expected appointment of Kieran O'Doherty, a founder and vice chairman of the state's Conservative party, as a $38,000-a-year commissioner of the Postal Rate Commission was announced yesterday by President Ford.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 20--A second-year pro. Tony Maresca, widened his lead from 4 to 41 pins tonight as match play began in the $60,000. Long Island open bowling tournament.

Any current interest in the composer Niccolo Piccinni is historical. He is famous in the music encyclopedias for being a major rival of Gluck's in the late 18th-century Parisian operatic scene, a rivalry stirred more by the two composers' followers than by themselves. Gluck won out, and his operas still hold the stage today. Piccinni's works are almost totally ignored.

When performance time came, he had to replace Mr. di Giuseppe.

WASHINGTON, Feb.20--The nation's governors voted 28 to 12 today against a tariff on imported oil and other pricing devices that the Ford Administration wants to use to slow energy consumption.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The chairman of a national commission studying gambling said today that leaders of professional and amateur sports had failed to make a convincing case against legalizing gambling on team sports.

Richard O'Connor, who wrote some 60 books, mostly biographies and popular history, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Ellsworth, Me. He was 59 years old.

LISBON, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Government announced a blueprint today for state control of key industries and the breakup of big agricultural land holdings.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 20 (UPI)--Premier-designate Seni Pramoj's efforts to form a government took a bizarre turn today when he suddenly canceled the presentation of his cabinet to King Phumiphol Aduldet, saying his coalition had split, only to discover it was a mistake.

TRENTON, Feb. 20--An appeals court ruled today that a state legislator could not have access to files of a special joint legislative-ethics committee despite his assertion that its records might give him guidelines for avoiding violations of conflict-of-interest statutes.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (Reuters)--A murder indictment has been returned here in the death of a rock musician of a drug overdose, sources on the county grand jury said today.

DETROIT, Feb. 20--The Ford Motor Company reported today net earnings of $22-million for the fourth quarter of 1974--a drop of 61 per cent, from the $57-million earned during the same three-month period in 1973. Rafael Kubelik, completing his two-week stint as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, is leading the orchestra this week in Brahms's Symphony No. 2 and Frank Martin's Petite Symphonie Concertante for Harpsichord, Harp, Piano and Double String Orchestra, and the two works bring out the best in him.
Barbara Rich Rinkoff, an author of books for children and young adults, died Tuesday of cancer at her home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Her age was 52.

TRENTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) A new policy on fighting pollution is emerging from the State Department of Environmental Protection.
HANOVER, West Germany, Feb. 21 (Reuters) Works of art worth more than $4.6-million have been stolen in burglaries here and in Frankfurt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission said today it had asked a court to force some of the nation's biggest companies to surrender detailed information about their profits and losses on individual product lines.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 21 President Park Chung Hee's new political structure, announced last week, will include a new supreme council, a reshuffled Cabinet and a revitalized National Assembly, an authoritative member of the ruling party said today.

TRENTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) Health Commissioner Joanne E. Finley said today that $34.8million in impounded Federal funds were now available to New Jersey for the construction of hospitals and other health facilities.
