NEWARK, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Federal Government announced today that it had allocated $33.9-million to help subsidize rents for 7,772 families in New Jersey.

Edward H. Watson, a geologist who studied the terrain of Brazil's interior to determine the feasibility of building the new city of Brasilia, died yesterday in his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 72 years old.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 A Soviet writer who recanted his antiSoviet views was given a suspended sentence today at the end of his trial in Leningrad, according to Tass, the official press agency.

Grains and soybeans dropped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to adoption by the European Economic Community of import levies on corn to reduce European demand for United States corn, used mainly to feed livestock.

The highest short interest position in its history was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange for the month ending in mid-February. The exchange said the figure rose to 25,121,419 shares from 20,813,260 in mid-January.
BRAWLEY, Calif., Feb. 21 The residents of Brawley are finally beginning to relax. But it hasn't been easy.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24 Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor on corruption in the criminaljustice system who was arrested in Nassau County on Jan. 19 on a charge of speeding. While driving a stateowned car, has paid a $20 fine in the case, it was reported today.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Speaking calmly but bitingly, the Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, criticized Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak today in a speech on the floor of the Senate, where such personal attacks have been rare.

NEWARK, Feb. 24 The New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies will need $133-million in additional capital during the next five years to maintain, improve and "de-institutionalize" its facilities around the state, Ann Klein, the Commissioner, said today.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry P. Van Dusen, leaders in American theological life, swallowed over doses of sleeping pills last month in the bedroom of their Princeton, N.J., home in an effort to carry out a suicide pact.

The Transit Authority yesterday formally accused its police chief, Robert H. Rapp, of making false statements about payoffs from subway concessionaires to transit policemen, and of encouraging or condoning the falsification of subway crime figures.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 25 Country Woman, an interesting yacht with an interesting name, won the MiamiNassau ocean race today by 2 minutes 24 seconds over Stinger after the two raced almost bow-to-bow over 21 hours through almost 200 miles of the Atlantic Ocean.

TRENTON, Feb. 25 Governor Byrne asked the New Jerseys State Supreme Court today to give the Legislature until July 1 to approve a new system of financing public schools in the state instead of the Oct. 1 deadline the court had set last month.

VIENNA, Feb. 25 A declaration by oil-exporting countries of guaranteed levels of supply in exchange for guaranteed income from industrial consumers was debated here today at a ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Eggs dropped 4 cents a dozen last week, following a 3-cent drop the week before and now, with the white, Grade A Large size selling at 86 cents a dozen, this superior source of protein is 16 cents a dozen cheaper than it was a month ago, according to the weekly-market basket reports of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

The first few men got on the breadline before 6 A.M., and when it opened an hour later there were 200 of them, waiting to get a baloney sandwich and coffee in a cardboard cup. Brother Albert Aldrich stepped out from the kitchen then, and held up his hand. "O.K.," he said, "ladies first."
Daniel P. Moynihan, former American Ambassador to India, said today that the United States should drop its defensive attitude toward the new United Nations majority of third-world countries.

Through the ages, attractive females have tried many ways of fending off unwanted suitors, but some female insects have evolved perhaps the most effective method chemicals that turn off the sexual interest of unsuitable males.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 The Senate today overwhelmingly passed a bill authorizing the State Commissioner of Health to appoint an older person in each county of the state to serve as a nursing-home patient-advocate to investigate, complaints from residents and make reports to the Commissioner.

ALBANY, Feb. 25-Governor Carey today asked the Legislature to set up a new state agency designed to rescue the insolvent Urban Development Corporation by floating its own bonds and serving as a conduit for more than $250-million in state subsidies.

In an effort to unscramble the oftenbewildering arrows, images and verbiage cluttering air, rail and bus terminals, some of the nation's leading designers have devised 34 standardized graphic signs to speed travelers on their way. The results, which go on view at an East Side gallery today, may prove just as puzzling at least at first glance in the opinion of the designers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The attorney for a stenographer in Speaker Carl Albert's office charged today that an influence-peddling investigation that resulted in the stenographer's indictment was an at tempt to defame the Speaker of the House.

WASHINGTON Feb. 25 The Civil Aeronautics Board has failed to take any action against American Airlines even guilty to making illegal campaign contributions almost a year and a half ago, Ralph Nader said today.
Kaufman Broad, the West Coast-based multinational home builder, announced yesterday that it had obtained a new $111-million domestic credit agreement from a group of 16 banks.
EVANSTON, Ill. Contrary to popular conception, the Indians who lived in the Central Mississippi River Valley in 6500 B.C. were not primitive savages who struggled just to survive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Controversy over the nomination of Nathaniel Davis to be Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs continued today as Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. called for withdrawal of the appointment.

Community groups opposed to the construction of a United States Postal Service garage under new housing in Chelsea won a victory yesterday when a Federal judge here granted a preliminary injunction against the start of the project.

Michael Haran brought an unusually austere program to Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, bracketing the introspective D minor Sonata of Faur and Ten Variations by Haim Elisha with two long, unaccompanied works: the Bach Suite in D and Kod ly's Sonata (Op. 8).

BRUSSELS, Feb. 25 (UPI) The dollar rallied slightly at the close of trading today on European foreign-exchange market's in apparent response to a decision by oil-producing countries to retain the United States currency in calculating the price of crude oil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Supreme Court held today that school officials who discipline pupils unfairly cannot defend themselves against civil rights suits by claiming ignorance of the pupils' basic constitutional rights.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (UPI) George Parnassus, the boxing promoter who was credited with bringing big-time boxing to southern California in staging more than 100 title fights, died early today in his home at the age of 78.

ALBANY, FEB. 25 The State Court of Appeals found today that there was "overwhelming proof" that Alice Crimmins killed her 4-year-old daughter in 1965. The court statement was made as it overturned a lower court's reversal of Mrs. Crimmins's manslaughter conviction in the death of her daughter.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland "Their general opinion is that it were better for England if this whole island were sunk into the sea; for they have a tradition that every 40 years there must be a rebellion in Ireland."
DETROIT, Feb. 25 The American Motors Corporation today became the second auto maker to announce price cuts to follow the rebate programs, credited with lifting depressed new car sales.

Commodity futures priced generally moved lower yesterday, dragged down partly by much lower prices for gold and silver. The most immediate reason for the decline in the two metals was a statement by Jamshid Amouzegar, Iran's Interior Minister, that he favored continued use of the dollar as a means of payment to oilexporting countries. On the news the dollar rose sharply in terms of many other currencies.

American education has devoted too much of its resources to massive remedial instruction, and not enough to the prevention of failure. Wasteful of manpower and funds, this policy is even more severely flawed in human terms. The frustrations suffered by children who cannot keep up with their peers are hard to erase, even with superficially effective remedial work.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 Two long established unions in the textile and clothing field are discussing a merger as a means of strengthening their organizing and service activities.

Elliot L. Richardson, scheduled to take up his duties in London Monday as the new American ambassador, privately told British correspondents that there was an even chance Secretary of State Kissinger would resign before the end of President Ford's term and that he would probably become his successor, The Chicago Sun-Times reported yesterday.

Henri Simonet, vice president of the European Economic Community in charge of energy policy, strongly supported a world floor price for oil yesterday. In New York, after speaking to energy officials in Washington, Mr. Simonet said he thought that a floor price of $7 to $8 for a barrel of oil would be advisable, although he said that the Common Market had not made any major study of the question.

In an unusual move, the Federal Trade Commission ,reversed its position yesterday on an agreement it had reached with the Xerox Corporation to settle an antitrust complaint that it had brought against the copying-machines maker two years ago.

Margaret Thatcher, leader of the Conservative party of Britain, chose "a Tory's Tory" yesterday when she named Lord Thorneycroft as party chairman. He replaces William Whitelaw, now Mrs. Thatcher's deputy in the House of Commons, as chairman a role that mainly involves keeping the party in trim.
City officials said yesterday that they had promised to remove hazardous conditions from 37 day care centers here by March 5 or risk the permanent loss of millions of dollars frozen by the state.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25 Yemen today became the first Arab country to sentence a hijacker to death.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Federal Power Commission ordered today for the first time a comprehensive inventory of the nation's natural gas reserves.
There are a number of people who would love to ban advertising from children's television programing. Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, however, is not among them.

Interest rates have declined sharply this year in the face of heavy financing activity and the prospect of much more over the next several months. Along with the decline in interest rates, investors have become less insistent on higher yields for riskier bonds.

LONDON, Feb. 25 The British Government announced plans today for a basic tax rate of 45 per cent on oil revenues from the North Sea to be sure that the nation will benefit fully from its rich underwater petroleum deposits.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. The American Bar Association called on Congress today to let people of moderate income deduct personal legal expenses from their income taxes the way they now deduct some of their medical expenses.

Rod Stewart, the Scottish-English rocker who appeared with his band, Faces, for a sold-out Madison Square Garden concert Monday night, first emerged in the mid-nineteen-sixties as a member of the Jeff Beck group. He then switched over to Faces, and has alternated on disks between Faces albums and solo albums ever since.

TRENTON, Feb. 25 Having lost his legal battle to have a bid-rigging indictment against him dismissed, former Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel was reported tonight to be seeking to stand trial without a jury.

Investors holding bonds and notes of the financially troubled Urban Development Corporation suffered a severe setback yesterday as the state housing agency notified its bankers that it could not meet $104.5-million in payments due yesterday.
LAUDERHILL, Fla., Feb. 25 "Big business, show business and sports go together like apple pie and ice cream," says the official program of the 1975 Jackie Gleason Inverray Classic golf tournament.
NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 25 Mrs. Pauline Dresser Merrill, widow of the Rev. George Grenville Merrill, died yesterday. She was 98 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Federal Reserve Board has already set in motion actions that should lead to a "quicker pace" of expansion of the nation's money supply, Arthur F. Burns told Congress today.
Last October, Barbara Saslaw Dixon decided not to buy salad oil for a while: Soybean oil futures were selling at the Chicago Board of Trade for the unusually high price of almost 50 cents a pound.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged yesterday that two Federal agencies and six private companies were violating Government civil rights laws by discriminating against Jews, either under orders from Arab countries or voluntarily in the hope of obtaining business in Arab countries. CHICAGO, Feb. 25 Mayor Richard J. Daley, the last of the big-city Democratic bosses, routed three opponents in the Democratic primary in his bid for an unprecedented sixth four-year term as Mayor of the nation's second largest city.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 It was precisely seven years ago that Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller was frustrated by voter rejection, on two occasions, of low-income housing proposals.

Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, testified today that the New York City transit fare would rise a nickel, to 40 cents, on April 1, unless the state substantially increased its subsidy program. BRUSSELS, Feb. 26 (UPI) The dollar hit its sixth record low in as many trading days in Amsterdam today. On other European money markets, the United States currency also dropped, cancelling the preceding day's rallies and edging toward record laws 'reached' earlier in the week.

SQUDERTON, Pa. An abandoned little bank, a stack of cast-off furniture and cartons of odds and ends may not look like the foundation for a cultural revival. But here in a small town 25 miles north of Philadelphia these things are being transformed into a "heritage center" for one of America's oldest and least conspicuous communities: the Mennonites of eastern Pennsylvania.

Henri Cartier-Bresson, if not without question the greatest of living photographers, must certainly be considered one of the three or four principal contenders for the title. His name is a byword for distinction, and his pictures are avidly published and collected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 With a growing sense of futil ity, the United States continues to urge a negotiated end to the Cambodian war, but State Department officials said today that they were not even certain with whom the Phnom Penh Government of President Lon Nol could negotiate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. said today that the United States Embassy here appeared to have adopted a policy of "tacit acquiescence" in the arrest of political prisoners by the Saigon Government.

SOUTH AMBOY, Feb. 28 About 1,000 relatives, friends, former students and fellow clergymen gathered in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today for the funeral of the Rev. Thomas J. Quinlan, who was shot to death last Monday morning at the parochial school in Penns Grove where he was principal.

MANILA, Feb. 28 (AP) Early official returns from the referendum on President Ferdinand E. Marcos' oneman rule have given him nearly 90 per cent approval, but he has suffered a minor setback in one province.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 28 Thirteen opposition politicians said today that they had been tortured by South Korean security agencies soon after President Park Chung Hee seized emergency powers in the fall of 1972.
Vice President Rockefeller resigned yesterday as chairman of the Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, which he created.
Katherine Roberta Anderson and Samuel Khoury were married yesterday evening in the Calvary Methodist Church in Arlington. Mass., by the Rev. Alfred Perry.

A suit charging Newark with violations of Civil Service regulations was dismissed yesterday by Judge Melvin P. Antell in Essex County Superior Court when the city agreed to rescind an order dismissing 32 Public Works employes.

BUFFALO, Feb. 28 Relatives of a blind 93-year-old Seneca Indian woman testified here today that when they had gone to visit her at a local nursing home they found she was being beaten "by about 10 nurses."

PHNOM, PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 28 The heavy steel grates of Phnom Penh's shops have been locked and barred for the last week. The stalls in the central market are deserted at what should be the afternoon rush hour. There is fear in the Chinese community and the economic heartbeat of this isolated city of two million people has come to a virtual halt.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 The recent rush of baseball talent into New York continued today when the Mets paid the San Francisco Giants close to $150,000 for the power-hitting Dave Kingman.

BUFFALO, Feb. 28 A former Attica Prison inmate testified here today that he had seen John Hill, one of two defendants on trial here charged with killing Correction Officer William E. Quinn, strike an unidentified correction officer with a board on the morning the prison rebellion started in September, 1971.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 28 The feeling throughout the American Basketball Association is that the Spirits of St. Louis are going to be one of the league's top clubs once they get some experience. They showed continued improvement tonight at the Nassau Coliseum despite a 117-110 loss to the New York Nets.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 28 Marion County Prosecutor James F. Kelley dismissed today criminal charges against two investigative reporters of The Indianapolis Star who were indicted by a local grand jury last September for alleged conspiracy to bribe a police officer.

It was a railroad that ran one day only that happy day two years ago when Mayor John V. Lindsay inaugurated what the city billed as the "Overland Rail Route" linking the Brooklyn waterfront for the first time to the mainland rail network for freight service.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28 Five militant Arab nationalists from the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River and East Jerusalem, detained in Israeli prisons, were expelled today across a United Nations checkpoint into Lebanon.
Three of the country's largest banks the Bank of America, First National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reduced yesterday, the interest rates they charge on loans to corporations.

When the King of Thailand and his friend and relative, the new Premier, get together, they may just be jamming. King Phumiphol Aduldet, who is a noted jazz musician, plays the clarinet and saxaphone. Premier Seni Pramoj plays the double bass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a modified air fare discount that would let the nation's airlines offer discounts of 20 to 25 per cent over some 60 per cent of all domestic routes.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has acquired a 50 per cent interest in six hotels from the Hilton Hotel Corporation for $83.4million. Of the sale price, $65.95-million is cash and about $17.4-million is ex isting mortgage indebtedness. The transaction results in a nonrecurring gain, after applicable income taxes, of $27.3-million, equal to $3.26 a share based on 8,365,942 Hilton common shares outstanding, according to Barron Hilton, president of the hotel chain.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 Governor Carey today appointed his campaign manager, Gerald Cummins, as chairman of the State Thruway Authority, thus maintaining the post's tradition as a leading patronage award.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 28 Leftist guerrillas tonight killed a United States honorary consul whom they had abducted, the police said.

PORT HAWKESBURY, Nova Scotia, Feb. 21 When environmentalists all over the United States are battling the oil industry and blocking its development,, this maritime province is actively soliciting supertankers and refineries for a new deepwater port.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 28 Cambodian Government forces today began an effort to push enemy rocket emplacements out of range of Pochentong Airport, the last remaining supply link between the capital and the outside world.

Or merely the place where the greatest number of manufacturing facilities is located?

TOPSHAM, Me. The wet snow drops straight and steadily. Somewhere between our home and the center of town, the burden of its beauty is too much for an aging wolf pine. A limb snaps and falls, taking the roadside utility lines down with it. Our lights blink and die; the furnace shuts down, as do our water pump and refrigerator. We have lost our power, as they say in Maine.

LAUDERHILL, Fla., March 1--The thing about Jack Nicklaus that his fellow pros admire more than his superb golfing talent is his competitive spirit. Today the Golden Bear showed how competitive he can be by working his way our of the field to take the lead in the third round of the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic.

MONTAUK Dr. Henry W. Moeller knows how to turn adversity into scientific and probably economic triumph. While unsuccessfully experimenting with the cultivation of seaweed, Dr. Moeller, a botanist at the New York Ocean Science Laboratory here and an associate professor of biology at Dowling College in Oakdale, has developed a mobile method of raising mollusks in plastic netting that not only allows growers to avoid polluted waters, but also increases the yield.

As before, you can slip out into the lobby during the marathon for supper or refreshments, even linger for a continuous screening of the Ren Clair film "Entr'Acte" (to the piano music of Satie).

Menahem Begin, the perennial leader of the opposition to the perennial Labor party Governments, is not beset by soul-searching.

Nathan's Famous, Inc., said yesterday that it had entered into negotiations to acquire control of the Wetson's Corporation, which operates a 28-unit chain of fast-food restaurants in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The negotiations are in the initial stage.

The persuasive, almost obsessional Catholicism that runs through Jos Coronado's works gives them a brooding, mystical character that is at times exceedingly obscure. Suffering is almost a way of life. Mr. Coronado presented a program of his works, including the new "Almas," on Sunday evening at the Washington Square Methodist Church.

The first life I remember taking belonged to a very young chicken. It was trailing its mother under a widemesh wire fence I happened to be descending and I stepped on it. It was a shattering experience. I was restored only after earnest maternal assurances that it was a deed done without malice or intent and didn't matter anyhow because it was only a chicken.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 3 In the solitude of an empty track, Roosevelt Raceway staged an eerie program of harness racing tonight after pari-mutuel ticket agents had gone on strike and forced the track to shut its doors to the public.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 One soldier was killed and 29 were wounded when their truck was ambushed in the strife-torn southern port of Saida today, according to a military communiqu issued here.
WASHINGTON, March 3 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The Daily News shut down operations for the second day after newspaper deliverers, protesting new work schedules, defied a preliminary injunction last night and refused to report for work.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The staff of the new Senate Budget Committee said in a report to the members today that it was possible, chiefly through a much larger tax reduction than proposed by President Ford, to achieve a faster and stronger recovery in the economy than the Administration projects, and to do so without adding to the inflation danger.

WASHINGTON, March 3 The widows of five of 25 workers who died of lung cancer and the president of the chemical company where they worked clashed today before a Senate subcommittee in their descriptions of what efforts the company had taken to protect the workers.
MONTREAL, March 3 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire's goal in the second period proved to be the winner as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the California Seals, 4-2, in the National Hockey League tonight.

A five-story factory building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn vacant since the Detecto Scale Company left in 1971 will be remodeled into a "vertical industrial park." It will be the first such venture in the country to be financed with a Federal grant.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) An investigation of Illinois thoroughbred racing led today to charges against 12 trainers for allowing 40 horses to be drugged prior to races at three Chicago area tracks.
Procter Gamble, television's biggest national advertiser, has just made an unusually large newspaper buy, according to trade sources.

A state agency yesterday proposed mandatory deposits on all beer and soft-drink containers, including bottles, cans or cartons, but with a delay in enactment this year "due to the serious economic conditions in the nation and the state."

WASHINGTON, March 3 A score of liberal activist groups representing factory workers, teachers, farmers, environmentalists, mayors, churchmen and home builders announced a new coalition today to lobby for domestic and human concerns in the Federal budget.

BUFFALO, March 3 Defense lawyers mounted a cumulative challenge today to the credibility of a former Attica inmate who testified last week that he had seen one of two defendants on trial here strike a fallen correction officer when inmates first laid siege to the Attica State Correctional facility on Sept. 9, 1971.
WASHINGTON, March 3 The major elements of a possible energy compromise between the Ford Administration and Congress began to take shape today at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing.
Two elderly women died last night in a three-alarm Bronx apartment-house fire that authorities said had been set by a 4-year-old boy.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3 (UPI) Bombs exploded in a community center and a fish-and-chips shop in a predominantly Roman Catholic neighborhood today, wounding four persons in what the police said could be part of a continuing feud among rival Irish republican groups.

Despite the praise and enhanced stature that he won for reversing United States policy toward mainland China, former President Nixon could never quite bring himself to revise the Government's similarly anachronistic stance toward Fidel Castro's Cuba. Now, with a President unburdened by emotional attachments to the policy of an earlier decade, the Administration is, in Secretary of State Kissinger's words, "prepared to move in a new direction" toward Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 3 Paul A. Zeitz, a 16-yearold Brooklyn youth who is first in a class of 700 at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan was awarded the first prize of a $10,000 college scholarship in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, tonight for work in advanced theoretical mathematics.

Don Kurth runs to his mailbox six times a day. "I guess it's just out of habit," said Mr. Kurth, a senior at Columbia College who has applied to 21 medical schools and is waiting for replies. "I'm also chewing my nails and getting a lot less sleep."

SHIPROCK, N.M., March 3 (UPI) Armed members of the American Indian Movement ended today their weeklong occupation of an electronics plant under a grant of unconditional amnesty from its Navajo owners.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3 President Tito has begun a political campaign against suspected adversaries at home and abroad.
Single-game insurance policies similar to the flight insurance available at airports ought to be made available to players skating on Madison Square Garden ice.

BERLIN, March 3 The West German Government flew five imprisoned radicals to the Middle East today in capitulation to the demands of kidnapper's who have been holding a Berlin political leader as a hostage here since Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 A score of liberal activist groups representing factory workers, teachers, farmers, environmentalists, mayors, churchmen and home builders announced a new coalition today to lobby for domestic and human concerns in the Federal budget.
The stock market advanced impressively yesterday in much heavier trading as investors continued to draw encouragement from sliding interest rates.

Steel production in the week ended March 1 rose to 2,723,000 tons from 2,710,000 tons in the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The latest index was 111.6, up from the previous week's index of 111.1.

Buying by holders of short positions to even out their accounts and take profits brought a strong rally in grain and soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The upswing came after sharply lower prices early in the session a continuation of several weeks of sliding prices.
SCRANTON, Pa., March 3 (AP) Striking teachers shouted down today what was described as a final offer at ending their week-old walkout that has closed the city's 32 public schools.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Fast but noisy supersonic transports would be allowed to operate on commercial flights into the United States under rules proposed today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

The city's Human Rights Commissioner, Eleanor Holmes Norton, said yesterday that Vietnam veterans with less than honorable discharges were being discriminated against in job opportunities, and she urged an ungraded-discharge system for all veterans.

Otto Winzer, the former East German Foreign Minister and last survivor of the group of hardline Communists around the late Walter Ulbricht, died yesterday at the age of 72. His death was announced in East Berlin by the East German Communist party's Central Committee, of which he was a member.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 (AP) A helicopter crash today killed the Chilean Defense Minister, Gen. Oscar Bonilla, and six other persons.
A woman gave birth in the women's rest room on the second floor of the Criminal Courts Building yesterday.
SMITH RIVER, Calif., March 3 (AP) A fifth person died today following a shooting yesterday in which a gunman armed with a high-powered rifle opened fire from a balcony at a motel here.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ill., March 3 (UPI) A Lawrence County farmer said today that starlings and blackbirds caused damage estimated at $1-million in the last 18 months in his area and that a committee of farmers would seek a Federal permit to control the birds.

Castle Cooke, Inc., of Honolulu is scheduled to have a change in command on April 1. Donald J. Kirchhoff, 49, president and chief operating officer of the company since June, 1973, is to succeed Malcolm MacNaughton as chief executive officer. Mr. MacNaughton, who joined the company in 1942, will become 65 on Sunday. He will continue as board chairman.

William T. Coleman Jr. was confirmed by the Senate yesterday as Secretary of Transportation, and will become the second black Cabinet member in history. He was preceded by Robert C. Weaver, who became Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in 1966.
MOSCOW, March 3 The Bolshoi Theater announced today that its ballet and opera companies would make a joint tour of the United States for the first time this summer.

WASHINGTON, March 3 A monthly forum for Government regulators, the "usually' unfamous" but nonetheless important officials sometimes overlooked in Washington, was opened today by Ralph Nader and his public citizen organization.

Charges of attempted murder and robbery against a 19-yearold Brooklyn youth were dropped yesterday because two police officers had persisted in their belief that he had been mistakenly, identified and arrested as an accomplice in the crime.

SHELTON, Conn., March 3 The people of this mill town took stock of their position today following the blast and fires that destroyed a multimillion-dollar rubber factory, wiping out 800 jobs. They found little reason for hope.

The question most punctually tossed at a movie critic (it starts after a month at the post) is whether you're tired of movies, or if you've ceased to enjoy them. The answer from this corner is that the appetite has only increased. But you need to keep widening your movie experience in order to stay fresh, especially through seeing revivals of many styles and periods while you're saturated in the idioms of contemporary film.
An event that was once part of every tournament program but is now on the endangered species list ended the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional at the New York Hilton Hotel here Sunday.

A generally held view among experts in the contraceptive field is that each woman's needs and circumstances must be considered individually before choosing a contraceptive. Implicit in this view is criticism of physicians who stress a particular method they favor, rather than giving the woman a choice from among all the alternatives.

Governor Carey's move to provide immediate state funding for his new Project Finance Agency offers the missing link-hard cash-that could salvage his faltering plan to save the Urban Development Corporation from bankruptcy.

Lehman College fought off a determined second-half effort to beat City College, 54-51, and capture its second straight City University of New York basketball title last night. A crowd of 800 watched the final at Queens College.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday plans to borrow $600-million by issuing debentures and notes.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 A perjury charge alleging that John D. Erlichman lied to a Los Angeles County grand jury about his involvement in the break-in of a Beverly Hills psychiatrist's office was dismissed today by a Superior Court judge here.

ALBANY, March 3 Governor Carey's request for $110million to allow the Urban Development Corporation to pay its bills stalled in the Legislature today. The leaders were in apparent agreement that $110million was more state money than the U.D.C. needed to stay alive right now, but in a series of meetings throughout the day they could not agree on how much was enough.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) The Justice Department filed suit today to force the International Harvester Company to sell its holdings in Steiger Tractor, Inc., on the ground that it was in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Esmark, Inc., Chicago, the world's largest meat packer, and the Rapid-American Corporation, a holding company for major consumer-goods concerns, yesterday announced angreement calling for the acquisition for $210-million of the International Playtex Company by Esmark.

Ely M. Aaron, a Chicago lawyer since 1919, and chairman of that city's Commission on Human Relations from 1960 to 1966, died yesterday at his home. He was 78 years old.

Martin on the Vietnam issue. At least two of them were said to be considering recommending that he be replaced as Ambassador to South Vietnam.

Levine, the State Industrial Commissioner, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) The Ford Administration wants to cut Federal school lunch subsidies for children from middle-income homes, and Agriculture Department experts say that up to six million children could be involved.

Food prices dropped 1.4 per cent in New York City last week, one of the largest de clines of the recent inflationary period, which began with the feed grain crisis of 1972. WASHINGTON, March 4-- Secretary of State Kissinger leaves for the Middle East to- morrow, guardedly optimistic that he will persuade Israeli and Egyptian leaders to make the compromises necessary to bring about a new Sinai agree ment.

TRENTON, March 4--Gover nor Byrne said today that he had appointed Joseph Wein- traub, former Chief Justice of the New Jersey State Supreme Court, to head a study of the embattled State Commission of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) --The Federal Power Commis sion proposed today an eight- point program to stimulate nat ural gas production, beginning with the revocation of its own authority to regulate natural gas prices.

BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, March 4 (AP)--Pedro Aleixo, who was deposed as Vice Presi dent by the military in 1969 to prevent his succession to the presidency, died yesterday of a heart attack following emphy sema. He was 73 years old.

Thomas P.F. Hoving, di rector of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has agreed to serve as interim director of the crisis-ridden Queens Museum.

GENEVA, March 4--The first intensive international effort to remove through collective bar gaining major impediments to trade other than tariffs was begun today in the framework of the new round of multina tional trade talks.

ST. ANDREWS, New Bruns wick--This eastern-most area on the long friendly border between Canada and the United States has become the focus of a diplomatic dispute that is causing concern in both Ottawa and Washington.

PATERSON, March 4--Juan Colon, a 21-year-old unem ployed factory worker and drug addict, was convicted today of first-degree murder in the fatal beating of a 79-year-old Roman Catholic priest hert on Oct. 29.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., a diversified industrial and financial services company, re ported yesterday earnings in creases of 37 per cent for the fiscal second quarter, ended Jan. 31, and 38 per cent for the fiscal first half. Revenues were up 20 per cent in both periods.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Three Senators called on the Ford Administration today to normalize relations with Cuba.
GENEVA. March 4--West and East Germany joined the Geneva disarmament conference today and pledged to play an active role in the search for arms accords.

BRUSSELS, March 4--The foreign ministers of the nine Common Market countries agreed here today on the need to support the development of alternative sources of energy. But they made no concrete decision to adopt a plan, like those suggested by Secretary of State Kissinger and the Common Market Commission, to insure that the price of oil does not drop below an agreed minimum price.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday soared to the second highest level in history. Prices ended with only moderate gains but at the highest point in six and a half months.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- President Ford announced to day that he would postpone for 60 days the two final stages of his oil import tax to encour age Congress to work out a compromise energy program by May 1 and to move faster on a cut in income taxes as a spur to the lagging economy.
The Bolshoi Opera, in its first visit to the United States, will open a four-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 25 with its production of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov."

AMMAN, Jordan--King Hussein of Jordan is personally more involved with the question of Arab-Israeli peace than any other Arab chief of state for the simple reason, as he puts it, that four generations of his family have been linked directly to Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Administration's proposal for $222-million in emergency military aid for Cambodia re ceived a serious setback today when a House Appropriations subcommittee delayed action on the request.
NEW BRUNSWICK, March 4--Yesterday, this was a one-horse town. Today it sur rendered the distinction, along with the horse.

The Average White Band's concert at Avery Fisher Hall Monday night--its first here since the death of its original drummer and the chart-topping success of its latest single and album--was an obvious hit with the audience.

Impatient with further de lay, Chief Judge David N. Edel- stein yesterday set May 19 in Federal District Court here as the new starting date for trial of the Government's massive six-year-old antitrust suit against the International Busi ness Machines Corporation.

There are about 500 people who gather and edit the news at The Daily News and yester day afternoon, even before the job furlough became official, many of them were on the tele phone telling their families that they were about to join the unemployed.

Hazel Mallory, a 70-year old Chicagoan, has become so adept at making toy ani mals she can turn out a siz able pink elephant over. night, She is one of a group of 150 women, average age 75 who crochet and stuff a whole menagerie of cuddly animals to be sold under the Elder Artisans of Chicago la bel.

A New Jersey Superior Court judge yesterday ordered Hill side High School in Union, County to readmit a girl who had been suspended from classes since Jan. 13 for al legedly fighting with another student. The order also directed the school to provide "special in school academic instruction" to help the girl make up missed work.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The Senate Finance Committee took a major step today toward separating the controversial and emotional issue of repeal of the oil depletion allowance from the antirecession tax-cut bill.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 4-- The favorites advanced to night in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey playoffs, but not easily. Boston Univer sity, the defender, was forced into overtime at home before beating Brown, 5-4, while Vermont overcame a 5-2 Providence lead with five goals late in the third period to win, 7-5.

St. Louis, March 4 (UPI)-- Julius Erving and Billy Paultz triggered a third-quarter surge that sent the New York Nets to a 110-106 victory over the spirits of St. Louis tonight in the American Bas ketball Association. Erving tallied 36 points and Paultz 24.

ALBANY, March 4--Directors of five of the state's largest public housing authorities called on the Legislature today to enact a $87-million program to stem the deterioration of public housing and to meet rapidly rising costs of fuel and utilities.

The Boston Celtics turned Madison Square Garden into a disaster area for the Knicks last night. While the capacity crowd of 19,694 booed and chided, "Put in the second team," the Celtics battered the Knicks, 126-111.

Violence came in two sizes last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, where the Joffrey Ballet gave the first performances this sea son of two Gerald Arpino ballets; "Valentine" and "The Clowns." "Valentine" tells of a sexist boxing match, while, with escalating violence, "The Clowns" describes the aftermath of an atomic doomsday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) --Congessional investigators charged today that some offi cials of the United States Geo logical Survey owned stock in companies holding, mineral leases on Federal lands ad ministered by the agency.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4--The Yankee script writers' dream could turn out to be only that--a dream.

Food prices dropped 1.4 per cent in New York City last week, one of the largest de clines of the recent inflationary period, which began with the feed grain crisis of 1972. The drop was exceeded in magni tude only by the 2.1 per cent decline of the week of Aug. 20, 1973, produced at that time by the meat boycott.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Horseracing may need some kind of Federal regulation unless state governments stop treating it merely as a source of tax revenue, the industry's top spokesmen conceded today.

LANDOVER, Md., March 4 (UPI)--Gilles Gilbert turned in his third shutout of the season as the Boston Bruins trounced the Washington Capitals, 8-0, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Gilbert stopped 27 Washing ton shots.

One of the more bizarre stories in American sports history--an evening of har ness racing unfolding in front of a deserted grandstand-- ended yesterday when pari mutuel clerks voted to halt their strike against Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- The helicopter carrier Okinawa, with several hundred marines aboard, has been in the vicinity of the Gulf of Thailand for several weeks in case it is nec essary to evacuate American civilians from Phnom Penh, a Defense Department source said today.

WASHINGTON--The plane came down into New York through a heavy snowstorm, an hour late, and was diverted from La Guardia to Kennedy. Appointments of Great Importance were being jeopardized or canceled as our taxi crept slowly into Manhattan. Snow was falling steadily, the roads were slippery and everything was a mess. New York seemed at its most difficult, and the logistics of surviving through a two-city work day seemed hopeless and impossible.

A campaign to bring the John F. Kennedy Library to New York has been quietly started by City Council President Paul O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, March 5- Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States would have to reassess its emergency airlift of military supplies into Cambodia if the Cambodian Government was unable to provide adequate protection for the Phnom Penh airport.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, March 5-In a crowded hotel meeting room here, 300 miles below the Arctic Circle, a far-reaching national debate has opened on the future of Canada's vast northlands.

DETROIT, March 5 Final Ford Motor Company new-car sales figures for February released today were enough to push the sales total of domestic any imported cars for the month past the same period a year ago.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 5 (UPI)-George Gervin scored 34 points tonight in pacing the San Antonio Spurs, to a 122-109 triumph over the New York Nets, in an American Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, March 5 Manufacturers' inventories rose in January by the smallest amount since August, 1973, but some build-up persisted, the Commerce Department reported today.
ALGIERS, March 5 The Shah of Iran said today that it was ridiculous to speak of reductions in oil prices without simultaneous reductions in the prices of industrial goods.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The commission assigned to reshape Federal gambling legislation wound up two days of hearings on horse racing today with grave doubts about that industry's ability to take care of itself.

NEW DELHI, March 5 An ousted Cabinet official told Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today that her Government was floundering and that "chaos and anarchy" loomed in India unless the Congress party spurred rapid social and economic changes.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The Agriculture Department rejected the objections of consumers and announced today that it was putting into effect virtually unchanged its revised beef grading standards.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 6 The eight-day-old coalition Government of Premier Seni Pramoj was defeated in a confidence vote in the National Assembly today.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 6-This capital's airport was shelled heavily today for the second day, as Government troops struggled to reach the area to the northwest from which the rockets and artillery rounds were being fired.

At first, said Philip Pilevsky over a cup of coffee at a diner in Whitestone, Queens, the banks were reluctant to lend to him and his partner. That has changed. In the last five years they have built about 200 small stores in the city at an estimated construction cost of $25-million.

The Concord String Quartet has been heard here often since its formation three years ago but usually in new works. Wednesday night in the Hunter College Playhouse, it had a relatively conventional program to itself, made up of Beethoven's Quartet in G (Op. 18, No. 2), Berg's Lyric Suite and Dvorak's "American" Quartet.

For longer than he likes to remember, Robert G. Rhett, a purchasing executive at the Kennecott Copper Corporation, has been paying ever-increasing prices for the wide range of materials and manufactured products he buys for his company.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was questioned yesterday about a hitherto undisclosed 1962 report on the nursing-home industry, that found "no improvement in the overall operation" of the industry after the 1960 Kaplan report.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the country's largest merchandising concern said yesterday that sales for the five-week period to, March 1 fell to $1.08-billion, or 0.l per cent below the level in the corresponding period of 1974.

JERSEY CITY, March 6 Jersey City firemen said today that they had received favorable public reaction to the telephone campaign to stop the city from dismissing 65 fire fighters next month for economy reasons.

Cause I've been to these meetings when I was in the Farm Workers .

Federal Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld yesterday denied a motion by the Justice Department to delay a financing and divestiture plan involving Avis, Inc., which had been submitted by the company's court-appointed trustee, Richard Joyce Smith.

The Senate liberals have marched up the hill and down the hill and arrived, if not exactly where they started, not very far away. The vote to impose closure on the long filibuster conducted by Senator James Allen, Alabama Democrat, and his allies clears the way for a final vote on the so-called compromise proposal to reform the Senate's rules.

John Edwards McKay, who was product director of the baby products division of Johnson Johnson, surgical goods manufacturer, when he retired in 1965, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 57 years old.

Running for President is a hard and chancy business in this huge country, full of varied interests and attitudes that one man can rarely satisfy. Gerald Ford and Henry Jackson are finding that out and Nelson Rockefeller, who got the point in 1960, 1964 and 1968, is being taught it all over again just in case he'd forgotten.

WASHINGTON, March 6 The Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education urged today that the Federal Government embark on a multibillion-dollar program of subsidizing the tuition of students in private colleges and universities

WASHINGTON, March 6 Representative Al Ullman, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that he expected the House to pass by April 30 a major energy bill that includes an increased gasoline tax, gradual decontrol of crude oil prices, a windfall profits tax on oil producers and "a very flexible quota on imports geared to the economy."

FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 6 Reuters) West Germany announced today a half-point cut in its bank rate, from 5 per cent to 5 per cent. The new rate, effective tomorrow, was announced by the central bank (Bundesbank) after a meeting of its central council here. The Lombard rate, which commercial banks pay for central bank credits against securities, was also cut effective tomorrow from 7 per cent to 6 % per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 6 The Republican National Committee softened even further today an already cautious reform program, then approved it with almost no dissent.

ALGIERS, March 6 The oilexporting, countries offered today to negotiate with industrial nations on the "stabilization" of oil prices. But they stressed that the agenda of a conference could riot be limited to diseussion of prices.

The Mayor's now dominant role in the budgetary process would be further curtailed in the proposed charter revision by removing him from participation in Board of Estimate action on the budget. That would eliminate his power to veto any reduction or deletion in the budget made by the Council and Board of Estimate. Sole authority to override a mayoral veto would be vested in the Council, a power it now shares with the Estimate Board.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 6 (AP) David Thompson's 38 points, including four free throws in the last 15 seconds, sealed a 91-85 victory for North Carolina State over Virginia tonight to climax an exciting first round of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

Dan Wagoner is a choreographer who is attracting increasing attention, and his company, Dan Wagoner and Dancers, got off to a good start Wednesday night at Pace University's Schimmel Center. The group will perform there again tonight and tomorrow night.

TRENTON, March 6 (AP) The state announced today that 67 illegal aliens had been discovered working at two plants of the Heidenberg Corporation in Closter. The Department of Labor and Industry said they had been found during a joint state-Federal examination.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) Ambassadors and other diplomatic representatives of 33 African nations went to the State Department today to protest the nominaion of Nathaniel Davis as Under Secretary of State for African Affairs.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6 Mr. Yunich will be subpoenaed to appear before two Assembly committees conducting hearings on the state's five transportation authorities if he refuses to do so voluntarily, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, said today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) Arthur F. Burns chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today defended his decision to ask for an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on whether any employe of the board had leaked information on bank interest rates to a magazine.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday that ridership on its subway and bus lines was down by 200,000 passengers a day in January, compared with the same month a year ago.

JERUSALEM On his new trip to the Middle East, Secretary of State Kissinger will be trying to reconcile Egypt's inkerest in the return of some territory and Israel's interest in some progress toward peace. Isr el's Premier, Yitzhak Rabin, has used the pungent formula: "A piece of territory for a piece of peace." This formula leads to a problem: How do you measure a "piece of peace"? I would like to suggest an operational test.

WASHINGTON, March 6 In recent years' prominent figures in the news have begun peddling their appearances on television for fat fees, and even the Soviet Government will now sell you a TV act by a tame poet if you'll pay its price.

A group of Japanese business executives, touring the United States in an attempt to learn more about its economy, stopped in Atlanta yesterday and proposed a closer relationship between "businesses in Georgia and Ja pan "for mutual benefit and profit "

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 6 A goal by Jude Drouin with 2 minutes 21 seconds to play enabled the New York Islanders to salvage a 2-2 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight and gave them an important point in the National Hockey League standing. It also began a sevenday, five-game stretch that will severely affect their playoff chances in the Patrick Division.

Strong export buying of grains and soybeans for export pushed prices ahead on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. A large acceptance of deliveries of March contracts by some leading exporters was also considered a buoyant factor along with a report that the House agriculture committee had voted by a large margin to set one-year loan prices for wheat, corn and soybeans.

WASHINGTON, March 6 Lots of nonconductors are getting into conducting these days, from David Oistrakh to Yehudi Menuhin to Daniel Barenboim to Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau to Placido Domingo to Sherrill Milnes. Some of them have stuck Mr. Barenboim in particular. But there remains a certain residue of cynicism about such career expansions, with a strong whiff of self-indulgent dilettantism hanging in the air.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)-The Agriculture Department announced the removal today of export curbs on major farm commodities imposed last fall to help conserve dwindling United States supplies of grain and soybeans.

"Gee, what's that great smell?" he asked. "Oil paint and turpentine," he was told.

The nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers slashed capital appropriations by 24 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974, The Conference Board reported yesterday. The appropriations, or authorizations for capital improvements, amounted to $12.45-billion in the quarter, seasonally adjusted, down from a record of $16.4-billion in the third quarter.

The Signetics Corporation of Sunnyvale, Calif., a manufacturer of integrated circuits and semi-conductors used in a wide range of electronic products, announced yesterday that a preliminary agreement had been reached with United States Philips Trust for the acquisition of Signet- ics by the Trust.

ASWAN, Egypt, March 6-Egyptian officials waiting for the arrival here tomorrow of Secretary of State Kissinger today reasserted Egypt's desire to reach a second-stage military disengagement agreement with Israel through American mediation, in spite of the Palestinian attack on Tel Aviv.

The New York Stock Exchange took the unusual step yesterday of suspending shares of a listed company on the ground that the company no longer met minimum exchange standards as to market value and earnings.
The third fire in eight days at a major New York Telephone Company installation in the city yesterday was declared "suspicious" by the Fire Department.
The commodity spot market price index of footstuff and industrial materials fell to 196 from 199 last week.
TRENTON, March 6, AP The New Jersey State Bar Association announced today the formation of a special committee on legal services to the elderly.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 6 The pilgrims of the pro golf tour, making their second Florida stop, took advantage of the season's first warm weather today to rout the pussycat Rio Pinar Country Club course, extracting 47 subpar scores and 29 more at even par in the opening round of the Florida Citrus open.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) The House Agriculture Committee approved today an emergency increase in 1975 price supports for milk, wheat, corn and other major crops despite warnings that the bill faced a Presidential veto.
BOSTON March 6 (UPI)? Chris Evert and Evonne Goolagong won opening matches in the Virginia Slims of Boston tennis tournament, tonight and will be paired in tomorrow's semifinals.

The Schubert Mini-Festival at Lincoln Center moved to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, presumably to feature non orchestral works performed by the Chamber Music Society, which is associated with the New York Philharmonic in presenting the Festival.
GENEVA, March 7 An attempt by the Swiss Cabinet to find a compromise on the abortion issue, which sharply divides the nation, suffered a sharp setback today in the lower house of Parliament.
The New York Public Library plans to occupy the entire sixstory building it owns across Fifth Avenue from the Main Library after the Arnold Constable department store moves out next month.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 6 (AP) Sergi Volkov of the Soviet Union held the lead going into the final men's event, the freeskating, hoping to win another gold medal for his country in the world figure-skating championships.

PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP) Bob Hassett and Tom Sheldon finished 1, 2 in the 200-yard medley to help Maryland to the team lead after tonight's six final events in the Eastern Intercollegiate invitation swimming meet.

MIAMI, March 6 (UPI) Officials of the Florida Secretary of State's office have ordered the Nixon Historical Association to halt fund solicitation to buy former President Richard M. Nixon's two Key Biscayne homes until the project is properly registered and approved by the state.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) All but two of the nation's 23 nuclear power reactors have passed a Government-ordered test for cracks in their cooling pipes and most already are back in operation, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

W.R. Grace Co., a major chemical and natural resources concern, reported yesterday increases of 17.2 per cent in profits for the fourth quarter and 53.1 per cent for all of 1974.

GARY, Ind. Racial politics is common enough in America these days, but in the Democratic mayoral primary here there is a new twist. The two main candidates are black, and they are arguing about treatment of the city's white minority.

The Penn Central Transportation Company, which has been in reorganization since it went into bankruptcy in June, 1970, reported yesterday continuing huge deficits. For the month of January, it lost $48-million on fully accrued basis. In January, 1974, the net loss was $34.2million, Revenues, however, improved.by 2.2 per cent to $170million from $166-million.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 6 Antioch College's Board of Trustees meets this weekend for what has been termed a "showdown" vote over whether to dismiss the college's president, James P. Dixon Jr.

R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed secondary offering next month of 2.1 million shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) Bankruptcy filings in the last six months rose 33 per cent from the year-earlier level, Rowland F. Kirks, director of the United States Courts, said today.

SHREWSBURY, Mass., March 6 (AP) A Shrewsbury policeman was wounded fatally last night when he apparently stopped a man for questioning in a motel parking lot here. With new series coming and going like perishable guests or the talk-show circuit, last night was NBC's turn to offer a couple of contenders for syndication immortality. "Sunshine" traces its roots to the outstanding drama spe- cial of the same name that was carried many months ago on the rival CBS network (which gives some indication of how competitive patterns are being disrupted). "The Bob Crane Show" is, technically speaking, an original.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) A $12-billion emergency subsidy designed to lower mortgage interest rates and revive the depressed housing market was approved today by the House Subcommittee on Housing. The vote was 12-4, divided strictly along party lines, with the Democrats in the majority.
LONG BEACH, Calif., March 6 (UPI) The layoff of 1,000 workers is expected tomorrow at the Douglas Aircraft division assembly plant of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation here, union sources said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP) Dr. Leon Goldman, a prominent surgeon and medical educator, died here Tuesday. He was 71 years old.

HARRISBURG, Pa. March 6 (AP) Michael Kallinger, a 13year-old accused of participating with his father in a $20,000 robbery, was committed to a youth development center today for personality diagnosis and psychiatric evaluation.

Valerie Louthan, the redhaired Irish designer who heads her own knitting mill in Scotland, is busily bringing, luxurious old cashmere sweaters into the modern era. Her latest wrinkle: styling them as softly as blouses.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) The obliteration of black rights that followed reconstruction a century ago could recur unless Congress extends the Voting Rights Act, a former chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today.

While the price varies a good deal, nutritionists agree that there is not enough difference among the various kinds of orange juice to matter. What's more, man-made products don't show up badly either.

BUFFALO, March 7 Defense lawyers in the Attica murder trial moved today to subpoena Vice President Rockefeller as a witness.
A Presidential Commission on Olympic Sports has been set up to analyze the multitude of problems facing amateur athletics in the United States and to offer long-term solutions.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (AP) The California Supreme Court has agreed to review a state bar recommendation that Donald H. Segretti be disciplined for his Watergate activities.
ATLANTA, March 7 (UPI) The Boston Bruins whipped the Atlanta Flames, 4-2, tonight, with the line of Andre Savard, Don Marcotte and Terry O'Reilly accounting for the visitors' first three goals.

Henry W. Connelly, a partner in the New York law firm of Shearman Sterling, died Thursday of leukemia in the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo. He was 42 years old and lived in Short Hills, N. J.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 7 (UPI) Sergei Volkov skated conservatively but consistently last night, ignored a painful knee injury suffered in practice and became the first Soviet skater to ever win the world figure skating men's championship.
Murray Hartman, professor of English at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 55. His home was in Teaneck, N. J.

The city finally sold $537-million in bond-anticipation notes yesterday at the highest interest rates ever for this type of issue, ending marathon negotiations with bankers for a loan to meet the next payroll and two notes due Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 7 The Senate finally voted tonight to reform its filibuster rule.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7 Streetcars and buses will emerge from their barns Sunday after a winter-long hibernation, signaling the end to a strike of operators and drivers that deprived the city of its public transportation system for almost three months.

Daniel Carranza, a 22-yearold police informer charged with armed robbery and burglary, was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of six years in prison, after telling Justice Jack Rosenberg in State Supreme Court that he was guilty in both cases and would accept whatever sentence he deserved.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 7 A Long Island cab driver who was arrested Tuesday night in a 1950 Chicago murder was freed today at the direction of the State's Attorney's office in Chicago for lack of evidence.
AUGUSTA, Me., March 7 The Mid-Atlantic Sugar Corporation today withdrew its offer to purchase the idle sugar refinery in Easton, Me., for $2.3million.
WASHINGTON, March 7 The special Watergate prosecution asked Judge John J. Sirica today to dismiss the charges against the one remaining defendant in the Watergate coverup case, Gordon C. Strachan.
STANFORD, Calif., March 7 (AP) Howie Dallmar resigned tonight as head basketball coach at Stanford University, a post he held for 21 years, old. He had a 264263 won-lost record.

LONDON, March 7 The Continental Oil Company, one of the American oil companies operating in the North Sea, withdrew tonight the cautious welcome it gave to the British Government's proposal for a 45 per cent tax on oil revenues from the North Sea.

DIX HILLS, L. I., March 7 One year after their 9year old son, John, was kidnapped and then released unharmed for a $50,000 ransom, Michael and Juanita Calzadilla say they are still haunted by the experience.
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 7 Government troops have lost their last beachhead on the lower Mekong River, Cambodian and Western military sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Ford appealed tonight for a broadened Republican party embracing "all who care about this great country," implicitly rejecting conserva tive demands for greater ideological purity.

Governor Carey's proposed liberalization of unemployment insurance would restore New York State to its proper place in the front rank of enlightened social concern for those jobless through no fault of their own.

GENEVA, March 7 Industrial and developing nations agreed today on a list of 11 barriers to the free flow of international commerce that will have first priority in negotiations as the world trade talks here move into the negotiating phase.

A portrait of the days when the sidewalks of New York were the playing fields of footpads and thugs, when crime kept decent folk off the streets and when poverty and filth enshrouded the city emerges from "How Grim Was My City", an unusual exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Museum of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 7 President Ford appealed tonight for a broadened Republican party embracing "all who care about this great country," implicitly rejecting conserva- tive demands for greater ideo- logical purity.

A fourth fire within nine days struck a New York Telephone Company facility here yesterday, and the Fire Department said it was the second time in two days that the company had been a victim of arson.
For the last two weeks, a Chinese trade mission has been visiting New York's textile and fashion showrooms in the hope of gaining American know-how and building up two-way trade.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 7 By blowing up bridges and seizing one base camp in the last four days. North Vietnamese troops have succeeded in cutting the vital road that leads from Pleiku, the principal Government-held town in the Central Highlands, to the coast.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged in February at 8.2 per cent but, in a sign of continuing deterioration in the economy, the total number of employed persons dropped by more that half a million.

LONDON, March 7 Steadily falling oil consumption and an unusually mild winter in Europe have created the worst crisis in international shipping and shipbuilding since World War II.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 Ore month from the start of the regular season, baseball opened its exhi- bition program in Florida today with five games. But for the New York Mets and most of the other teams training in the sun, it was still the eve of battle, the final day of preparation before heading into 28 practice games and 162 that count.
BONN, March 7 West German officials say they believe unemployment has peaked here, with a slight increase last month to 5.2 per cent or 1,183,500 jobless the highest since February, 1959.

After decades of steadily rising construction costs, when budget overruns became the norm, the cost of public and private construction has started to dip below cost estimates as builders compete for the few available jobs.

The United States Export-Import Bank told Congress yesterday that it was prepared to extend a direct loan of $111.9million to British Airways for the purchase of 15 United States commercial jetliners costing about $373-million.

KILLINGTON, Vt., March 7 (UPI) Karen Colburn of Bangor, Me., and Robbie Huntoon of Brandon, Vt., won their mogul competitions today in the opening events of the United States national amateur free-style championships.

WOODBURY, March 7 Over vigorous defense objections, Judge R. Edward Klaisz Jr. of Gloucester County Court delayed the assault trial of a migrant-crew chief today to permit the state to bring two rebuttal witnesses here from Puerto Rico.
DALLAS, March 7 (UPI) Maurice L. Levy, a former National Broadcasting Company reporter and cameraman, died Monday of cancer. He was 52 years old.
The stock market, responding to favorable economic news yesterday, finished with a moderate advance in heavier trading.
TOKYO, March 7 Japan Air Lines, until recently the world's fastest growing airline, is faced with a deficit of $126-million in its current fiscal year, the largest of any carrier.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 7 (UPI) The defense rested its case today after former Gov. David Hall told a jury that United States Attorney William Burkett and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were willing dupes in a state and Federal plot to frame him.

HANOVER, N.H., March 7 Mal Howard of Princeton won his second event in the Eastern Seaboard swimmers' meet tonight and North Carolina State retained a narrow lead in the team scoring after 11 events. The Wolfpack has 210 points to Princeton's 197 in the three-day competition at Dartmouth's Karl Michael Pool.

Construction of a nursing home in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn--one of the first in a state program to bring nonprofit care for the elderly to minority-group neighborhoods--has been delayed, apparently the victim of a spillover of investor uncertainty over the financial problems of the state's Urban Development Corporation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8--North Vietnamese troops, which have stepped up coordinated attacks throughout the Central Highlands in the last few days, today overran a small district seat in Phu Bon Province, the Saigon command announced.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia March 8--Ambassador John Gunther Dean was rebuffed last year when he proposed to Secretary of State Kissinger that an attempt be made to establish contact with a key Cambodian insurgent leader to feel out the possibility of peace negotiations, according to sources in the United States Embassy here.

In the course of compiling productivity statistics, Mayor Beame's in-the-field productivity-measuring teams often employed somewhat odd measuring means, encountered unexpected roadblocks and were occasionally stymied.

Brenda Ann Kavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kavanagh of New York, was married yesterday to Nicholas J. Cooney of Ridgewood, N.J., son of Mrs. Nicholas Cooney of New York, and the late Mr. Cooney.

Dr. and Mrs. Hugo Bonom of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rita Bonom, to Edward B. Brunswick, son of Mrs. Alfred E. Brunswick of Philadelphia and the late Dr. Brunswick, who was an assistant professor of surgery at Jefferson Medical College. A June wedding is planned.

HACKENSACK--Although the recession has cut into the phenomenal growth pattern of the indoor tennis business in such big cities as Chicago and Detroit, the trade still appears to be alive and well in New Jersey's affluent suburbs.
The State Charter Revision Commission recommended yesterday that substantial changes be made in the way New York City plans and builds capital improvements.

ENGLEWOOD--Many a Bergen County husband, marveling at his wife's new culinary feats, doesn't know that it's all coming from Carol's Corner at a local butcher shop, T. Meats at 89 West Palisade Avenue.

SOUTH ORANGE--A free lecture series designed to help high school students understand vital issues and conflicts affecting the present and future will be presented at Seton Hall University, beginning Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California took a firm stand today against President Ford, Vice President Rockefeller and others who called this week for a Republican party broad enough to include moderates and liberals as well as conservatives.
There is probably no home maintenance problem that crops up more frequently--or causes more frustration-- than that of paint peeling, cracking or blistering around the inside or outside of the house.

Rabbit's tale. Once upon a time there was a sawdust velveteen-covered Rabbit who lived in a Boy's nursery, shared his owner's life and of course his bed. Though time faded the toy's features, the Boy came to love him as if he were a real rabbit. Then the Boy caught scarlet fever and the Rabbit was doomed for destruction.

Waiting at the starting line for the other runners from Oxford and Cambridge, I paced about nervously. Though I had arrived at Oxford with the attitude that I would run only to keep in shape, it was not long before I had come to regard my performances in meets as important.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 8--Funny thing about President Ford: Almost everybody is grumbling these days about something he has done or hasn't done, but nobody's really sore at him. The opposition around here to Rockefeller, Kissinger, and Simon is savage and personal, but unlike Nixon, who was blamed for everything, Ford somehow manages to avoid personal blame for anything.

Pierre Feit, the Frenchborn oboist known through a number of import recordings, and the Slovenian String Trio, formed by the broadcasting network in Ljubljana, Yugoslavia, made their New York debuts at Town Hall last Sunday.
Mr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Yaguda of Cranford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mona Shelley Yaguda, to Moshe Adam Ephros, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Z. Ephros of Brooklyn.

BEIRUT--While Secretary of State Kissinger flies between Egypt and Israel, trying to sell those two buyers on his second-stage peace plan in the Sinai, he is barely knocking on the door of another potential customer.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6--The Biblical bulrushes that hid the baby Moses in the Nile marshes and thus saved his life are being employed today in a quite different fashion to protect the health and lives of thousands of people in many parts of the world.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 8 (AP)--Five-time Dutch champion, Dianne de Leeuw outclassing her competition from the outset, employed a daring routine and captured the women's gold medal last night at the world figure skating championships.
POUND RIDGE, N.Y., March 8--Pound Ridge has nearly completed its plans for the bicentennial, and Fred Zwick, the Supervisor of this northern Westchester community, is getting excited.

Tom Wicker, political columnist and associate editor of The New York Times, treats himself as a variously flawed or capable stranger in this account of his four days as one of many observers, invited by convicts, at the catastrophic uprising in the Attica State Correctional Facility in upstate New York in September of 1971.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8--The New York Mets took their first steps on the "road back" today and fumbled into a 5-2 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals. But Tom Seaver, "anxious as a rookie," survived three innings on his own road back after his mysterious swoon of 1974.
STARKVILLE, Miss., March 8 (AP)--Kevin Grevey scored freshman center, Mike Phillips, added 26 as Kentucky beat Mississippi State, 11880, and won a share of the Southeastern Conference title tonight.

A delicate gray green tree stands alone on a page. Turn the page. The tree is cut and carved by tools into the shape of a book. "ABC" is chiseled into the cover. Both wood and tools are rendered with trompe l'oeil precision.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Political candidates and their contributing committees had more than $20-million left over at the end of last year.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif.--There are certain advantages (though not many) in having lived through more decades than one wants to be reminded of. One of them is now being enjoyed by people in their fifties and above. It is the knowledge that another depression would be no fun.
Mr. and Mrs. Bennett H. Shaver of Akron, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Joan Shaver, to John David Knight, son of Dr. and Mrs. Elmo L. Knight of Tonawanda, N.Y.

The Federal Government's latest figures show unemployment unchanged for the first time in months and inflation abating. But what appears to be welcome news is not entirely so. Both statistics disguise or reflect a continuing decline in the economy.
Marianne Ellen Chawluk and Robert Elmer Drumm of New York, Woodrow Wilson fellows and doctoral candidates at Columbia University, plan to be married in August.

Written in 1946, "Mercier and Camier" was Samuel Beckett's first postwar novel and his first in French. The manuscript was accepted in 1947 by Beckett's first French publisher, Bordas, but for reasons unknown he withdrew it before publication. For 24 years he steadfastly refused to allow it to be published, calling it a working draft or preliminary attempt to evolve a new technique in fiction.
